topic:
Marine Vegetation

Commercial harvesting of marine vegetation such as algae, seaweed and kelp for food and drug purposes.  

Recent research has shown that marine vegetation is a valuable source of both food (human and animal) and a potentially useful drug.  This search will focus primarily on these two uses.  Also to be considered relevant would be instances of other possible commercial uses such as fertilizer, etc.


You are a strict classifier for "commercial uses of marine vegetation".

RELEVANT if all of these hold:

- The document describes a specific commercial application of marine vegetation (e.g., human food, animal feed, pharmaceuticals).
- It identifies the type(s) of marine vegetation involved (e.g., algae species, seaweed varieties, kelp).
- It details processing or utilization steps (e.g., extraction methods, formulation, cultivation practices) or quantifies commercial outcomes (e.g., yield, market value, clinical trial results).

NON-RELEVANT if any of these hold:

- It only discusses ecological roles or environmental benefits of marine vegetation without reference to commercial exploitation.
- It covers wild-harvest biology or taxonomy without linking to commercial uses (food, drugs, fertilizer).
- It focuses on laboratory research on bioactive compounds without any mention of commercial development or market application.
- It describes non-commercial uses (e.g., personal hobby harvesting, cultural practices) without evidence of an industry or business context.

NEGATIVE Example:
Title: "The Role of Kelp Forests in Coastal Ecosystems"
relevant: false
justification: "Ecological study, no commercial harvesting or applications."

POSITIVE Example:
Title: "Seaweed Extracts from Laminaria japonica Developed into Animal Feed Supplements"
relevant: true
justification: "Marine vegetation: Laminaria japonica; Commercial use: animal feed; Details: extraction process and feed trial outcomes."

results.content:
NINE WAYS TO FIGHT FOOD POISONING 



   Food safety quiz:


   What does a hamburger teeming with sickening amounts of bacteria
taste like? Answer: A hamburger.


   That's the problem with most food poisoning _ the bacteria that
cause the misery of stomach cramps, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting
cannot be tasted, seen, or smelled, according to an article in the
July issue of Redbook magazine.


   And what may cause you a few days of feeling yucky can be a
serious, even life-threatening, illness for your child.


   ``Infants and small children are particularly vulnerable to the
toxic effects of food-borne illness,'' says Michael Reed, M.D.,
director of the Poison Control Center at Rainbow Babies and
Children's Hospital in Cleveland.


   The younger the child, the greater the risk of dehydration from
vomiting and diarrhea, which can put the body into shock. Since 50
to 70 percent of outbreaks arise from mishandling of food in the
home, there's plenty you can do to keep your family safe.


   Here are the summer troublemakers you're most likely to
overlook:


   1. Shopping trip-ups:


   The average food item in your local supermarket has traveled
nearly 1,000 miles to get there, notes Robert Hollingworth, Ph.D.,
director of the National Food Safety and Toxicology Center at
Michigan State University. And while the Food and Drug
Administration and other food safety experts estimate that
perishable foods items such as dairy products, meat, poultry, fish,
and vegetables can stay out of the cold for a total of four hours,
``It's probably way too long,'' says Winkler Weinberg, M.D., a
member of the Georgia-Pacific Health Smart Institute Advisory Board
in Atlanta.


   Assume any such food's time in the safety zone is nearly expired
and keep it out no longer than an hour, less if it's very hot _ 85
degrees or above.


   2. Hot cars


   The trunk is your car's hottest spot, and heat incubates
bacteria and other food-borne menaces. Stash groceries in the back
seat and turn on the air- conditioning, says registered dietitian
Molly Gee of the Methodist Health Care System in Houston. And make
grocery shopping the last stop on your list of errands.


   3. Cold storage


   If your refrigerator and freezer are stuffed full, air can't
circulate properly, which can create warm, germ-friendly spots.


   ``If your refrigerator is only 10 degrees above what it should
be, bacteria will grow,'' says Hollingworth. Keep shelves as clear
as possible and check your appliances' temperature: Refrigerators
should register 34 to 40 degrees and freezers should be at or below
0. (If your appliance doesn't have a built-in thermostat, buy one.)


   4. Problematic produce


   Raw fruits and vegetables are increasingly the culprits in
food-borne illness. Although much of our produce is now imported
from countries with less-than-rigorous food safety policies, you
can't be less vigilant with homegrown produce.


   ``There have been problems with local organic and small-farm
fruits and vegetables,'' says Hollingworth. Unless it needs to
ripen at room temperature, produce should be refrigerated
immediately. Don't bother to wash before storing _ it could get
contaminated in the fridge, and you'll need to wash it again, notes
Weinberg.


   Rinse before eating, then wipe dry with paper towels. Laboratory
tests show that rinsing plus wiping removes 99 percent of
contaminating germs while water alone removes only 75 percent.


   It's a good idea to wash and wipe even thick-rind fruits like
melon _ any microorganisms on the outside will be transported
inside as you slice.


   5. Germy hands


   Running the tips of your fingers under cold water does not count
as hand-washing, says Weinberg. ``Not only are your hands still
contaminated, but so is the dish towel you wiped them on.''


   Make sure all family members wash their hands for two minutes
(with warm, soapy water) after using the bathroom and before
eating.


   6. Marinating mishaps


   Defrosting or marinating meats on the kitchen counter provides
ideal conditions for bacteria to prolifera

results.content:
The Seattle Post-Intelligencer plans to move the following
stories for clients of the NYTimes News Service for editions of
Wednesday, June 3, and thereafter. If you have any questions,
please call Tina May at (206) 448-8355.


   SCHOOL-SALSA (Seattle) Listen up, students! Salsa is a
vegetable! (Yea right, so's catsup.) No, we really mean it. The
feds have decreed that schools can serve salsa just like it was a
side of peas or beans and it'll count as a vegetable. But no
dipping, please.


   By Kathy George. (story will move in the ``a'' category)


   DRUGS-FUTURE (Seattle) In the near future, pharmaceutical drugs
as we know them will be changed forever by the merging of two
exploding scientific fields -- genomics, or the study of the human
genetic blueprint, and information sciences. Drugs will be safer,
and more tailored to treat specific diseases with fewer side
effects, scientists said yesterday at an international meeting of
technology experts in Seattle. In addition, patients will be able
to tell before they take a drug if it will work for them, given
their particular genetic makeup. Such advances are being made
possible by applying the vastly increasing computational power of
computers to unraveling the mysteries of how genes interact in the
human body.


   By Carol Smith. (story will move in the ``f'' category)


   BBA-MARINERS (Baltimore) Mariners at Baltimore.


   By Jim Street. (story will move in the ``s'' category)


   BBA-JOEY-CORA (Undated) Seattle Mariners All-Star second baseman
Joey Cora says he plans to retire after the 1999 season to spend
more time with his family, a Puerto Rican newspaper (El Nuevo Dia)
reported.


   By Jim Street. (story will move in the ``s'' category)


   BA-COLUMN-VECSEY (Baltimore) With Mariners in Baltimore. Who's
to blame for the M's current mess, with the messed-up bullpen and
the Randy Johnson circus? Woody? The scouts? Ownership?


   By Laura Vecsey. (story will move in the ``s'' category)


   BBA-RANDY-JOHNSON (Baltimore) The latest on the Randy Johnson
trade talk. Latest word is that the Dodgers are growing tired of
waiting and might bail out.


   By Jim Street. (story will move in the ``s'' category)


   BKN-GEORGE-KARL (Seattle) George Karl will speak publicly for
the first time since the Sonics announced they would not offer him
a new contract. He has a television interview on Fox Sports
Northwest at 7 p.m. PST and then a party for fans, starting at 8
p.m. PST.


   By Ronald Tillery. (story will move in the ``s'' category)

results.content:
&HT;   



   I am sitting in a restaurant in the North Carolina mountains,
looking at the menu. One of the offerings is something called
marinated and grilled pork tenderloin with rosemary-Zinfandel
sauce, goat cheese-chive mash and Carolyn's fresh-picked snap
beans, whomever Carolyn the bean-picker might be.


   As I am not big on goat cheese-chive mash, my choice, instead,
is the marinated and grilled leg of lamb with mint aioli, vegetable
marmalade and Tuscan beans. Although I had no idea what ``aioli''
was, it just sounded better than the goat cheese-chive mash.


   Passed up, also, was the too adventurous-sounding
chocolate-infused espresso-crusted grilled tenderloin of beef with
Irish cream sauce, French beans and goat cheese-au gratin potatoes.
I thought to myself that if I wanted coffee with dinner, I'd order
it in a cup instead of ``infused'' in a piece of beef.


   When my plate arrives, I look down at it, then across to my wife
with my best ``is-that-all-there-is?'' look. She has problems of
her own. Her citrus-soy marinated rare grilled yellowfin tuna with
jasmine rice, stir-fried vegetables and a variety of sauces more
common to Japanese restaurants seems to still be flapping. This is
one big piece of sushi.


   She sends it back so that the cook may kill and warm it.


   What I'm looking at on my plate are circular-placed,
quarter-sized, thin pieces of lamb; six in all. I could get all six
pieces into one mouthful. Between them are curious-looking dollops
of a light green substance that is identified to me as the aioli
and further defined as mayonnaise flavored with crushed garlic;
infused, I am certain.


   The rest of the entree has this hockey puck-looking disk of
beans glued together by the vegetable marmalade.


   It is then that my wife and I fondly begin discussing the dinner
we had a couple of nights earlier in South Carolina _ a tangy,
filling platter of Memphis-style ribs, baked potato and salad. Note
that each and all of these ingredients are identifiable to the
average American.


   It would seem that in these recent decades of chi-chi American
gastronomy, presumably foisted upon us by California chefs run
amok, there are becoming just two types of restaurant dining: fast
food and no food. What's in-between is fading from the restaurant
platter.


   Try going to one of those restaurants where the kitchen is out
in the open, the chefs considered to be celebrities, and try to get
some meatloaf. Fat chance!


   I left the restaurant for my room, still hungry and longing for
that jar of peanuts on my nightstand and a cold Dr Pepper.


   The experience of enigmatic and paltry main courses reminded me
of a column written by a now-gone colleague who tired of the trend
to fantasy-style dining. He showed up at a 7-Eleven one night, and
foraged the food cabinets of the establishment. ``First, I munched
on an adventurous pemmican appetizer called a Super Jerk Slim
Jim,'' John Keasler wrote. ``It sent my taste buds right into happy
little aerobics!


   ``The main course,'' he continued, ``is prepared by a system of
micro (or little-ditty) waves. My companion was overjoyed with her
Red Hot Beef and Bean Burro, an astounding bargain at 79 cents,
while I literally drooled over my Shredded Beef Chimichanga With
Green Chili and Cheese in a Fried Flour Tortilla, at the same
price.''


   So, that seems to be our choice: aioli, chocolate-infused
espresso-crusted something, goat cheese-chive mash on one side and
ribs, hamburgers and a plain old steak or fried catfish on the
other.


   No one ever had to explain a menu to me at Denny's, or even
Shoney's.


   But that's what's so great about this country, eh?; the choice.


   (Howard Kleinberg, a former editor of the Miami News, is a
columnist for Cox Newspapers. His e-mail address is
hkmiami(at)aol.com.)


   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers


   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service

1996-06-27 
 China's Demand for Quick-Freezing Machines to Rise 


BEIJING, June 27 (Xinhua) -- China's annual demand for freezers
is expected to reach at least 11,800 by the turn of the century.


China produced more than 2.2 million tons of frozen food last
year, and the country's yearly demand for it is expected to rise
to 8.5 million tons by the year 2000, the "China Light Industry
News" reported.


China now produces more than 140 million tons of meat, marine
products and vegetables annually, causing an increase in the
demand for freezers, according to the report.


Experts predict that frozen food will account for 60 percent of
the total food consumption worldwide during the next 10 years.

results.content:
1997-05-09 
 List of Goods Exempted From Sanctions on Burundi 


DAR ES SALAAM, May 8 (Xinhua) -- The list of goods exempted
from the sanctions imposed on Burundi has been expanded with a
view to easing hardships facing children, women and the elderly
people in the war-torn country, a press statement said today.


The statement from Foreign Ministry of Tanzania said the Great
Lakes Sanctions Committee which met here on May 6, has released a
list of 25 categories of goods to be exported to Burundi,
including food stuffs, medicines, construction, educational and
agricultural items.


The statement said, "The idea is to ease the difficulties on
the elderly people, women and children, so the goods which are
supposed to consolidate the military regime in Burundi are still
not allowed", emphasizing that the sanctions against Burundi are
still intact.


The food stuffs allowed include animals and their products,
fish and marine products, fruits, nuts, vegetables and edible
roots and tubers.


On the list there are also cereals like maize, wheat, rice,
millet and animal or vegetable fats and oils and related goods.
Others are agricultural items like hoes, fertilizers, chemicals
and pesticide.


Apart from the above-mentioned, the list also includes
minerals, construction materials along with laboratory equipment,
medicines and pharmaceutical products.


However, sources from the ministry said there is no bilateral
trade between Burundi and any other country in the zone and those
goods may be traded by individuals.

results.content:
1996-05-22 
 Thailand's Food Exports Increase Steadily 


BANGKOK, May 22 (Xinhua) -- Export performance of Thailand's
food product industry has been showing a steady improvement,
according to Sanit Vorapanya, director-general of the Department
of Export Promotion.


The upward trend is the result of a rebound in the world
economy and a surge in food consumption in many countries, Sanit
was quoted today by local newspaper the Bangkok Post as saying.


Thailand is among the world's five biggest exporters of food
products. Its food exports were worth 141.7 billion baht (5.7
billion US dollars) in 1994, rising 5.8 percent to reach 149.87
billion baht (5.99 billion US dollars) in 1995. The target for
this year is 163.54 billion baht (6.54 billion US dollars).


Processed goods such as canned, frozen and dried marine foods
account for about 70 percent of the total. Among other items are
fresh and processed vegetables and fruit, and frozen poultry.


Thailand is the world's chief exporter of frozen and canned
shrimp and canned tuna, and the second biggest canned pineapple
exporter after the Philippines.

results.content:
1996-07-12 
 Sino-Foreign Frozen Food Venture Expanded 


JINAN, July 12 (Xinhua) -- The second phase of construction on
a Sino-foreign frozen food processing venture recently began in
the Weihai Economic and Technological Development Zone.


The expansion project, in east China's Shandong Province, will
cost 10 million US dollars, which will be provided by enterprises
of China, the Republic of Korea (ROK) and Japan.


A new production line will be added to bring the venture's
total annual output to 50,000 tons, making it the largest of its
kind in Asia.


Five fishing vessels, each with a capacity of 3,000 dwt (dead
weight tonnage) will be purchased to develop oceangoing fishing.


The first phase project went into operation in October, 1995,
at a cost of 27 million US dollars.


Nearly 90 percent of processed frozen fish and marine food,
meat, vegetables and flour-made products have been exported to
Japan and the ROK.

results.content:
TASTY TAPAS TREND TAKES OFF 




   HOUSTON _ Tapas, delectable little bites, are making it big at
parties and on restaurant menus. They suit today's lifestyles
because they're usually easy to make and don't require cooking
expertise. They're perfect for little meals or finger-food snacks
with drinks. Tapas (pronounced TOP-ahs), translated ``lids on
top,'' are appetizers _ the Spanish equivalent of French hors
d'oeuvres and Mexican bocas (short for ``bocados,'' meaning
mouthfuls or bites).


   It's the second time around for tapas. Although some Houston
restaurants have offered tapas for about 20 years, they enjoyed a
brief fad in the '80s, then faded.


   Tapas went the way of fondue and crepes until the '90s, when
restaurants introduced Houstonians to South American-style tidbits.


   Restaurants concerned with authenticity have an education job on
their hands. Some classic Spanish ingredients are an acquired
taste, particularly smelt, salt cod, baby eel (angula), squid
(calamare), snails, octopus, baby anchovies (boquerones), chorizo
sausage, blood sausage (morcilla) and salty-cured Serrano ham.


   Shrimp, mussels, a variety of olives, bowls of almonds, fresh
pimentos and Spanish Tortilla (potato omelet) receive more instant
acceptance.


   Penelope Casas has written several books on Spain. In her books,
she offers a wealth of tips on tapas, including the following:


   Choose a variety of tapas _ vegetables, meats, seafood. Prepare
one or several from each category: fried, baked or grilled; cold or
marinated; in sauces; or with bread or pastries.


   For a large group, choose finger foods or serve tapas on
toothpicks. Make 10 to 20 different tapa varieties and set them out
buffet-style.


   Tapas that need last-minute preparation and should be eaten
immediately, should be spaced over the course of the evening and
passed on trays.


   For a small gathering, start with lighter tapas, such as
rice-filled pimentos or seafood-stuffed mushrooms, and progress to
more filling tapas.


   Serve tapas with sherry (well-chilled fino sherry is
traditional), especially if tapas are spicy or salty. Serve with
the appropriate white or red wine, beer or sangria.


   Among popular tapas with drinks are croquettes (made with
potatoes or seafood), grilled vegetables with garlic sauce,
Potatoes Bravas (spicy potatoes), cheese (Mi Luna offers a platter
with goat cheese, Brie and manchego tossed in olive oil that has
been infused with peppercorns, chervil and lemon), marinated olives
and mushrooms. &QL; 
 &QL; 
XXXXXEND OF STORY &QL;

results.content:
COOL CHICAGO CHEF JAMS AT THE AMERICAN RESTAURANT'S 25TH
ANNIVERSARY DINNER 



   .MDNM/(something, but chefs do it and it's so fleeting and it's
gone.'')


   The next quick fix


   As Americans learn more about food but cook less, Trotter
predicts chefs will become the next quick fix.


   In mid-February Trotter will open Trotter to Go, a mile from his
restaurant. The take-out concept will feature spit-roasted organic
birds, loins of meat, 35 types of grain, noodle and marinated
vegetable salads, a 100-bottle esoteric wine section, breads and
pastries plus a ``juice bar element.''


   ``If you don't have time to cook and maybe you've never really
learned to cook and here's a Wolfgang Puck frozen pizza, I've heard
of this guy and I've read a few articles about him in Bon Appetit,
this is probably going to be pretty good.


   ``Buy prepared foods a la Emeril Lagasse and you can expect
southern New Orleans flare. A la Alice Waters and it's going to be
organic and Provencal, clean and vegetable driven.


   ``These chefs have kind of carved out these niches, and their
reputation immediately signifies something. If you're not going to
have time to cook at home, wouldn't it be great to have these
products?''


   Trotter's first foray into the home kitchen was successful. His
Gourmet Cooking for Dummies (1997, IDG Books Worldwide) sold more
than 100,000 copies.


   Yet ``I'm not necessarily interested in the home cook,'' he
says. ``My job is to put together the most flavorful food I can.
I'm not trying to appeal to elite diners either. I'm just trying to
stay true to a point of view and produce food that I personally
would like to eat.


   ``Now, if doing a certain dish at the restaurant involves rare,
esoteric ingredients that would preclude the home cook from doing
that dish, then I'm interested in taking that idea _ that
combination of flavors _ and doing it in a greatly simplified way.
But I'm not out there trying to rope in the mainstream. I can't
think in those terms.''


   Books by Trotter


   - Charlie Trotter's (Ten Speed Press, 1994) _ A
behind-the-scenes look at the award-winning restaurant, with 72
recipes.


   - Charlie Trotter's Vegetables (Ten Speed Press, 1996) _
Passionate about vegetables, Trotter focuses on the shapes and
textures of vegetable artistry. Chapters are divided into the 12
months of the year, and specific vegetables are featured at the
peak of ripeness.


   - Charlie Trotter's Seafood (Ten Speed Press, 1997) _ Fish and
seafood are showcased in 75 recipes using more than 80 different
fish and shellfish.


   - Charlie Trotter's Desserts (Ten Speed Press, 1998) _ Trotter's
modern dessert presentations are primarily fruit driven.


   - Gourmet Cooking for Dummies (IDG Books Worldwide, 1997) _
Trotter goes mainstream with a guidebook to kitchen savvy, complete
with Charlie cartoon faces.


   - The Kitchen Sessions With Charlie Trotter (Ten Speed Press,
1999) _ A companion to Trotter's PBS Television series of the same
name, this book is written for the home cook and encourages using
the recipes as a ``framework'' for more spontaneous cuisine.


   - Lessons in Excellence From Charlie Trotter (Ten Speed Press,
1999) _ Written by Paul Clarke, this business school-style text
uses Charlie Trotter's as a case study on how to run a successful
company.

servings


   2 cups chicken stock


   4 tablespoons butter, divided


   1 large turnip, peeled and cut into batons


   Salt and pepper, to taste


   1/4 cup chopped lemongrass


   1 cup 1-inch-thick leek slices (white part only)


   1 tablespoon rice wine vinegar


   1 tablespoon tamari soy sauce


   1 tablespoon red miso


   4 (4-ounce) pieces salmon


   2 tablespoons olive oil


   3 cups watercress, thick stems removed


   To prepare the broth: Place the chicken stock, 2 tablespoons of
butter and turnip in a medium saucepan and bring to a simmer. Cook
3 to 4 minutes or until the turnip is about half cooked. Remove the
turnips from the liquid and season to taste w

results.content:
&HT;   



   &QR;  Oil holds flavors on the palate. When reducing the amount of
oil or cooking fat-free, use extra herbs and spices. Be gentle.
No-oil cooking requires lower heat and more attention.


   &QR;  Fat-free foods have less moisture. A trick to get fat-free
cheese to melt is to hydrate it well before melting. Marinate in
cold water, vegetable or mushroom broth for 5 minutes.


   &QR;  Cook with fresh and spicy condiments, flavored mustards, sweet
chutneys and ready-to-go salsas.


   &QR;  When steaming vegetables, use distilled water instead of tap
water. You'll be surprised how avoiding chlorine improves the taste
of vegetables.


   &QR;  Saute onions or mushrooms in small amounts of frozen
concentrated apple juice to caramelize.


   &QR;  When using nuts or seeds in salads, dry-roast them first to
enhance flavor. A little goes a long way.


   &QR;  Make cream sauces with soy milk and fat-free powdered
buttermilk, or use Butter Buds.


   &QR;  Use earthen bakeware with lids and just a trace of oil for
roasted root vegetables.


   &QR;  When poaching fish, use a small amount of dry vermouth. It
will cut down on the fishy taste.


   &QR;  When baking pizza, saute vegetables on the grill to cut down
on baking time. Use a pizza stone to prevent burning the crust.


   &QR;  Always have a good vegetable broth handy. Fresh or frozen
broth will make a big difference.


   &QR;  Cook rice, grains and beans in broth.


   &QR;  Thicken sauces with vegetable purees. Strained baby prunes
will thicken any rich mushroom sauce.


   &QR;  When sauteing, remember just about anything will work.
Hydration is the key. You can use wine, beer, non-carbonated spring
water, frozen apple juice concentrate, even Coca Cola.


   &QR;  Oil sprays are handy but use them sparingly.


   &QR;  Make your own healthy bacon bits: Mix 1/2 cup of Grape Nuts
cereal, 1 tablespoon Liquid Smoke and 1 tablespoon of reduced-salt
soy sauce.

results.content:
&HT;   



   AUSTIN, Texas _ One of the hallmarks of adulthood, along with
marriage, getting a mortgage and signing up for a 401K, is having
your cholesterol level measured. If you're older than 20, you
should have it checked periodically, especially if you have heart
disease in your family. If you're in your 40s or 50s, you're way
behind schedule if you haven't had it checked recently. All it
takes is a quick blood test.


   If your numbers are low, you know you're doing something right;
if they're high, you and your physician can take action.


   High cholesterol is one of the major risk factors for heart
disease, although it's far from the only one. Much of the treatment
for high cholesterol is simple _ eating in a healthy way and
exercising.


   Many people know they have high or borderline-high cholesterol
and aren't doing anything about it. They figure they feel fine, and
they lost that pamphlet their doctor or nurse gave them at their
last appointment. If you're one of those people, this guide is for
you, or anyone else you know who's at risk for heart disease.


   WHAT IS A HEALTHY LEVEL?


   Cholesterol is measured in milligrams per deciliter of blood
(mg/dL). Knowing your total blood cholesterol level is important in
determining your risk for heart disease. If you have high
cholesterol, you're not alone. Nearly 97 million Americans have
levels that are borderline-high or high. Cholesterol levels are
graded on this scale:


   Less than 200 mg/dL is desirable


   200 to 239 mg/dL is borderline-high


   240 mg/dL and up is high


   WHO SHOULD HAVE THEIR HIS OR HER CHOLESTEROL TESTED?


   In general, adults who are older than 20 should have their
cholesterol levels tested every five years, according to the
American Heart Association. You may need to be tested more
frequently depending on your health history and family history.


   WHAT IS THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN ``GOOD'' AND ``BAD'' CHOLESTEROL?


   The ``good'' cholesterol is HDL-C, high-density lipoprotein
cholesterol. HDL-C is thought to aid in the removal of excess
cholesterol from the blood. High levels of HDL-C are associated
with a decreased risk of heart attack. Your HDL-C level should be
35 mg/dL or higher.


   ``Bad'' cholesterol is LDL-C, or low-density lipoprotein
cholesterol. Too much LDL-C in your blood can stick to the walls of
your arteries, narrowing them and reducing their ability to
transport blood. In people without heart disease, the LDL-C level
should be lower than 130 mg/dL.


   Here's an easy way to remember the difference. L stands for
life-threatening or LDL cholesterol, and H stands for healthy or
HDL-C. Ask what your levels of each one are.


   HOW CAN I LOWER MY CHOLESTEROL?


   The American Heart Association's most important piece of advice
is: Watch what you eat. To help lower your cholesterol, eat five or
more servings of fruits and vegetables each day. Eat a wide variety
of foods low in saturated fat and cholesterol.


   You also should exercise. Aerobic activities such as dancing,
brisk walking, jogging, biking or swimming will help. Activity that
increases your heart rate for 30 or 60 minutes or longer each day
is best. On busy days, remember that even 10 or 15 minutes of
physical activity is better than none.


   FOODS LOW IN SATURATED FAT AND CHOLESTEROL


   Lean cuts of red meat, chicken or turkey, roasted or baked with
the skin removed, fresh or canned fruits and vegetables, whole
grains, beans, pasta, breads, potatoes, hot and cold cereal, taco
shells and plain tortillas, olive oil, corn oil, canola oil, baked
or broiled fish, skim milk, low-fat or nonfat yogurt, low-fat or
part-skim cheese, angel food cake, fig bar cookies, gingersnaps,
animal crackers, jelly beans, hard candy, popsicles and frozen
yogurt.


   FOODS HIGH IN SATURATED FAT AND CHOLESTEROL


   Fatty cuts of red meat, fried chicken, avocado, coconut, gravy,
french fries, cream sauces, butter, shortening, mayonnaise, fried
fish or fish in cream sauce, whole milk, cream, ice cream, eggs,
cream cheese, cheese, doughnuts, pastries, cakes, coo

results.content:
No, they are not prize fighters, but comeback kids who strut
their stuff in the bins of farmers' markets and some food-forward
grocery stores.


   Not too many years ago, these heirloom tomatoes seemed doomed,
pushed toward oblivion by generally picked-while-green hybrid
Romas, hydroponically grown cluster tomatoes and a few other
varieties of great uniformity, near-indestructibility and, for the
most part, insipid flavor.


   A few intrepid gardeners/conservationists tried to keep the old
varieties alive, growing them in backyard plots and swapping seeds
with like-minded tomato lovers. And they managed _ largely via
farmers' markets _ to popularize these tomatoes that range from
tiny cherries to whopping two-pounders and from green and yellow to
rust and the hue of old Bordeaux wine.


   Janet Brown is one of these tradition-minded growers who has
parlayed a personal passion into a viable business. She now grows
30 varieties of heirloom tomatoes on her small family farm, AllStar
Organics in Lagunitas (Marin County).


   Brown has less than three acres under cultivation, but she grows
enough to supply a number of high-end restaurants, natural food
stores and central Marin's upscale grocery, Woodland Market in
Ross.


   Brown's farming career began _ depending on how you care to look
at it _ either with a disaster or with serendipity.


   Eight years ago, the software development company for which she
worked went belly-up. Having gardened all her life, the Long Beach
native who had lived and owned land in Marin for more than two
decades, decided to say farewell to the corporate routine. ``I took
a little risk,'' she admits of her move into for-profit organic
gardening and food advocacy, ``But I didn't have much to lose. I
could always go back.''


   The valley where she lives with her husband, Marty Jacobson, is
ringed by trees and has its own microclimate. She calls it a warm
bowl, although its cool nights slow things down to the point that
her harvest is starting in earnest just about now. She expects her
tomatoes to be at their prime around September 8, though she and
her husband _ sometimes assisted by son Bo, 19 _ expect to harvest
three times a week until Halloween.


   There are a few early varieties, but most heirloom tomatoes tend
to ripen late, unlike the hybrids that fill supermarket bins and
which were developed for early harvesting.


   Brown explains that an heirloom tomato is not only a fruit that
has not been genetically altered, but one that has gone through the
hands of at least four generations of gardeners.


   Gardeners, she says, have kept meticulous records for a long
time. Genetic diversity, she says, is best preserved when a maximum
number of people cultivate a certain plant, not when huge companies
control the market by patenting DNA.


   Brown cites an example of survival: In 1994 she planted a tomato
named 1894 after the year of a calamitous flood in the Ohio River
Valley that wiped out crops. But somewhere nearby, the valley's
traditional tomato survived and the seeds were returned to the
valley and have been nurtured since.


   Passionate about sustainable agriculture and preserving our
agricultural heritage, Brown splits her time between her farm and
Berkeley's Center for Ecoliteracy.


   She also finds time for the Marin Food and Agriculture Project
and its gleaning program. This grass-roots endeavor shows middle
and high school students how to gather produce that's left in
organic gardens and farms after the official harvesting is done _
the likes of baby spinach leaves and parts of other crops that are
either too small or too tall to be garnered in regular harvesting.


   Farmers, Brown says, can't afford to pay crews to pick these
leftover vegetables, yet gleaners can collect hundreds of pounds of
perfectly good produce that is then given to the Marin Food Bank or
soup kitchens. Working a typical four-hour shift, a school class of
about 30 youngsters averages 1,000 pounds of vegetables, she
reports.


   Brown says proponents of organic gardening like herself are
h

results.content:
Food and dining stories from The N.Y. Times News Service for
Wednesday, March 3:


   AMERICAN-MEAT (New York) _ Bruce Aidells and his collaborator,
Denis Kelly, has spent nearly a decade studying the state of meat
in America to produce ``The Complete Meat Cookbook,'' published
last November by Houghton Mifflin. Not only does it secure his
image as a man unafraid of meat, even in these vegetable-revering
times, but it also is rife with heretical ideas. ``Meat has changed
in America,'' he said. ``We need to change the way we cook it.'' By
Molly O'Neill.


   With photo.


   With recipes.


   MEAT-MARINATE (Undated) _ Since the earliest days of recorded
history, and maybe even before, humans have marinated their food,
steeping meat, fowl and fish in some combination of liquid _
usually oil or acid _ and seasonings. At first, there were
practical reasons: Tough meat needed to be made tender, it needed
to be preserved, and, with humans ever attuned to improving their
lot, it needed to be flavored. But from ranch to refrigerator,
almost everything has changed about meat and the way it is treated
today. Everything, that is, except marination. By Eric Asimov.


   With recipes.


   WINE-MICROWAVE (New York) _ A new question is creeping into wine
service in New York: How do you want that cooked? For many years,
Americans have confounded the rest of the world by drinking their
white wines too cold and their red wines too warm. Sommeliers no
longer hesitate when diners ask that a luscious Corton-Charlemagne
be plunged into an ice bucket. They just do it. It's easy. Red wine
poses a different problem. If it arrives at the table with slight
chill, and the diners want it the temperature of a blood
transfusion _ fast _ the sommelier must resort to wiles, and the
wiliest wile of all, it turns out, is the microwave oven. By
William Grimes.


   FOOD-NOTES (Undated) _ News and notes on food and dining. By
Florence Fabricant


   SWEET-POTATO-EATING-WELL (Undated) _ The column: On that
nutritional powerhouse, the sweet potato. By Marian Burros.


   With recipe.


   SIMPLE-COOKING (Undated) _ The column: The easiest roast duck _
high heat & fast. By Mark Bittman.


   With recipe.


   TAPIOCA (Undated) _ The stuff of puddings goes savory on new
menus. By Melissa Clark.


   With recipes.


   MASTER-CHEF (Undated) _ The column: on ``everything tuna,''
crusted like a bagel with all kinds of seeds. By Rick Moonen.


   With recipe.


   FRANCE-MICHELIN (Undated) _ An interview with the main Michelin
man. By Florence Fabricant.


   WINE-TALK (Undated) _ The ccolumn: the fine art of spitting. By
Frank J. Prial.


   (Eds, there will be no WINE-TASTINGS this week.)


   FOOD-Q&A (Undated) _ Food questions answered. By Melissa Clark.


   We expect to move all Living Section stories by early evening
with a ``d'' category code, unless otherwise indicated.


   For information and repeats call the News Service at (888)
346-9867 or (212) 556-1927. And be sure to look for other stories
from our partners: Bloomberg News, The Boston Globe, Cox News
Service, Hearst Newspapers, The Arizona Republic, Kansas City Star,
Fort Worth Star-Telegram, Los Angeles Daily News, San Francisco
Chronicle and Seattle Post-Intelligencer.

results.content:
2000-09-26 
 U.S. Farm Produce Changes Chinese Market 


SHANGHAI, September 26 (Xinhua) -- A group of chefs from the
United States are staying in Shanghai's top-class hotels to teach
Chinese chefs skills about their cuisine.


Previously, U.S. marine products businessmen in co-operation
with hotels in Shanghai hold a seafood festival, providing
consumers menus with U.S food in Chinese.


U.S. farm produce businessmen are holding the seafood festival
as China will soon enter the WTO.


According to customs statistics from January to July, U.S.
edible oil seeds, frozen meat, and milk and butter goods passing
through Shanghai customs respectively increased 68.2 percent, 219.
7 percent and 80.5 percent over the same period of last year.


Fruit and nuts, feather and down imports increased as high as
289 times and 56.6 times the figure for last year, respectively.


At the same time, sturgeons which live in cold water have
successfully reproduced in the Yangtze River. It is a favorable
food in many Shanghai hotels together with Salmon from Alaska.


Farmers planting water melons, oranges and apples in Anhui,
Jiangsu, Jiangxi, Zhejiang, Shaanxi provinces are busy with
registering trade marks, after seeing that "Sunkist" orange from
the United States are well-sold because of its brand.


With superior geographic position and better techniques,
Shanghai has imported more than 300 kinds of seeds of vegetables
and flowers. And now it grows 30,000 tons of overseas vegetables
annually.


Xu Yanming, owner of a sturgeons farm in northern Shanghai,
said that due to the improvement of breeding techniques and the
market demands, he has introduced several kinds of fish from cold
areas. His 40,000-square-meter breeding pond has become the
largest sturgeon breeding center in east China.


Sturgeons sell at more than 200 yuan (about 12 U.S dollars) a
kilogram but still cannot meet market demands.


Shao Wangyu, professor with a WTO research center in Shanghai,
said that Chinese and overseas farm produce compete with each
other. The influx of overseas produce has given Chinese consumers
more choices.


He said Chinese farmers should increase market awareness and
learn marketing strategies from their overseas counterparts.


On March 23, shortly after China announced that it would lift
restrictions on importing U.S oranges, Sunkist oranges began to
roll into the Chinese market with a big publicity campaign.


U.S. businessmen plan to export 500 million yuan worth of
Sunkist oranges to China in the coming five years.


The chefs from the United States are scheduled to teach 1,200
people in major cities such as Shanghai, Beijing, and Dalian in
one year and a half.


Greg Drescher, a senior official with the Culinary Institute of
America, said the training program is funded by U.S. Department of
Agriculture, and supported by over 30 U.S wheat, peanuts, wine,
oranges and marine products companies.

results.content:
A TASTE TREASURE FROM DAVY JONES'S LOCKER 



   In a world in which ``new'' too often signifies merely a change
in food packaging or processing, Nova Scotia sea parsley is
floating against the tide. This marine vegetable is an anomaly of
nature, not industry _ though it would not be showing up in stores
now without a little help from human hands.


   Sea parsley, a tiny, curly leafed, burgundy-colored seaweed, is
a miniature version of dulse, the red marine plant best known to
diners as an ingredient in seaweed salads in Japanese restaurants.
It is a natural mutation, discovered in 1978 by a group of
scientists off Grand Manan Island in the Bay of Fundy, near the
coast of Maine.


   The scientists formed a company, Ocean Produce International, to
cultivate the seaweed in saltwater tanks and sell it.


   Until a few months ago, this delicacy was known only to Japanese
and other Asian cooks, as well as vegetarians, who bought it
directly from the company. But now it is being sold, in one-ounce
packages, for about $5 at specialty groceries in New York. It is
also available by mail order from Adriana's Caravan, (800)
316-0820.


   It did not take long for chefs to be captivated by this new
ingredient, which smells like the ocean but whose taste changes,
depending on how it is used.


   Rick Moonen, the executive chef of Oceana, said that sea parsley
``seems to have a natural affinity to Asian ingredients, but also
classic French preparations, like consomme.'' He adds it to seafood
soups or stews or to the pot when steaming a fish. The seaweed
lends a briny yet clean flavor.


   As a Canadian product, sea parsley often turns up on the menu at
the Canadian Consulate in New York, where Louis Charest, the
executive chef, has been using it for a year or so. He chops it and
adds it to salads, as he would arugula. He also uses it to flavor
salmon, sturgeon and turbot dishes; buries a fish in it for
steaming, and includes it in a warm lobster salad.


   Sea parsley, like most seaweed, is packed with vitamins and
calcium, and contains amino acids, which break down food fibers and
permeate them, changing their texture. If sea parsley is used raw
or barely cooked, the changes are subtle. If simmered or broiled
with other ingredients, however, it tenderizes them and alters
their taste.


   What chefs have discovered about this chameleon of a vegetable
is that when it is fresh and raw, it has a mild nutty taste with
hints of oyster and lots of crunch. When fried, it becomes a golden
green color and very crisp, and tastes more like bacon.


   Boiled sea parsley becomes deep green and takes on a mussel-like
taste. Sun dried, it has a roasted vegetable flavor. Fresh out of a
microwave oven, it tastes more like nori and is great when mixed
with a little rice vinegar.


   So go ahead and do what the chefs do _ experiment. Fry some sea
parsley and sprinkle it like croutons on a salad, particularly a
salad accompanying cold or smoked seafood, or use it as a garnish
for seafood or vegetable dishes or as an accompaniment to smoked
fish, sushi and sashimi.


   For a wonderful blast of the ocean, add it to broths for
poaching or steaming. When boiled in lightly salted water for 15
minutes, sea parsley produces a broth that tastes like clam and
oyster juices _ a good base for a chowder or a quick seafood stew.


   Visually, it may take some imagination to recognize the
similarities between surf parsley and the more familiar turf
parsley. But just as curly or flat leaf parsley gives a dish a
whiff of the garden, its marine counterpart bespeaks the mysterious
flavors of the deep.


   SEA PARSLEY SALAD WITH RICE WINE VINAIGRETTE


   Time: 40 minutes


   For the dressing:


   2 teaspoons sesame oil


   3 tablespoons vegetable oil


   { shallot, minced


   4 teaspoons rice wine vinegar


   2 teaspoons lemon juice


   1 tablespoon soy sauce.


   For the salad:


   One-third cup vegetable oil


   4 cups (about 3 ounces) sea parsley


   3 carrots, peeled and finely julienned


   1{ cups peeled and finely julienned jicama

results.content:
VEGGIE OUT WITH CURTIS



   With unrestrained enthusiasm and a smile wider than the
Chattahoochee River, Curtis Aikens makes his success look like
child's play.


   The burly, vegetarian star of the cable TV Food Network's ``Pick
of the Day'' has an irresistible sweetness that could make even the
most dedicated meat-and-potatoes eater want to gobble a plate of
grilled tofu.


   All that positive energy is exactly what Aikens used to mask a
dark secret for more than 20 years.


   ``I'm the first African-American to have a cooking show on TV,
yet I didn't learn to read until I was 26,'' Aikens, 40, said
during a brief break in a whirlwind Fort Worth weekend.


   ``Sharing with kids is what's so important that you achieve
things by reaching for them,'' Aikens said. ``I tell the kids to
set goals, to strive to be better and to give back.''


   Wherever he goes to do personal appearances, either cooking for
a charity event or publicizing his latest cookbook, Aikens finds an
outlet for spreading his literacy gospel and talking to children
about overcoming odds.


   Aikens was born in Conyers, Ga., just east of Atlanta. He said
he didn't suffer from dyslexia but just wasn't taught properly. He
repeated the third grade and just ``schmoozed'' his way through the
rest of school.


   ``It was exhausting,'' he said. ``I wish someone had been as
open to me about asking for help as I try to be when I'm talking to
kids.''


   He practices what he preaches about giving back: All royalties
from his cookbooks _ the latest of three is 1995's ``Curtis Cooks
With Heart and Soul'' (William Morris, $23) _ go to reading and
literacy programs, he said.


   Aikens was 26 and running his own produce business in the San
Francisco area when he saw a TV commercial for a literacy program.
It promised confidentiality, and Aikens got the tutoring he
desperately needed.


   Drawing on the passion that his mother, Laura, has for cooking,
Aikens turned his love of vegetables and food preparation into a
high-profile career. He made his mother's pumpkin pie first when he
launched his TV cooking show in Atlanta in 1989.


   ``Mama taught me to cook; she's my big inspiration. There's
nothing like her collard greens and corn bread,'' he said. ``She's
proud of me, and I'm proud of her, too.''


   Soon he was the produce man on ABC-TV's ``Home Show,'' and his
first cookbook was published in 1990.


   His vegetarian theme has had staying power. Originally, he
sought a meat-free diet to lose weight but wound up sticking with
it because ``vegetables eat and taste good.''


   ``I'm not anti-meat. I just grew up loving and eating
vegetables,'' he said. ``Our family always believed that vegetables
are as big a part of the meal as meat.''


   What's his favorite vegetable? Whatever's fresh. Aikens enjoys
sauteing veggies in a tiny bit of olive oil and adding a bit of a
favorite salad dressing or some marinara for serving. Or he'll
grill asparagus, potatoes and any other vegetables that are handy.


   ``Most people have no idea how easy this is,'' he said. ``You
saute the vegetables a few minutes, cook some pasta and in 10
minutes, it's on the table.''


   When he's feeling nostalgic, his favorite dish to make is
collard greens, cooked with an onion, sliced bell pepper, garlic, a
bit of olive oil and salt. He's happy to report, too, that he can
now find decent collard greens in California.


   ``Okra is one of my real favorites, but the Southern kind is
hard to get in California. The okra we get there from Chile just
isn't the same,'' he said.


   That's important because Aikens splits his time _ when he's not
taping the TV show in New York _ between homes in Georgia and in
Marin County, where his two young sons live, north of San
Francisco.


   Travels will soon take Aikens on his first trip to Great
Britain. That's where he'll be working on a new international
literacy program with suspense novelist Ken Follett, whom he met
recently through mutual friend Robin Leach while vacationing in
Antigua. MORE:


   (Visit the Star-Telegram's online servi

results.content:
A TWO-DAY MARINADE GIVES ZEST TO SEA BASS 



   If cooking is as much alchemy as chemistry, here is the dish to
prove it: Chilean sea bass metamorphosed by a two-day submersion in
a miso marinade, then broiled until it is as brown and shiny as a
perfectly barbecued rib.


   Two days is a long time to marinate anything, particularly fish,
but it takes that long for the marinade to work its magic. It is a
blend of orange juice and zest, brown sugar, sake, a light miso
paste and the pungent chili paste called sambal oelek.


   Chilean sea bass, which is actually Patagonian tooth fish,
starts out as what I call a Jell-O fish: its flesh is soft, wet and
oily. Steam it and its texture will remind you of soft-boiled eggs.
But cover it with the marinade and all that changes, strikingly.


   The marinade's salts and sugars act as a cure and turn the soft
fish into one that flakes in large, firm shards. Marinated, the
Chilean sea bass comes to resemble cod, but creamier and richer.


   And after two days, it is not just the texture that changes. The
fish is imbued with the salty, sweet, bitter, acidic flavors,
complexity and exotic richness of the marinade's ingredients, many
of them rooted in the traditional cooking of Japan, and all of them
intensified when the fish is cooked.


   I top the glazed fillets with cilantro leaves and surround them
with a salad of mango and scallion greens splashed with a citrusy
dressing, an integral part of the dish.


   The fish calls for the coolness and sharpness of the salad and
its dressing, whose flavors are haunting but immediately appealing.
The crisp citrus taste in the dressing comes from the
citrus-flavored soy sauce called ajipon, and from yuzu kosho, a
chili paste that includes yuzu, a Japanese citrus fruit prized for
the oils in its skin. To pull the flavors into balance, I add
mirin, a sweet Japanese rice wine, and rice wine vinegar.


   You may have to make a few shopping trips to collect the
ingredients for this dish, but I promise you they will be worth
it. &QL; 
 &QL;


   MISO-GLAZED CHILEAN SEA BASS &QL;


   Time: 40 minutes, plus 2 days for marinating the fillets &QL; 
 &QL;


   2 oranges


   1 cup freshly squeezed orange juice


   { cup light-brown sugar


   } cup sake


   1\ cups light miso paste (see note)


   1 tablespoon sambal oelek chili paste (see note)


   6 skinless fillets of Chilean sea bass, each about 7 ounces


   \ cup ajipon (see note)


   \ cup mirin (see note)


   \ cup seasoned rice vinegar


   \ cup soybean oil


   1 teaspoon yuzu kosho (see note)


   1 tablespoon vegetable oil


   2 carrots, peeled and finely shredded


   { daikon, peeled and finely shredded


   2 teaspoons soy sauce


   1 ripe mango, peeled, pitted and cut into short, thin strips


   3 scallions, green parts only, thinly sliced diagonally


   6 sprigs cilantro, leaves only. &QL; 
 &QL;


   1. To prepare marinade: Using a vegetable peeler, remove zest
(avoid the white pith) of 1 orange in about 6 wide slices. In a
small saucepan, combine slices of zest, orange juice and brown
sugar. Bring to a boil, then lower heat and simmer until reduced to
one-third. Turn heat to its lowest setting, and stir in the sake,
miso paste and chili paste. Stir for 10 minutes, then remove pan
from heat. Transfer to a bowl, and cool quickly by placing over
ice.


   2. Place fish and marinade in a large zipper-lock plastic bag,
making sure fish is coated with marinade. Press out the air, and
seal securely. Refrigerate for 2 days.


   3. To prepare yuzu dressing: Finely grate the zest of remaining
orange. In container of a blender, combine grated zest, ajipon,
mirin, rice vinegar, soybean oil and yuzu kosho. Puree until
smooth. Set aside at room temperature, or refrigerate up to 4 days.


   4. Preheat a broiler with a rack 8 inches from source of heat.
Remove fillets from marinade, and place on a metal baking pan. Add
a few spoonfuls of water, and brush fillets with just enough
marinade to glaze them. Broil until deeply browned and cooked
through, about 7 minutes.

results.content:
TEA? TURMERIC? THE QUEST FOR SAFER BARBECUE



   The height of the barbecue season is not when anyone wants to
hear about the hazards of eating meat with a nicely blackened crust
hot off the grill. But scientists have long known that substances
created when meat and poultry are cooked at high heat can cause
cancer in animals and that there is some evidence that they may
have the same effect on humans.


   While health professionals still recommend cutting back on
overall meat consumption, recent research suggests that there are
more appealing ways to make grilled meat less hazardous. Some are
common-sensical, like eating it rare (though this is not
recommended for chicken or hamburger) or medium instead of well
done, or cooking it at lower temperatures for shorter periods. But
others are more startling, like sprinkling meat with tea powder, or
mixing ground meat with cherries, or just marinating meat before
cooking.


   Clearly, scientists are now so aware of the potential risks that
they are looking into every corner of the kitchen for solutions.
But their research is in its earliest stages, so they are not
really sure how or why some of these techniques work.


   ``It's hard for scientists to say we don't know,'' said Dr. Mark
G. Knize, a member of the Biology and Biotechnology Research
Program at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in Livermore,
Calif., who is conducting some of the research on the effects of
marinades.


   For whatever reason, though, he and other scientists have found
that one of the most promising techniques for meat and poultry is
marination. Done even briefly, it reduces the cancer-causing
compounds called heterocyclic amines, or HCA's, formed when
creatine in muscle meats reacts with amino acids at high
temperatures. (Fish is much less a problem than meat or poultry.)
But marination does nothing to reduce the level of other
carcinogens that arise when fat falls on a fire and causes smoke.


   Scientists have not yet deconstructed all their marinade
ingredients to pinpoint the anti-cancer agents. They suspect that
the antioxidants in certain foods like garlic, onions, chives,
turmeric, thyme, rosemary and oregano, as well as vitamins C and E,
are responsible.


   In studies last year at the Cancer Research Center of Hawaii in
Honolulu, three different sauces were used to marinate steaks
overnight. One was a teriyaki sauce, another contained turmeric and
garlic powder and the third was a commercial sauce made of honey,
high-fructose corn syrup, vinegar, concentrated tomato juice,
modified food starch, salt and seasonings. Four-ounce pieces of
marinated and unmarinated steak were cooked on a propane gas grill
for varying times at varying temperatures. The marinades were not
reapplied during cooking.


   The shorter the cooking time and the lower the heat, the lower
the levels of the suspect amines in meats marinated in the teriyaki
and turmeric sauces, compared with unmarinated meat. Steaks
marinated in the commercial sauce and cooked similarly had much
higher levels of the amines than the other marinated meats; the
researchers said this may have been partly because the corn syrup
and honey caused the steaks to burn and char faster and more
extensively.


   I conducted taste tests on the teriyaki and turmeric sauces. The
turmeric marinade adds flavor to tender but otherwise tasteless
steak, while the teriyaki makes meat slightly sweet, although the
brown sugar it contains causes the meat to burn faster.


   In a 1997 study at Lawrence Livermore, researchers marinated
chicken breasts in a mixture including garlic, salt, citrus juice
and olive oil that also contained considerable sugar, and they
concluded that the sugar was probably responsible for an increase
in one of the amines. Using sweet commercial barbecue sauces may be
just the wrong thing.


   Other researchers are looking into other antidotes. Dr. John
Weisburger, director emeritus of the nonprofit American Health
Foundation in New York, has done studies indicating that sprinkling
tea powder, either green or black, on m

results.content:
IMPROVISING A SALAD FROM THE GARDEN 



   NEW YORK _ When I was the chef at Greens, the vegetarian
restaurant in San Francisco, we were affiliated with Green Gulch
Farm, which was just across the Golden Gate Bridge, in Marin
County. I lived at the farm and worked closely with the head
gardener, and together we found and grew unusual seeds. As a
result, we were able to serve all kinds of exotic vegetables at the
restaurant. Although today it's expected that a restaurant of any
stature will be working with farmers or even have its own farm, in
1979 this was not the case.


   After driving the crates of produce across the bridge to the
restaurant, more often than not I found that I had nothing in
enough quantity to feature by itself. So one of my menu standards
was what we called Farm Salad _ a composed salad of raw, steamed,
pickled and grilled vegetables, with a few sauces, usually
accompanied by a wedge of frittata or some hard-cooked eggs, also
from the farm. By necessity, these salads were ever-changing, but
all presented a variety of tastes and textures.


   Now, I choose vegetables from the farmers' market and my small
garden, and I've vastly simplified the number of ingredients and
the method, using just one dressing for everything. I steam or
parboil most of the vegetables, but there is certainly room for raw
vegetables, grilled peppers or onions, and pickled vegetables or
olives. This dish allows you to improvise based on what's around
and how much you want to do.


   These days, I like a pestolike dressing based on fresh, fragrant
marjoram. Like basil, marjoram is widely used in Liguria, the
region around the Italian Riviera. Marjoram has a wonderful,
powerful flavor, and it's tied together here with other typical
ingredients, like capers, pine nuts and olives, in a sauce akin to
one used in the Ligurian salad called cappon magro, which is
usually composed of a variety of fish and vegetables. (If you want
to add cold steamed or grilled fish to the farm salad, it's
perfectly appropriate.) I find it difficult to avoid eating this
delicious sauce with a spoon or spreading it on bread.


   Although the sauce recipe below is fairly precise, the vegetable
suggestions are just that: suggestions. If you figure at least 12
ounces of vegetables a person, along with a little protein _ in the
form of hard-boiled egg, fish or a combination _ the meal will work
out fine.


   FARM SALAD WITH MARJORAM SAUCE


   Time: about 1 hour


   4 medium beets, or more small ones


   12 small new potatoes


   1 pound green beans, trimmed


   4 to 8 small carrots, peeled


   2 red onions, peeled and cut into half-inch rounds


   2 small zucchini, cut in half lengthwise


   { cup plus 2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil


   1 {-inch-thick slice good white bread, crusts trimmed


   2 tablespoons red wine vinegar


   1 teaspoon minced garlic


   2 tablespoons marjoram leaves


   3 tablespoons drained capers


   { cup pine nuts


   1 cup finely minced parsley leaves


   2 tablespoons pitted olives, like nicoise


   Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste


   12 radishes, trimmed


   4 to 8 pickled artichoke hearts (canned are fine)


   1 medium cucumber, trimmed and cut into eighths


   4 hard-cooked eggs, cut in half.


   1. In separate batches, steam or parboil beets, potatoes, green
beans and carrots, until each is tender. Plunge into ice water to
cool. Peel beets and potatoes if you like; cut into wedges if they
are large. Cut green beans and carrots into 2-inch lengths if
large. Refrigerate until ready to serve. &QL;


   2. Grill or broil the onion and zucchini, brushing occasionally
with the 2 tablespoons of olive oil, until tender. Refrigerate
until ready to serve. &QL;


   3. Soak bread in vinegar. In a mortar and pestle or small food
processor, combine garlic, marjoram, capers, pine nuts, parsley and
olives; grind until coarse but not pureed. Add the bread and the {
cup olive oil, and grind some more _ again, the texture should be
coarse. (If you're using a food processor, pulse on and off to
main

results.content:
WATCH WHAT YOU EAT WITH YOUR PRESCRIPTION DRUGS 



   ALBANY, N.Y. _ It's no mystery that many prescription drugs
don't mix well with others and that taking drugs with alcohol is
almost always a mistake.


   But it may surprise you to learn that sometimes food and drugs
interact in ways that may be bothersome or even harmful.


   The culprits, under certain conditions, include such seemingly
benign and healthy foods as milk, leafy green vegetables and
grapefruit juice.


   A single glass of grapefruit juice, for example, can boost
concentrations of some blood pressure medicines, including Plendil,
Procardia, Sular and Verelan, to potentially harmful levels.


   Estrogen in birth control pills and hormone replacement therapy
may also be affected, as well as the antihistamine Hismanal. Take
grapefruit juice with cyclosporin, a drug that fights organ
rejection in transplant patients, and it may cause confusion and
trembling.


   Those potential interactions are getting more attention these
days as the number of Americans taking prescription medicines
continues to increase. Most side effects aren't so dramatic: upset
stomach, diarrhea, fatigue and irritability.


   ``Approximately 85 million American adults take one or more
prescription medicines,'' said Linda Golodner, president of the
National Consumers League, an advocacy group in Washington, D.C.
``Yet despite this widespread use, many consumers do not know about
potential risks, side effects and possible drug interactions.''


   The problem has been compounded in recent years with the advance
of newer medicines, many of which have subtle effects on different
enzyme systems in the body.


   In addition, many medical conditions, including the AIDS virus,
require patients to follow a complex and difficult prescription
regimen with some drugs taken on an empty stomach, others taken
with food, to ensure best results.


   ``It can be very difficult depending on what regimen they're on
to know when to take them,'' said Bonnie Purdy, a clinical
pharmacist at the Albany Medical Center. ``Some drugs if you take
them with food, absorption is closer to 90 percent. If you take
them on an empty stomach, absorption is closer to 40 percent.''


   To increase awareness about potential problems, the National
Consumers League, in cooperation with the Food and Drug
Administration, has recently published a brochure to alert
consumers to possible food-drug interactions for some of the most
common prescription medicines.


   To date, the consumers league has received about 120,000
requests from across the country for the brochure, which includes
information on how to take everything from antibiotics to
anti-anxiety drugs.


   These are some of the recommendations:


   _ Take penicillin and amoxicillin on an empty stomach, unless it
causes upset, in which take them with food.


   _ For Cipro, Levaquin, Floxin and Trovan, other antibiotics, the
key is to avoid calcium-containing products such as milk, yogurt,
antacids and any iron-containing vitamins and minerals. Such foods
and vitamins significantly decrease drug absorption.


   _ With the anti-anxiety drugs Xanax or Valium, be aware that
caffeine may cause excitability, nervousness and hyperactivity.


   _ Avoid eating foods high in the chemical tyramine, such as
cheese and sausage, if you are taking antidepressants known as
monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors. The mix can cause a potentially
fatal rise in blood pressure.


   Health experts welcome the National Consumers League's effort,
but emphasize that the best defense against any harmful food-drug
combination is open and frequent communication among patients,
doctors and pharmacists.


   ``Everyone should perform as a team,'' said Kathleen M. Bonnier,
a pharmacist at Lindsay Drug Co. in Troy, N.Y.


   &UR;  &LR;  &QL;


   (For a copy of the National Consumers League's brochure on
food-drug interactions, send $2 to the National Consumers League,
1701 K St. NW, Suite 1200, Washington, DC 20006.)

results.content:
1997-11-30 
 China Begins Exporting Nutritious Spirulina to USA 


HANGZHOU, November 30 (Xinhua) -- A local health-food producer
in Hangzhou, capital of Zhejiang Province, has won approval from
the U.S. Food and Drug Administration o export spirulina, a
nutritious edible seaweed.


The Zhejiang Oriental Lanbao Medical and Health-Care Goods
Company, which has developed the Lanyijian Spirulina Tube,
recently shipped its first batch of the nutritious food to the
United States.


Spirulina is a kind of tiny seaweed, with a history of 3.5
billion years. It is one of the oldest biological species living
on photosynthesis, according to local experts.


Spirulina is said to be so nutritious that one gram of it is
equal to 1,000 grams of vegetables or fruit.


The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations has
listed the seaweed as the most ideal food for mankind. In many
developed countries, it is compulsory for children to consume a
minimum amount of spirulina.


Chinese-made spirulina tubes are believed to be competitive in
the international market for their purity and low prices, local
experts say.

results.content:
HOW TO ENJOY OLIVE OIL 



   SANTA ROSA, Calif. _ Olive oil on the table has been fashionable
at many restaurants for the past decade. But not everyone knows
what to do when confronted by silverware, napkin, fresh bread, salt
and pepper _ and a bottle of olive oil.


   You try to figure why there is no butter on the table, and what
you are supposed to do with the oil?


   Hey, it's easy. Just pour the oil on your bread. If you get a
small saucer, pour the oil on the saucer and dip your bread. Pour
directly or dip. Either way is OK. If there is one plate of oil for
the whole table, just share, family-style, politely.


   More and more restaurants, especially Italian ones, are adopting
the Mediterranean tableau, serving olive oil as a regular
condiment, leaving the butter in the kitchen.


   If you have to have bread and butter too, don't hesitate to ask.
In most restaurants, the customer is always right.


   But when the oil is there, consider pouring it on your bread, or
drizzling on top of a hearty vegetable soup or grilled vegetables.


   Restaurateur Michael Hirschberg remembers shocking his staff 10
years ago when he said he wanted to put olive oil instead of butter
at the table at his Ristorante Siena.


   ``The waiters reacted in horror. I might have said we are going
to put rat poison on the table,'' Hirschberg said.


   Now that restaurant is Mistral and there still is olive oil,
with a pour spout, at every table. Mistral serves 100 lunches a
day, and gets maybe one or two requests for butter.


   ``People seem to understand. Some people pour it on to the
bread, others on the plate and dip. I don't know if there is a
proper way,'' Hirschberg said.


   Marin County olive oil maven Nan McEvoy pours her signature oil
into soup and onto fresh bread. Healdsburg olive oil producer
Ridgley Evers likes drizzling his on fresh fish or delicately
cooked French lentils.


   The point of fine olive oil is that it enhances the taste of the
food.


   Save the very best as an exquisite flavoring in butternut squash
soup, over grilled vegetables or dotted on gently steamed fava
beans, Evers said.


   ``There is no one best oil. You should buy an inexpensive oil to
cook with and you should use a series of very good oils to finish
with. You will end up with better flavor, less fat and spending
less money,'' he said.


   As the wine connoisseurs like to say: Try it. Your opinion is
the most important one.


   (The Press Democrat in Santa Rosa, Calif., is part of the New
York Times Regional Newspaper Group.)

results.content:
&QL; 
 &QL; 
SAN FRANCISCO _ We asked experts from Williams-Sonoma, Home Chef
and Sur La Table cookware stores to list gadgets they expect to be
hot sellers for holiday gifts. Which will endure as favorite
kitchen tools and which will end up in the bottom drawer? Only time
will tell.

   &UR; Razor-sharp graters and zesters. &LR;  This line from Microplane, a
company that makes extraordinarily sharp woodworking tools, has
entered the cookware market. Kit Dombrowski from Sur La Table calls
the graters ``amazing.'' They come in five sizes, and retail from
$13-$19.


   &UR; Potato ricers and food mills.  &LR; These tools are far from new,
but Home Chef founder Judith Ets-Hokin says they are _ and predicts
they will continue to be _ strong sellers.


   Potato ricers create fluffy, lump-free mashed potatoes and
retail for around $20.


   Food mills are much more versatile; they work as a masher,
strainer, blender and ricer _ but they can be expensive. Home
Chef's most popular food mill retails for $85 and comes with
exchangeable disks for additional versatility. Prices range from
$30-$100.


   &UR; Nonstick baking sheet liners.  &LR; Ets-Hokin says these are a great
gift choice for bakers. The silicon-coated liners allow cookies and
candies to easily slide off and are making a move from the
professional to home kitchen. Home Chef's eight stores sold 61 of
them in one recent business day. The liners come in two sizes and
retail for around $26.


   &UR; The Instant-Marinator.  &LR; Vacuvin makes this piece of equipment
that reduces the time it takes to marinate meat from one hour to 17
seconds. The meat is placed in a pouch with the marinade &UR;  &LR; and the
device removes the air, causing the pores to open. &UR;  &LR; After 17
seconds, the air is let back into the pouch. The pores close,
holding flavor inside. The Instant-Marinator retails for $29.


   &UR; A gravy/stock strainer.  &LR; These measuring cups, with a long
pouring spout coming off the bottom, are not new but are remarkably
useful to get rid of fat in stock and pan drippings. Since fat
rises to the top, when liquids are poured out of the cup through
the bottom spout, the fat remains and can be discarded. The
strainer retails around $15.


   &UR; OXO Good Grips turkey lifter.  &LR; This gadget eases the chore of
getting the heavy holiday bird out of the pan. Slip the hook into
the turkey cavity and pull. It retails for about $10.


   &UR; Camerons Smoker. &LR;  No need to wait for summer barbecue season if
you enjoy smoked foods. This smoker is designed to be used indoors.
It sits on any stovetop and imparts smoke flavor into meat,
poultry, fish or vegetables as they cook. It retails for around
$60.


   &UR; Popeil Showtime Rotissierie and Grill ($179.99) and George &LR; 
 &UR; Forman Grill ($99.95).  &LR; Both are ``as seen on TV'' items, bringing
outdoor cooking into the kitchen. The table-top rotissiere is large
enough to hold two chickens. The Foreman ``lean, mean grilling
machine'' is an electric grilling pan that allows fat to run off
into a tray. At Macy's, these two items have been outselling the
classic Cuisinart food processor.


   &UR; Millennium-themed items.  &LR; Stores are heavily promoting
everything from caviar spoons to monogrammed Champagne stoppers for
end-of-the-year celebrations. But what will happen to these come
Jan. 2, 2000?


   (Rebecca Markowitz is a student at the California Culinary
Academy.)

results.content:
&HT;      


 &UR;  &QL;  &LR; 
 &UR; SAN FRANCISCO _ &LR;  Culinary assumptions abound in the cooking world.
For example, we ``know'' these truisms:

   _ Dried beans must be soaked overnight before cooking.


   _ Meat shouldn't be salted before cooking or it will lose too
much moisture.


   _ Pork roast must be cooked to 170 degrees for flavor and
safety.


   In our new ``Best Way'' column starting today, the Food staff
will systematically challenge many of these truisms and techniques
that our mothers, friends and cookbook authors have told us were
true.


   Cooking has changed, but our assumptions often haven't. We have
better ovens that bake with more even heat. The freshness and
quality of produce and meats have improved. We can buy more
varieties of meats and vegetables that benefit from different
cooking techniques. Plus we have less time to experiment in the
kitchen to find out what works and what doesn't.


   In ``Best Way,'' the Food staff will examine preparation
presumptions and try to establish the most reliable way to cook
many of our favorite foods.


   Today we tackle the ultimate comfort food _ baked potatoes.
After testing, tasting and retesting we tried 16 variations before
coming up with the winner.


   We also developed a citrus marinade for chicken and pork to
determine the optimum time the meat should marinate and whether the
marinade should contain salt. You may be surprised at the results.


   In coming weeks we'll examine the dried bean question. We'll
share our findings on producing the creamiest, fluffiest scrambled
eggs; and we'll even tackle the best way to brew coffee.


   If you have a cooking question or a subject you'd like us to
investigate, we'd love to hear from you. We'll answer as many
questions as we can in print. Send it to Best Way, Food Department,
The Chronicle, 901 Mission St., San Francisco, Calif. 94103.


   &QL; 
 &QL; 
 &UR; By Elizabeth Brubaker &QL;  &LR; 
 &UR; c. 1999 The San Francisco Chronicle &QL;  &LR; 
 &UR;  &QL;  &LR; 
 &UR; SAN FRANCISCO _ &LR;  There's nothing simpler than a baked potato, or so
we thought until we started to figure out the best way to cook it.
We discovered that even slight changes in the cooking method and
temperature could make big differences in the final product.


   In a three-step process, we cooked medium-sized russet potatoes
14 ways, testing oven temperature, cooking time and cooking style.
We wrapped, oiled, buttered, salted _ and left some completely
plain. We even tried the microwave.


   In our series of taste tests, the Food staff agreed potatoes are
best when cooked in a 350-degree oven for 11/2 hours. Potatoes
baked at higher temperatures for less time had limp skins and dense
flesh.


   The most varied results, however, came from slight changes in
the cooking method.


   The potatoes cooked in foil were a disaster _ they tasted more
steamed than baked. The skin was limp and chewy, the flesh dense
and overly-moist.


   Rubbing the potato with oil produced a similar steamed effect,
but the flavor was better.


   And when microwaved, the potato turned into a shriveled, mushy
mess.


   &QL; 
 &UR; THE BEST WAY &LR;


   The plain potato, pierced with a fork to let steam escape,
produced the best results. Baked at 350 degrees for 11/2 hours, the
potato emerged with a great flavor and a light and fluffy texture.
In addition, the skin was crisp but chewable.


   &QL; 
 &UR; AN APPEALING ALTERNATIVE &LR;


   If you want a change from the pure baked potato experience, the
potato rubbed with olive oil and coarse salt is a good choice. The
skin absorbs the flavor of the oil and the flecks of salt give it
added visual interest.


   Surprisingly, the Food staff found that the potato rubbed with
butter wasn't as good as the one with oil. It was fluffier inside,
but the cooked butter flavor didn't improve the outside.


   &LR;  &QL; 
 &UR; FOR THE HURRIED COOK &LR;


   In a time crunch, you can microwave a potato for 5 minutes, then
finish it in a 350-degree oven for 10 minutes. The oven helps crisp
the skin and dry

results.content:
FRESH PRODUCE PILING UP? READERS TO THE RESCUE



   Hot weather means work in the kitchen for gardeners. You don't
want to waste all your effort by letting fresh produce go bad, but
you don't want to spend every hour ``putting things by,'' either.


   Frances Riley of Grand Prairie, Texas, sent in this pickle
recipe a few years ago. Frances says she thinks this recipe may be
the one used for the pickles served at McGehee's Catfish Restaurant
in Oklahoma.


   Julie Wende of Fort Worth sent in the recipe for ratatouille,
which makes a fine entree.


   _


   CADDO LAKE TOMATO PICKLES


   Yields 7 pints


   3 cups sugar


   1/2 cup pickling salt


   1 quart white vinegar


   1 gallon green tomatoes, roughly chopped


   1 quart onions, roughly chopped


   1/2 quart green hot peppers, chopped (jalapenos or a mix of
jalapenos and sweet bell peppers)


   Bring sugar, salt and vinegar to a boil. Add vegetables. Bring
contents of pot to a boil and boil for 2 minutes.


   Pack into hot, sterilized canning jars. Seal and process in
hot-water bath for 10 minutes. Serve either chilled or at room
temperature, with fried fish or any other plain meat.


   Nutritional analysis per 1/4 cup: 24 calories, 0 fat, 6 grams
carbohydrates, trace protein, 0 cholesterol, 359 milligrams sodium.


   _


   GARDEN RATATOUILLE


   Serves 4


   12 slices sourdough bread


   10 tablespoons garlic oil (coarsely chopped garlic added to
olive oil and marinated overnight)


   1/4 pound each Roma tomatoes, zucchini, red or green bell
peppers and any other garden vegetable


   2 tablespoons olive oil


   1 clove garlic, chopped


   Parmesan cheese or salt


   Fresh herbs such as thyme, rosemary and basil


   Thinly slice vegetables and then cut into 2-inch pieces. Add to
skillet with olive oil and garlic, and saute until tender (about 15
minutes). Add water by tablespoons as needed. Vegetables should be
cooked thoroughly and there should be a little vegetable ``gravy.''
Cut sourdough slices into fourths, brush with garlic oil (and the
garlic pieces, for garlicaholics) and sprinkle lightly with salt or
Parmesan cheese, then toast in oven. Chop herbs roughly to release
their aroma.


   Serve vegetables atop the toast, sprinkled with fresh herbs.


   Nutritional analysis per serving: 340 calories, 15 grams fat, 44
grams carbohydrates, 8 grams protein, 0 cholesterol, 466 milligrams
sodium, 40 percent of calories from fat.


   (Beverly Bundy is food editor for the Fort Worth Star-Telegram.
Send recipes and requests to Beverly Bundy, Fort Worth
Star-Telegram, Box 1870, Fort Worth, Texas 76101. Or E-mail to
bbundy(at)star-telegram.com. Include a daytime phone number.
Responses to requests will be made only through this column. Visit
the Star-Telegram's online services on the World Wide Web:
www.star-telegram.com) nn
