results.content:
THE GRILL OF YOUR DREAMS



   With today's penchant for outdoor living, creating a luxurious
contemporary patio and back yard and investing in a fabulous custom
built-in barbecue _ an extension of the great room _ is one of the
hottest trends.


   But you don't have to have a lavish setting or a fancy grill to
enjoy wonderful succulent foods cooked outdoors. A simple charcoal
or gas grill _ or even a hibachi _ will do.


   Grilling is still the all-American pastime. Seventy-five percent
of U.S. households own and use a barbecue grill _ and more than 60
percent of gas grill owners cook out several times a week
year-round, according to the Barbecue Industry Association.


   ``Grilling is so easy and tasty, it's no wonder it is one of
America's favorite outdoor pastimes,'' says Kristi Fuller, editor
of ``Better Homes and Gardens The New Grilling Book'' (Meredith
Books; $29.95). The down-to-earth volume covers all the basics _
including information on regional preferences, starting a fire,
heat control, timing tips, food safety, grilling gadgets and how to
select a grill. You'll also find a grilling glossary along with
grilling charts and tips sprinkled throughout the 372 pages, which
feature more than 500 recipes.


   Taste was the primary focus, although simplicity and ease of
preparation _ along with straightforward ingredients readily
available in supermarkets _ were also considerations in recipes,
Fuller says. All include prep and cooking times, as well as
nutritional information.


   Recipes run the gamut from condiments, appetizers, sides and
desserts to beef, veal, lamb, pork, chicken, turkey, fish,
shellfish, game and fowl. A separate chapter covers smoke cooking
with recipes like Pecan-Smoked Pork Chops, Texas Beer-Smoked Ribs
and Double-Smoked Salmon With Horseradish Cream.


   When it comes to smoke cooking, Fuller favors an electric smoker
because it's the most reliable. However, she suggests getting
acquainted with the smoking process on a simple scale by using a
charcoal or gas grill before investing in other equipment such as a
vertical water smoker or a horizontal dry smoker.


   Cooking on gas or charcoal grills is done by one of two cooking
methods _ direct or indirect heat. Direct grilling _ where foods
are placed directly over the heat source (and should be turned
halfway through the cooking time) _ is similar to broiling and
best-suited to foods that are tender, small or thin and cook
quickly in less than 25 minutes. That includes burgers, steaks,
kabobs, chops, hot dogs, boneless poultry, fish and most
vegetables.


   Direct grilling can be done with the lid up or down, but when
the cover is closed, the grill begins to simulate an oven. You can
cook larger items such as roasts or bone-in poultry more slowly
this way and impart a smoky flavor.


   When food is cooked by indirect heat, it is placed adjacent to,
rather than directly over the coals _ and the cover is down. This
method is used for large cuts of meat, ribs, whole fish and birds,
and other foods that require longer, slower cooking.


   When starting a charcoal grill, figure on mounding and igniting
about 30 briquettes per pound of meat to be cooked with the lid up.
Since it'll take about 20 to 30 minutes for the coals to turn ash
gray, start the grill 30 minutes before you're planning to grill
the food. Begin preheating a gas grill 10 to 15 minutes prior to
cooking.


   A key to successful grilling is determining the point when the
charcoal or gas will have attained the ideal temperature for
cooking the food.


   ``Too-high heat can char and dry out the food, while too-low can
defeat the quick-cooking benefit of grilling,'' says Fuller.


   You can judge the approximate temperature of the coals by how
long you can hold your hand above the coals at the cooking level
(of the food). If you can hold your hand comfortably over the coals
for only two seconds, figure that the fire is hot and the
temperature will be around 400 to 450 degrees F. Coals should
appear barely covered with gray ash and be burning when done. A
medium fire e

results.content:
&HT;   



   DAYTON, Ohio _ Using fertility drugs is expensive and
time-consuming. It can lead to painful frustration and unsettling
intrusion in the bedroom.


   But it doesn't have to carry the risk of delivering a litter of
children.


   The recent births of eight babies in Houston, Texas has drawn
criticism from the American Society for Reproductive Medicine and
the New York Times editorial page, which decried its inherent
health danger and expense.


   ``If I wanted to, I could have had patients with octuplets,''
says Dr. Mark Bidwell, the reproductive endocrinologist who directs
Reproductive Medicine at Kettering Medical Center. ``But I don't
think any responsible infertility specialist would do that.''


   If a properly trained physician adequately monitors a woman's
response to fertility drugs, the doctor can tell when conditions
are ripe for a multiple pregnancy and take steps to avoid it,
Bidwell says. In order to avoid it, the patient must agree to stop
a treatment course that costs about $3,000 and results in
successful pregnancies only about once in every five attempts. And
most people's health plans don't cover the treatment. Also, doctors
and administrators realize they compete with other specialists on
the basis of their pregnancy rates.


   Another problem is that doctors who administer fertility drugs
don't always recognize the warning signs of multiple conceptions,
Bidwell says. He and other sub-specialists have learned how to
identify women who are especially sensitive to the potent
injectable drugs. The 27-year-old Houston mother's sensitivity
became clear when she miscarried triplets earlier in the year.


   ``That should have been a tremendous red flag,'' Bidwell says.


   An alternative but even more expensive technique is in vitro
fertilization, in which eggs are fertilized outside the woman's
body. Its advantage, says Bidwell, is the doctor can control the
number of embryos that are created and implanted in the woman's
uterus.


   ``There are never any 100 percent guarantees,'' he says. And
about one-third of women who become pregnant under fertility
treatments give birth to more than one child. One-quarter of them
will deliver twins, and virtually all of the other 8 percent will
have triplets, but even most specialists will have occasional
patients with quadruplets or quintuplets.


   ``But that,'' says Bidwell, ``happens once or twice in an entire
career.'


   Resolve to add fruits and veggies to diet


   ATLANTA _ After weeks of family celebrations, office parties and
nonstop socializing, a lot of folks are feeling as stuffed as a
Christmas goose.


   But soon, all that revelry will give way to resolutions.


   And chances are, many will resolve to diet _ whether it's to
lose the 5 pounds gained over the holidays or the 20 pounds put on
over the last year. Or maybe it's simply a desire to eat and feel
better.


   No matter the reason _ or the particular diet philosophy you
plan to follow _ there's one goal that's good for everyone: Eat
more fruits and vegetables. Shoot for five servings a day at the
least _ the more the better. And most of us can stand to improve.


   Nationally, less than 25 percent are meeting the minimum
recommendation.


   Many folks are counting french fried potatoes _ the most popular
vegetable dish consumed in America, and a fat-rich nutritional
disaster _ as one of their servings, according to Chris Rosenbloom,
a nutritionist and professor at Georgia State University.


   Scientific evidence indicates that phytochemical and antioxidant
nutrients found in fruits and veggies protect human tissue from the
kind of toxic damage that occurs with everyday living. That means
diets rich in such foods may actually help prevent some cancers and
heart damage in addition to helping to lower cholesterol,
protecting vision and regulating blood pressure and blood sugar
levels.


   Vitamin C, vitamin E and selenium are phytochemicals. So are
beta carotene and carotenoids, found in such foods as carrots,
sweet potatoes and red peppers. Carotenoids are believed to

results.content:
Peter Martinelli, a Marin rancher committed to sustainable
agriculture and organic farming, has a similarly optimistic message
about what many perceive as adversarial opposites. He thinks
traditional agricultural interests and environmentalists can be
friends, working together toward changes in land use that benefit
both interests.


   Martinelli's family has been farming just north of Bolinas since
the 1930s. He didn't plan to follow in his father's and
grandfather's footsteps, but rather studied English and history at
the University of California at Berkeley.


   The pull of the land, however, won out over academia. Not long
after graduation, Martinelli, now 36, was back in West Marin,
tilling the soil and preaching the creed of the new environmentally
sensitive farmer. He had a mentor of impeccable credentials: For
nine years, he worked for Warren Weber, whose Star Route Farm,
launched in the early '70s, was a trailblazer for a revitalized
organic movement.


   Martinelli, assisted by siblings and cousins, grows a variety of
cool-werops _ potatoes, beets, carrots, lettuces (``no
tomatoes or corn here,'' he jokes), garlic, chard, kale and winter
squash _ on his family's 20 acres.


   The squash are particularly dear to his heart. They thrive in
the smket where his land is located _ it's a little more
protected than most of the surrounding land and therefore just a
smidgen warmer. The squash are also what he calls ``a low-life
support crop'' _ from planting until harvest, they need little
care. They don't attract insects nor do they require much water.


   Butternut and delicata are the most popular varieties _
Martinelli says it's partly because of their sweetness and partly
because they are manageable in size. Both those qualities appeal to
his customers who come to the Martinelli booth at the Saturday
farmers' market at Pt. Reyes Station and the Wednesday market in
Fairfax. He also has a stand at Tomales Bay that's open Wednesdays
through Sundays.


   The large _ in some instances, humongous _ squash he grows are
generally headed for the kitchens of his restaurant clients, who
include Manka's in Inverness, Insalata's in San Anselmo, and Chez
Panisse and Cafe Rouge in Berkeley.


   Restaurant chefs love to deal with these big boys _ kabocha,
turban and banana, and the giant, curved Tahitian squash that
resembles a butternut squash on growth hormones.


   Martinelli intends to plant more varieties in the future,
although he has already come at least half-circle. Historically,
the ranch, established in the 1870s, was first a dairy and apple
farm. His family started out raising beef cattle on the land, and
then he turned it into a vegetable farm.


   He now feels that mixed use _ cattle and vegetables _ is
probably the most ecologically sound, allowing for on-site
recycling of just about all the byproducts of farming.


   Martinelli's political fervor has not abated as his views have
evolved. He lobbies government to provide incentives to family
farms so a healthy farm belt can survive around towns and cities.
And he is dedicated to guiding consumers back to the once prevalent
belief that fresh food, lovingly grown in close proximity to its
markets, delivers optimal taste and nutrition.

results.content:
COMMUNITY CARDEN HELPS FEED RESERVATION RESIDENTS 



   ETHETE, Wyo. _ In the face of cutbacks brought about by the
overhaul of welfare programs, members of the Northern Arapaho Tribe
on the Wind River Reservation have started a seven-acre community
garden with donated land, seeds and equipment to grow vegetables
for themselves and for the elderly and disabled who cannot work.


   ``We were concerned that when time runs out, when they are no
longer eligible for government assistance, what are they going to
do for food?'' said Glen Revere, a nutritionist with the Indian
Health Services on the 2.8 million-acre Wind River Reservation,
about 100 miles east of Jackson, Wyo. ``Then we came up with the
idea for this community garden, and it's been bigger than we ever
expected in so many ways.''


   At the all-volunteer garden, this is the time of year when
potatoes grow larger than a man's fist, popping out of the soil,
and five-foot-high cornstalks develop ears with red, yellow and
white kernels ripening inside. The conditions on these wide plains
near the Wind River Range of the Rocky Mountains can be harsh, with
high winds, late springs and early autumns limit the growing season
to 90 days.


   Revere's partner in this effort is Irene Houser, director of the
Northern Arapaho Tribe Community Services, who has distributed
produce around the Wind River Reservation and to the Pine Ridge
Reservation in southwestern South Dakota.


   Ms. Houser, a member of the Northern Arapaho Tribe, said people
were stunned when she brought them bushels of potatoes, onions,
squash, zucchini, tomatoes, beets, radishes and other vegetables.


   ``They asked, `How much are you going to charge me for this?'''
she recalled. ``I said, `It's free,' and they were so happy. Many
of them didn't have food in their house when I showed up.''


   Mark Soldierwolf, a 70-year-old father of nine and grandfather
of nine, said: ``That food lasted us about six weeks. We dried some
things, boiled some. Just ate all of it.''


   Soldierwolf, a Northern Arapaho who served with the Marines in
World War II and the Korean War, lives with his wife, Florita, one
daughter and one grandchild. They receive food stamps for a
$300-a-month budget for the four of them, but they said they often
fed members of their family who stopped by. Soldierwolf estimated
they saved $70 with the free vegetables.


   Soldierwolf's family represents the problems that plague many of
the 1.3 million American Indians who live on reservations, of whom
49 percent are unemployed. The Bureau of Indian Affairs estimates
that at least half the American Indian population lives in poverty.
Soldierwolf said all but one of his adult children were unemployed.


   ``If you can make it to the end of the month, you're all
right,'' Soldierwolf said, referring to the monthly food stamps.
``It's worse than in the Depression.'' Mrs. Soldierwolf nodded,
with tears in her eyes.


   The Wyoming Department of Family Services says the Northern
Arapaho on the reservation account for 18.9 percent of all welfare
cases in Wyoming. The reservation population of 12,000 _ including
6,000 Northern Arapaho tribal members, about 3,000 Shoshone tribal
members and 3,000 from other tribes _ represents about 2.5 percent
of the state's population of 480,000.


   Revere and Ms. Houser say the community garden can help reduce
dependence on welfare by enabling residents to produce cash crops,
traditional Indian plants to be sold on or off the reservation.


   (STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)


   On the Crow Reservation in Montana, at a five-acre garden to be
planted this fall, the plan is to let people's work part at the
garden count toward fulfillment of their welfare community service
requirement.


   ``We are trying to provide people with skills that they can use
here or take with them,'' said Charlene Johnson, a Crow tribal
member and nutritionist with Indian Health Services. ``Indians are
not horticulturists. They were hunters and gatherers who were
forced to garden when they were put on the reservati

results.content:
1998-11-03 
 Thailand's Inflation Below IMF Forecast 


BANGKOK, November 3 (Xinhua) -- Thailand's inflation is likely
to average between 8.1 percent and 8.2 percent this year, compared
with 9.2 percent predicted by the International Monetary Fund
(IMF) judging from the current trends.


The prediction by Thawatchai Sophasatienpong, deputy
director-general of the Commerce Ministry's Business Economics
Department, is based on a 0.2 percent decline in the consumer
price index (CPI) between September and October, The Bangkok Post
reported Tuesday.


The department expects a similar decline in November and a
further drop in December, as long as there are no unexpected
problems such as floods.


The October inflation was 5.9 percent higher than in the same
month of last year.


The December price increase is expected to be 4.8 percent
year-on-year, compared with 8 percent forecast by the IMF.


The fall in October continued the trend in September, with
foods including rice, eggs, vegetables and fruit down in price.
The food and beverage index was down by 0.7 percent between
September and October, while the index for other products was up
by 0.2 percent.


Products to fall in price last month included fragrant jasmine
rice, pork, cabbages, chilies, orange, eggs and cleaning products.


Prices were unchanged for cooking gas, telecommunications and
electricity services, public transport and clothes. However,
marine equipment, fuel oil, ferry boat services and cement rose in
price.


Thawatchai said declining interest rates and inflation would
spur domestic consumption and economic growth.

results.content:
&HT;     VISIT TO AMERICA OFFERS A TASTE OF THAILAND 



   SCHENECTADY, N.Y. _ For all Aziz Ponary Mlima knew, the fried
tofu and spring rolls served at the cocktail party were
quintessential American fare. After all, this was his first trip to
the United States and he had only seen the John F. Kennedy Airport,
downtown Schenectady and points in between.


   A native of the East African nation of Tanzania, now with the
Goteborg University in Sweden, Mlima was one of more than 200 of
the world's top economists attending the North American
Productivity Workshop, held recently at Union College. The opening
banquet of the three-day seminar, as Mlima would learn somewhere
between the hors d'oeuvres and first entree course, was not
American food, but authentic Thai cuisine.


   Providing a six-course, 13-dish Asian repast as the opening
meal, was one of many ways organizers at the small private college
made a bookish seminar and trip to Schenectady attractive to the
attendees from all parts of the globe.


   Suthathip (Lek) Yaisawarng, chairwoman of the college's
department of economics, co-chair of the event and a native of
Bangkok, spent hours with the school's dining services staff
teaching the finer points of cooking with ingredients such as black
fungus (mushrooms) and makrood (kaffir lime leaves).


   ``I liked to cook when I was child,'' said Yaisawarng, standing
in the giant white tent erected for the feast in front of the Nott
Memorial on the Union campus. ``I didn't know that I'd need to come
back to it, and in such quantities!''


   But early in the evening, dinner was proving to be a highlight
of the workshop.


   As a group of Union professors played Dixieland jazz, attendees
juggled glasses of wine or bottles of beer and jostled each other
for plates of fish cakes with cucumber sauce. They conversed in
English, but the language came with a variety of heavy accents,
including German, French, Australian, Arab, and even Southern. The
delegates hailed from at least 30 countries, including New Zealand,
Bangladesh, Hungary, Belgium and Japan.


   Cocktail hour was followed by a soup course, which, though
plenty spicy for some, was tame by Nostratollah Nafar's standards.
Nafar, a professor at Allameh Tabatabai University in Tehran, Iran,
added ground chili peppers by the tablespoon to his bowl.


   More familiar with both Asian and American cuisine than Mlima,
Nafar explained, ``Chinese food not hot, it's sweet.''


   It is important that people eat together, meet socially and form
personal relationships at events like this so when they get into a
session, they are more likely to open up and make the conference
more productive, said Yaisawarng.


   If Mlima was disappointed to not be dining on New York strip
steaks and New England clam chowder at his first major feast in
America, it didn't last long.


   As the servers brought bowls of lime sorbet between entree
courses, Nafar exclaimed, ``Here's American food _ ice cream!''


   ___


   THAI SPRING ROLL WITH SWEET AND SOUR SAUCE


   2 tablespoons vegetable oil


   3 cloves freshly chopped garlic


   1 cup very lean ground pork


   3 cups julienned carrot


   2 packages cellophane noodles


   2 ounces dried Chinese black mushrooms


   1/2 cup chopped green onion


   1/2 teaspoon black pepper


   2 tablespoons Thai soy sauce


   1 pack spring roll wrappers


   2 tablespoons cornstarch mixed with 2 tablespoons water


   Vegetable oil for deep frying


   2 cups spicy sweet and sour sauce


   1 cup vinegar


   1/2 cup water


   1/3 cup fresh cilantro leaves


   Heat 2 tablespoons vegetable oil in frying pan. Add garlic and
fry for 2 minutes. Add ground pork and cook until done. Add carrot,
noodles, fungus, green onion and stir for 1 minute. Add black
pepper, soy sauce. Set aside to cool.


   Lay out one spring roll wrapper. Place 2 tablespoons of filling
on wrapper and roll. Seal with cornstarch mixture.


   Heat oil for deep frying (not too hot or spring rolls will
burn). Fry rolls until golden. Drain on paper towels before
serving.

results.content:
SALSA: There are plenty of flavor and texture options here, so
pick a couple of bottled favorites to keep handy in the pantry. If
you plan to use them within a week or two, you might want to
purchased the refrigerated salsas, which are fresher tasting but
not as convenient. Salsas of all varieties (tomato, pineapple,
mango and the like) lend themselves to adding Tex-Mex and other
flavors to skillet creations, dips, rice, cold bean and corn
salads, salad dressings and more. Also use salsa to top grilled
chicken breasts, steaks and the like. And of course, it's a great
dip with chips when you have nothing else on hand.


   FROZEN VEGETABLES: Keep a supply of lots of different single
vegetables as well as combinations to use in salads, soups,
stir-fries and more. Some favorites include corn for chowder, sugar
snap peas and various combinations for stir-fries, assorted strips
of red, green and yellow peppers, baby peas and haricots verts. I
like the quality of some of the Trader Joe's offerings.


   FROZEN FRUITS: Lots of possibilities are available including
pineapple, raspberries, strawberries, mango, melons and assorted
fruits to make into quick fruit salads or compotes (serve topped
with cottage cheese for a light dinner during summer), cobblers or
pies. Single fruits or combinations are also great whirred into
smoothies for breakfast or a snack or pureed for sauces for ice
cream, cake or waffles. Try processing frozen raspberries with tofu
in a food processor for a quick frozen dessert.


   SHREDDED CHEESES: Keep several kinds (flavor- and fat-wise) _
including some of the blends _ ready to add to tostadas, lasagna,
casseroles, salads, pizzas, sandwiches or English muffins. The
larger the bag, the bigger the price break. Once opened, these
cheeses have a tendency to lose freshness faster than a large block
of cheese.


   ROASTED RED PEPPERS: Available in jars (Mezzetta brand is my
preference), these are wonderful for those in a hurry. Rinse and
drain them, then puree in a food processor for sauces or dips or
cut them up and toss in soups, salads, sandwiches and main dishes.
Also try marinating pieces in oil, vinegar and a little garlic and
serve as part of an Italian antipasto platter. Once you get in the
habit of using the bottled, you may never go back to roasting your
own.


   CANNED GREEN CHILES: Available whole or diced, these give a
flavor boost to dips, quesadillas, rice, chiles rellenos, sauces,
chili, pizzas, entrees of all kinds and more. Whenever I whip up a
crustless quiche for brunch or dinner, I pour beaten eggs mixed
with a little milk or cream and seasoned with chiles and seasoned
salt and garlic pepper over plenty of shredded cheese in a pie
plate. Bake until set and you're in for some tasty dining.


   CANNED AND BOTTLED OLIVES: I keep all colors and flavors of
pitted olives handy for tapenades (made in no time flat in the food
processor) as well as to embellish casseroles and, particularly,
salads and pasta dishes. The tapenades can be mixed with cream
cheese for a dip, spread on rustic bread slices to accompany soups
and more.


   ARTICHOKE HEARTS: I prefer the canned to frozen (which I find
watery and flavorless). Buy quartered and rinse and drain well (I
add a sprinkling of red wine vinegar and drain well to get rid of
the canned taste) before adding to cold marinated vegetable or
pasta salads. Also great in baked artichoke cheese dip. You'll find
many ways to use them.


   PACKAGED ROASTED REFRIGERATED CHICKEN BREASTS: What a fabulous
and convenient shortcut. To save money, I purchase these at a
warehouse store (Tyson brand) where they are in the neighborhood of
$10-$12 per package of 6 or so breasts. Remove the skin and bones
and slice, chop or cut in strips to use in the full gamut of dishes
from soups and salads to entrees. Keep some frozen to thaw on a
dime when you don't have any other protein on hand to help solve
the dinner dilemma.


   ASSORTED MUSTARDS: I've been hooked on a large variety _
including Dijon, honey mustard, grainy, hot and prepared yellow
mustards _ for ye

results.content:
&HT;   



   Have you ever contemplated onions? Probably not. They hang
humbly in their little mesh sacks in probably every kitchen on
earth, and nobody ever pays them much attention or ever considers
where we would be without them. Yet the lack of an onion at a
crucial time can send you out to hunt one up more quickly than just
about anything, so necessary are they to our palates. The pale,
unassuming onion: always in the background, perpetually playing a
supporting role, allowing flashier foods to shine and dazzle.


   Onions weren't always taken so much for granted. When the world
was younger and people had a lot less to distract them, folks
flat-out marveled at the onion, which was one of the first
vegetables that humans cultivated for food after it emerged from
the primordial ooze. With its translucent layers and spheres within
spheres, the onion took on religious significance. The Egyptians
believed them nothing less than a symbol of eternity and took their
sacred oaths on onions.


   The Byzantine domes that are part of the architecture of
religious structures the world over? Onions.


   Their value became more secular during the Middle Ages, when you
could pay off your debts with a sack of onions. During the Civil
War, Gen. Ulysses S. Grant informed the War Department, ``I will
not move my army without onions.'' Three trainloads were delivered
to the front the next day.


   Civilization has long since stopped marveling at onions, but
once a year we do get a chance to give them a bit of well-deserved
attention. This is onion season, when growers in places such as
Washington state, Idaho, Oregon, Hawaii, South Texas and, of
course, South Georgia begin tooting their horns about their crop
and everyone becomes a little more aware of the humble bulb.


   Now's a good time to renew our appreciation for the onion, and
about 10 minutes on the Internet allows you to pay proper homage.


   &QR;  To hold your own in any conversation about onions, see
www.bpe.com/food/columns


   /ferrayfiszer/onions.htm for a good, readable overview of the
different types, where they are grown, what makes them sweet or
not, why they make you cry and a little history.


   &QR;  Another very well-done site is maintained by the National
Onion Association. Go to www


   .onions-usa.org/ for health and nutritional information, trivia,
trends and some great recipes.


   &QR;  With all the emphasis on the ancient religious significance of
onions, we forgot to mention that they were once considered a
powerful aphrodisiac. Roman writer Martial advised, ``If your wife
is old and you're . . . exhausted, eat onions in plenty.'' To see
how onions played a part in the romantic lives of the Arabs,
Greeks, Romans and Hindus, drop in at
www.santesson.com/aphrodis/onion


   .htm for an interesting visit.


   &QR;  And then there are onion laws _ lots of 'em. Head for
aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu


   /plantanswers/publications/onions


   /ONIONLAWS.html and learn that:


   &QR;  In Northfield, Conn., local residents are prohibited from
eating raw onions while walking down a street.


   &QR;  Barbers in Columbia, Pa., are prohibited from eating onions
between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m.


   &QR;  In Dyersburg, Tenn., residents aren't allowed to enter a movie
theater within four hours after having eaten raw onions.


   &QR;  And gentlemen in Headland, Ala., need to be aware that ``No
man can place his arm around or kiss an unchaperoned woman without
a good and lawful reason, should he have eaten onions within the
last four hours.''


   We're not kidding here.


   &QR;  Seriously, though, if you're interested in the amazing health
benefits of onions, see vic


   .tamu.edu/Press%20Release/onions91.htm, a site featuring
easy-to-read and interesting information by Jean Carper, author of
the best-selling book ``The Food Pharmacy: Dramatic New Evidence
That Food Is Your Best Medicine'' (Bantam Books).


   &QR;  For the complete skinny on Georgia's very own Vidalia onions _
how to pick, store, cook and eat them _ see ``Let Me Call You
Sweetie'' at augus

results.content:
1999-03-09 
 Myanmar Leader Returns From Thailand Visit 


YANGON, March 9 (Xinhua) -- Chairman of the Myanmar State Peace
and Development Council (SPDC) and Prime Minister Senior General
Than Shwe returned here Tuesday afternoon after ending a two-day
goodwill visit to Thailand.


During his visit in northern Thailand's Chiang Rai on Monday,
Than Shwe held talks with Thai Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai. The
two sides agreed to enhance the two countries' cooperation in
narcotics suppression, including cracking down on drug trade and
illicit trafficking in the infamous Golden Triangle area bordering
Myanmar, Thailand and Laos.


The talks also covered issues on settlement of border dispute,
and the two sides agreed to tackle the marine and fishing dispute
between them through negotiation.


Than Shwe, accompanied by Chuan, also visited a Thai crop
substitution plantation project in Chiang Rai where large areas of
opium have been successfully replaced by cash crops such as
vegetables and fruits.


Than Shwe also called on Thai King Bhumibol Adulyadej in
Bangkok during his visit.


Than Shwe's 40-strong entourage included SPDC First Secretary
Lieutenant-General Khin Nyunt, Foreign Minister U Win Aung and
four other ministers.

&HT;   



   New technology and cutting-edge nutritional research have led
many medical and scientific experts to conclude what everybody and
their great-grandmother have known forever _ that real and
substantial relief can come from over the counter _ the kitchen
counter, that is.


   People from all cultures have always known that curative
cuisine, from chicken soup (they don't call it Jewish penicillin
for nothing) to soups and teas made with curry, chile peppers,
ginger, garlic, citrus, horseradish and a host of other foods often
provide real relief for the ills of mankind.


   What we call ``feeling better,'' scientific researchers are
calling the effects of phytochemicals. Medical science has begun to
test and recognize that substances called phytochemicals, which are
neither vitamins nor minerals but are found in most fruits and
vegetables by the tens of thousands, contain potent therapeutic
properties that often dramatically relieve and sometimes even
eliminate certain illnesses.


   There is so much interest in these ``nutraceuticals'' that
public and private laboratories, including the National Cancer
Institute, are stepping up research by spending millions of dollars
to see how best to identify, extract and use phytochemicals to
create new drugs that in coming decades may be used to fight
diseases from the common cold to cancer.


   At
http://www.phys.com/bnutrition/01selfanalysis/05colds/colds.html, a
site sponsored by Conde Nast in collaboration with Tufts
University, you can find the latest in this exciting field of
nutritional research. But the best part of the site is how we can
use what is known now in our own kitchens to whip up culinary
curatives when the need arises.


   In a section called ``The Culinary Chemist,'' you will find
detailed information on phytochemically rich foods along with
recipes that can help relieve debilitating symptoms of a number of
ailments.


   ``The Symptom Advisor'' asks you to check off certain symptoms
you may be experiencing, from congestion to nausea to diarrhea to
headaches, and then ``prescribes'' a dish that may help. It also
advises, of course, that under certain circumstances you should see
a physician.


   Here are other interesting sites to visit:


   &QR;  At ``Flu Food,'' at
http://www.ab.sympatico.ca/Contents/Health/HEALTHYWAY/recflu.html,
you will find informative articles from various sources including
Better Homes and Gardens, CNN, Redbook and others concerning
kitchen remedies. There also are lots of recipes.


   &QR;  Http://www.naturalland.com/ is an interactive site where you
chat and pick up tips about healing foods, fitness and nutrition.
It changes daily. A recent tip of the day: ``Celery juice has a
mild diuretic effect, similar to many drugs that are prescribed for
high blood pressure. The juice is highly nutritious and can be
helpful for people who need to balance their blood pressure.''
Another imparted this bit of nutritional wisdom: ``For optimum skin
repair and healing, increase intake of foods rich in vitamin A and
zinc. Good sources for vitamin A are carrots, sweet potatoes,
butternut squash and mangoes. Zinc is found in wheat germ, lima
beans, legumes and nuts.'' Good stuff here.


   &QR;  At
http://www.ivillage.com/food/articles/0,3035,221(tilde)77,00.html,
you will find an excellent article entitled ``Cures in Your
Cupboard'' by nutritionist Sue Gilbert, who, while she doesn't go
into phytochemical research, does gi/ve sound nutritional
information about different foods.


   &QR;  And, finally, at
http://www.betterbaking.com/baker2/delisou.html you will find the
classic, Jewish penicillin.


   SOUP


   Bronchitis Broth


   Makes 15 servings of broth and vegetables; may be served
separately Preparation time: 40 minutes Cooking time: 1 hour, 10
minutes


   Pulmonary specialist Dr. Irwin Ziment at the University of
California-Los Angeles faxed the recipe he gives his patients, and
we started from there. After cooking the chopped vegetables for 30
minutes, you can refrigerate the broth and complete it up to two
days later.

results.content:
WHY GOOD PEOPLE EAT BAD FOOD 



   Americans aren't stupid.


   They've known for years that the fast food they're eating
probably isn't good for them. Back in 1988, 60 percent of fast food
diners told Consumer Reports that they were ``worried'' about the
nutrient value of fast food, and only four percent felt the food
deserved top health marks.


   The worriers had reason to fret. Although McDonald's and other
fast food chains have added salads, grilled chicken, and other
healthful entrees in recent years, today's menus are still full of
foods that are bad for the heart, such as Burger King's Double
Whopper with cheese, which contains a whole day's fat allowance
under one wrapper.


   But that doesn't stop Americans from spending one in every seven
food dollars on fast food, as the lure of quick and inexpensive
meals outweighs their health concerns. In fact, more than three
quarters of fast food eaters believe they're getting good value for
their money, according to a recent survey by the National
Restaurant Assocation.


   Now, health researchers warn that many fast foods may be more
hazardous than previously believed because so many contain ``trans
unsaturated fatty acids'' or so-called transfats, a particularly
hazardous type of fat that doesn't appear on food labels. Many
fast-food french fries and other products are cooked in transfats,
used to harden the vegetable oils restaurants now use instead of
animal fat.


   Walter C. Willett, chairman of nutrition at the Harvard School
of Public Health, has called on the US Food and Drug Administration
to require transfat labelling on fast foods as part of the agency's
new transfat labelling regulations, arguing that consumers are
confused by ``deceptive labels such as `cholesterol-free' or
`cooked in vegetable oil.' ''


   But, even if the FDA agrees with Willett, few expect transfats
to spur a revolution among fast food diners. McDonald's officials
thought the anti-fat revolution was at hand once before, in the
early 1990s when they trotted out a hamburger with half the fat of
normal burgers. By 1997, with sales languishing, the McLean Deluxe
was cancelled.


   ``It was launched with high hopes and seeming demand, but . . .
there wasn't really very much consumer interest in it,'' said
McDonald's spokesman Walt Riker.


   However, for those who want to eat healthfully, there are plenty
of choices at fast food restaurants, partly because chains know
that vegetarians or people on diets can veto the choice of
restaurant for an entire group of diners if there is nothing on the
menu that they want to eat.


   In addition, the fast-growing Subway restaurant chain is going
directly after health-conscious diners with a national advertising
campaign that stresses the low-fat content of their sandwiches. The
menu features seven submarine sandwiches containing less than six
grams of fat; among hamburgers, only a vegetarian ``garden burger''
can beat that.


   Fortunately, there are plenty of guides to help consumers
navigate the world of fast food from books such as ``The Fast Food
Freeway Guide: A Map to Lower Fat and Calories at Fast Food
Restaurants,'' to Internet sites.


   With a few clicks on Cyberdiet.com's ``Fast Food Quest''
section, users can compare fat, salt, cholesterol, calories, and
other nutrition issues among hundreds of fast foods, comparing
individual restaurants directly or seeking out the healthiest foods
from all of them. The fast food chains often have nutritional
information on-line as well.


   In the end, Americans' food choices are a contradictory matter
in which health and nutrition are just one concern. People consume
less fat and more fruit juice than they did 20 years ago, but at
the same time they consume far more soda and about 35 percent more
calories than the 2,000 recommended by the FDA. And so, they
continue to line up to place their orders for such menu items such
as the ``supersize'' Big Mac dinner _ all 1,410 calories of it.

The Seattle Post-Intelligencer plans to move the following for
clients of the NYTimes News Service for editions of Monday, June
14, and thereafter. If you have any questions, please call Veronica
Villarreal at (206) 448-8342.


   TEACHERS-MEMORIES (Seattle) _ The Class of '99 is graduating
after about 30 years, facing a new millenium without chalkdust,
school bells, upraised hands and reverberating hallways. The grads
will miss the toothless grin of a beginning reader, the
``lightbulb'' glow on the face of a kid who finally ``gets'' long
division, the troubled teen who discovers he's an artist, the
junior chemist whose experiment trips the smoke alarm. Yet, say
hundreds of veteran public school teachers statewide, it's time to
retire.


   By Debera Carlton Harrell. (Story will move in the ``a''
category.)


   GUNS-NRA (BELLEVUE, Wash.) _ A trio of House Republicans who
managed the effort to impeach President Clinton predicted they will
successfully defend gun owners' rights in a House fight this week
over proposed gun safety measures. The Clinton administration is
using the National Rifle Association as a ``red herring'' in an
effort to slap more controls on gun-owning Americans, said the
Republican congressmen during a weekend visit here.


   By Joel Connelly. (Story will move in the ``a'' and ``w''
categories.)


   BOEING-AIR SHOW (Paris) _ Commercial airplane orders will be
down significantly this year because of the global economic
slowdown, executives of The Boeing Co. and rival Airbus Industrie
warned yesterday. ``We see substantially fewer orders for the
industry than we saw last year,'' Boeing Commercial Airplane
President Alan Mulally told reporters at the Paris Air Show. ``The
main reason is a slowdown in the economy, especially in Asia.'' But
he said Asia also offers hope of a turnaround.


   By James Wallace. (Story will move in the ``f'' category.)


   INTERNET-ADS (Seattle) _ While new technology that blocks ads on
the Internet benefits consumers who feel bombarded with product
pitches, it is causing a stir among e-commerce and media companies
that hope to generate revenue through online advertising. The
filtering technology, which also blocks unwanted e-mail and Web
identification tags known as ``cookies,'' has forced some
e-commerce companies to re-evaluate their business models and
advertising strategies.


   By John Cook. (Story will move in the ``f'' category.)


   FOOD-PHO (Seattle) _ Nothing recalls home for me quite like a
steaming bowl of pho. Fragrant and comforting, this Vietnamese beef
noodle soup is made from a stock of slow-simmered beef bones. The
national dish of Vietnam, it is the one meal I must have when I
find myself in an unfamiliar place. W/ PHO-RECIPES.


   By Phuong Le. (Story has moved in the ``d'' category.)


   FOOD-PHO-RECIPE (Undated) _ Recipe for pho, Vietnames beef
noodle soup, along with recipes for a vegetable platter, shrimp
spring rolls and Vietnamese-style iced coffee.


   (Story has moved in the ``d'' category.)


   FOOD-OWEN-COLUMN (Undated) _ ``What do you do with that cheap
bag of aging button mushrooms from the supermarket?'' acquaintance
Richard Sieger asks, then answers his own question. ``I bought some
meat that was on sale and made sausage. The Polish butcher who sold
me the hog casings asked what I was going to make. I told him
`mushroom sausage.'


   By John Owen. (Story has moved in the ``d'' category.)


   BBO-MARINERS (Seattle) _ Seattle hosting San Francisco, end of
homestand.


   By Dan Raley. (Story will move in the ``s'' category.)


   BBO-MARINERS-NOTEBOOK (Seattle) _ Notebook items from Sunday's
game.


   By Dan Raley. (Story will move in the ``s'' category.)


   BBO-VECSEY-COLUMN (Seattle) _ Column on Sunday's Mariners-Giants
game.


   By Laura Vecsey. (Story will move in the ``s'' category.)

results.content:
CRUISE LINES RESPOND TO PASSENGERS' DEMANDS FOR HEALTHY FOOD 




   Countless comedians have uttered these words at the outset of a
cruise:


   ``You've come aboard as passengers, but with all the food here,
you'll be leaving as cargo.``


   Better weigh those thoughts. Oh, it's still possible to gorge
yourself silly on around-the-clock dining alternatives. And some
ships have yet to abandon the choco-holic buffet.


   But following the trend on land, most cruise lines now offer
heart-healthy options _ vegetarian entrees, sugar-free desserts,
even complete low-fat, low-cholesterol and low-sodium meals.


   Aboard Celebrity's five ships, nightly ``Lean and Light'' full
menus may include this recommendation: a shrimp cocktail, chilled
gin and tomato consomme with straw mushrooms, veal scaloppine with
lemon and frozen lemon yogurt with dark cherries.


   Total calories: 782. Total grams of fat: 9.


   Other lines offer similar enticements.


   From Princess' ``Healthy Choice'' menu: spaghetti in fresh basil
and tomato sauce, roast pork tenderloin with a corn muffin and warm
Mediterranean salad and lime sherbet.


   From Royal Caribbean's ``ShipShape'' menu: melon balls with port
wine, tossed romaine lettuce and plum tomatoes with fat-free creamy
roasted garlic dressing, baked lobster with citrus sauce and, for
dessert, a phyllo purse with pears and raspberry coulis.


   From Silversea's ``Light and Healthy Cuisine'' selections:
marinated Greek salad; marinated pan-fried scallops served with
capellini pasta, carrots and broccoli; and ice coupe peach Melba
with diet ice cream.


   From the ``Light Selections'' aboard Radisson Seven Seas' Song
of Flower: a strawberry cup; a salad with curry vinaigrette;
steamed rock lobster tail enhanced with saffron bouillon, vegetable
pearls and boiled potatoes; and a tropical fruit platter with diet
ice cream.


   Light cooking expert Jeanne Jones has created 20 new
lacto-vegetarian selections for Windstar's four sailing ships.
Among them: pear and gorgonzola pizza, herbed vegetable strudel,
Moroccan sweet potato stew, Cajun pasta and enchiladas with
butternut squash and corn.


   Among vegetarian entrees served aboard Royal Caribbean ships: a
five-layer vegetable tart served with red pepper puree, stir-fried
Chinese vegetables with tofu and Caribbean curried vegetables with
black beans.


   Carnival, the world's largest cruise line, spices lunch and
dinner menus with ``Nautica Spa'' items such as poached sole with
red bean ratatouille, steamed whole red snapper in coconut water
and lemon grass and a low-fat pumpkin pie. Meats, fish and poultry
are roasted or broiled, salads are prepared with diet dressings and
desserts with Sweet 'N Low or NutraSweet.


   No mystery surrounds cruise lines' concentration on lighter,
healthier cuisine: It's passenger demand.


   Holland America officials cite these figures: In 1985, only 10
percent of that cruise line's passengers ordered fish when provided
the option; today, almost 40 percent choose fish on Caribbean
cruises and 50 percent order fish in Alaska. Another 10 percent
order poultry.


   As part of its ``Passport to Fitness'' onboard program, Holland
America offers low-fat, low-calorie cuisine not only in its main
dining rooms but also at buffets. A typical Lido Buffet salad bar
includes 20 to 30 fresh items and a wide selection of light
dressings. Cholesterol-free mayonnaise and other condiments are
provided.


   Waves of change are sweeping over other aspects of shipboard
dining, too.


   No longer does a cattle-car mentality automatically prevail,
with passengers herded into one humongous room at an appointed
moment and spoon-fed course after course by singing waiters.


   Fine dining has arrived at sea. In intimate settings. At
flexible times. With preparations that would make a three-star
Michelin chef proud.


   Celebrity, at the forefront of this culinary revolution, even
employs a three-star Michelin chef _ Michel Roux, French-trained
proprietor of the Waterside Inn at Bray in Berkshire, England _ to
create its men

results.content:
&HT;   



   WACO, Texas _ Jacob Koehler, 2 1/2, will eat just about any
fruit or vegetable his dad puts in front of him.


   It's a good thing, too, considering his dad( David Koehler, is a
produce manager.


   ``Eating fruits and vegetables is very important, especially in
the early years for growing and building bones and muscles,''
Koehler said. ``They're good for getting the vitamin A's and C's
you need for a good start in life.''


   Getting children accustomed to eating a variety of fruits and
veggies early on in life is a key to setting them on the right
track to good, lifelong eating habits, nutrition experts say.


   The vitamins and minerals found in many fruits and vegetables,
especially vitamins C, A and B, calcium, fiber, iron and
carbohydrates, are essential for growth and development.


   Strawberries, kiwi, all citrus fruits and broccoli are all great
sources of vitamin C, an antioxidant thought to have protect
against certain chronic diseases, such as cancer, according to Lisa
Hoelscher, a registered dietitian who consults individuals on their
diets at her business Excellence in Health.


   Broccoli also contains fiber and rome calcium.


   Corn and potatoes contain some B vitamins, including niacin in
corn, and both are good complex carbohydrate choices and have
fiber.


   Carrots and other orange or yellow vegetables are sources for
vitamin A, another antioxidant.


   Some fruits and vegetables, including broccoli, cabbage,
cauliflower, Brussels sprouts, kohlrabi, garlic, onion, leeks,
chives, oranges and grapefruit, also contain phytochemicals,
substances that have been shown to provide protective effects
against chronic diseases such as cancer and heart disease,
Hoelscher said.


   According to the Food Guide Pyramid, children and adults should
eat five to nine servings of fruits and vegetables each day.


   Lelanie Presley, a dietitian and food service supervisor with
the Wcco Independent School District, says many children aren't
eating the number of servings of fruits and vegetables they should.


   ``I think part of it has to do with parent's knowledge of what
good nutrition is,'' she said.


   Today's always-on-the-go society doesn't help much, either,
proving a challenge even for health-savvy parents to ensure their
children eat the recommended servings of fruits and vegetables.


   ``Adults are in such a fast-food age now, more than they used to
be . . . that I think it makes it harder and harder for children to
learn about vegetables,'' Hoelscher said.


   But just because people are eating quickly these days doesn't
mean they have to leave out vegetables or allow children to turn to
their food of choice _ junk food, Hoelscher said.


   Here are some ways parents can get children _ from picky eaters
to overeaters _ to add more fruits and vegetables to their diets:


   _ Keep an assortment of fruits and veggies easily accessible to
youngsters.


   ``If he sees them, he'll want to eat those first,'' Koehler said
of his son.


   _ Take kids shopping for fruits and vegetables.


   ``It seems to always help when you take them shopping with you
because when they pick out some of the fruits and vegetables. They
have ownership in it,'' Koehler said. It also familiarizes kids
with the different type of fruits and vegetables, so they aren't
foreign objects once cooked and on the plate.


   _ When kids are old enough, have them help out in the kitchen.


   ``If they help in preparation of it, they have ownership in it
and want to eat it once it's cooked,'' Koehler said.


   _ Get creative with food. Make fun faces out of the different
fruits or carve vegetables into fun shapes.


   A child will eat almost anything if you melt some Velveeta
cheese on it or dip it in ranch dressing, Koehler said.


   _ Serve bite-size veggies, like carrots and broccoli, at room
temperature.


   _ For the picky eater, look for seasonal fruits. A child might
not be fond of citrus fruits, but may like watermelon, peaches and
plums, which are readily available during the summer.

Add N.Y. Times News Service budget for papers of Wednesday,
March 3:


   &UR; DINING &LR;  (``a'' code)


   AMERICAN-MEAT (New York) _ Bruce Aidells and his collaborator,
Denis Kelly, has spent nearly a decade studying the state of meat
in America to produce ``The Complete Meat Cookbook,'' published
last November by Houghton Mifflin. Not only does it secure his
image as a man unafraid of meat, even in these vegetable-revering
times, but it also is rife with heretical ideas. ``Meat has changed
in America,'' he said. ``We need to change the way we cook it.'' By
Molly O'Neill.


   With photo.


   With recipes.


   MEAT-MARINATE (Undated) _ Since the earliest days of recorded
history, and maybe even before, humans have marinated their food,
steeping meat, fowl and fish in some combination of liquid _
usually oil or acid _ and seasonings. At first, there were
practical reasons: Tough meat needed to be made tender, it needed
to be preserved, and, with humans ever attuned to improving their
lot, it needed to be flavored. But from ranch to refrigerator,
almost everything has changed about meat and the way it is treated
today. Everything, that is, except marination. By Eric Asimov.


   With recipes.


   WINE-MICROWAVE (New York) _ A new question is creeping into wine
service in New York: How do you want that cooked? For many years,
Americans have confounded the rest of the world by drinking their
white wines too cold and their red wines too warm. Sommeliers no
longer hesitate when diners ask that a luscious Corton-Charlemagne
be plunged into an ice bucket. They just do it. It's easy. Red wine
poses a different problem. If it arrives at the table with slight
chill, and the diners want it the temperature of a blood
transfusion _ fast _ the sommelier must resort to wiles, and the
wiliest wile of all, it turns out, is the microwave oven. By
William Grimes.

Florence Fabricant

results.content:
`BAREFOOT CONTESSA COOKBOOK': SHOELESS IN THE KITCHEN 



   Parties catered by Ina Garten of the Barefoot Contessa in East
Hampton, N.Y., are characterized by dauntingly lavish, artfully
arranged displays of vegetables, breads, fruit, cheeses and cakes.
But as her ``Barefoot Contessa Cookbook'' (Clarkson N. Potter,
$32.50) now reveals, the food from her shop could not be more
accessible.


   Aside from a few omissions, like the temperature for baking the
terrific chocolate buttercream cake, this is an excellent starter
cookbook, to set the novice on the path to successful dinners and
parties, especially looking toward summer. Bright photographs, by
Melanie Acevedo, show exactly how most of the food should look, and
illustrations show the differences between mincing, dicing,
julienne and chiffonade.


   The recipes are replete with nice little touches, like the black
sesame seeds garnishing the oil-glossed sugar snap peas, and
directions for roasting some of the tomatoes for the tomato-basil
soup. But with few exceptions, like the lobster pot pie, they are
not complicated.


   Whenever possible, Ms. Garten suggests shortcuts, advance
preparation and convenient substitutions, including canned and
frozen vegetables and prepared mayonnaise. Feel free to use
packaged puff pastry, and do not expect to have to bake your own
bread to re-create her food.


   Little notes accompany the recipes, elaborating on the
ingredients and techniques. The navel orange segments specified in
the pretty beet salad, for example, must be cut away from the
membrane, not merely separated as when eating an orange.


   All the dishes are designed for entertaining, whether it's
plying weekend guests with staggeringly rich scones for breakfast,
assembling an array of tasty dips to be scooped with endive leaves
for cocktails, making a big turkey meatloaf for more than one meal
or recycling extra grilled lemon chicken breasts into a salad.


   Most of the recipes serve six or more, and many will feed 10.
(That chocolate buttercream cake will serve up to 12; bake it at
350 degrees.)


   Want to dazzle your guests? Try the roasted whole boned salmon
with a fennel stuffing. It couldn't be easier, and it most
certainly will produce raves when served at a buffet or dinner for
10 to 15.


   BEETS WITH ORANGE VINAIGRETTE


   Adapted from ``The Barefoot Contessa Cookbook''


   Time: 1 1/2 hours


   3 bunches fresh beets


   Kosher salt


   2 navel oranges


   2 tablespoons raspberry vinegar


   2 tablespoons freshly squeezed orange juice


   3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil


   1/2 teaspoon sugar


   1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper


   1/2 cup finely diced red onion.


   1. Trim green tops from beets and place beets in large pot of
salted water. Bring to a boil and simmer uncovered about 1 hour, or
until just tender. Drain and set aside until cool enough to handle.


   2. Remove zest from oranges, preferably in long strips. Slice
off the rest of the skin and all the pith. Holding the oranges over
a large bowl to catch any juice, use a sharp knife to cut the
segments out, away from the membrane.


   3. Peel and dice beets into 1/2-inch pieces. Add to bowl along
with vinegar, orange juice, olive oil, sugar, pepper, red onion,
orange zest and 1 1/2 teaspoons salt, or to taste. Mix well.


   4. Check seasonings and serve cold or at room temperature. Salad
may be left to marinate in refrigerator a day or more.


   Yield: 6 to 8 servings.

results.content:
1998-05-08 
 Green Vegetables Becoming a greater Part of Tibetans' Diet 


LHASA, May 8 (Xinhua) -- A revolution is quietly taking
place on the dinner tables of an old ethnic group living on
China's Tibetan Plateau, as green vegetables enter their lives.


Tibetans used to get by only on zanba (roasted qingke barley
flour), beef, mutton, and butter tea, and humorously referred to
vegetables as "grass", a food of the Han, but they're now getting
used to the taste of "grass."


A primary school teacher in Lhasa, Gaisang Zhoima, says that
her family is now much more interested in vegetables than beef and
mutton and that they even feel odd if a meal comes without
vegetables. She says they usually have zanba and butter tea for
breakfast, rice, fried vegetables, and meat for lunch, and noodles
or steamed buns with beef or mutton filling for supper.


Then, on weekends and holidays, she is often busy cooking sea
food and vegetables. "We didn't have much knowledge of nutrition
in the past," she explains, "but with the increasing contacts with
people outside the region, we Tibetans are paying more attention
to a variety of food." And, what is more important, she says,
almost any vegetable can now be found in Lhasa.


Since the beginning of the 1980s, the government of the Tibetan
Autonomous Region has had policies encouraging people to produce
vegetables.


Tibet now has 10 large vegetable centers, with Lhasa, the
capital, at the center, with a total of 1,200 ha of land that
produce nearly 100 million kg of vegetables each year.


They satisfy 90 percent of the local demand for vegetables,
which have grown 10 percent in popularity each year, among both
urban and rural people, in recent years.


Some other fresh vegetables and seafoods are regularly shipped
to the region.

results.content:
THREE AND A HALF HOURS TO FRANCE, BY CAR 



   MALTA RIDGE, N.Y. _ As Route 9 shoots southward from Saratoga
Springs, the grand Victorian mansions of the old spa yield to the
familiar outposts of American road culture.


   There are gas stations and convenience stores, a vegetable
stand, a lawn-ornament emporium, a drive-in barbecue joint with
picnic tables, and the rusticated cabins of the Thorobred Motel. It
takes a sharp eye to pick out, on the left, the silver diner with
the small rooftop sign: Chez Sophie Bistro.


   The motorist who whizzes by in the afternoon is entitled to feel
a twinge of pity. That empty parking lot. That lonely diner. And
just think of the misguided idealists who thought they could sell
French food out in the wilderness.


   But as dusk approaches, car after car takes a sharp left turn
into Sophie's. By 7, the lot is full, and so is the restaurant.


   What they have found is a tiny bit of France 3,500 miles from
Paris, the neighborhood bistro that every New Yorker dreams of _
located, unfortunately, in a neighborhood that takes three and a
half hours to reach by car.


   Chez Sophie is worth the drive. For nearly 30 years, it has been
serving classic bistro dishes, the kind of deceptively simple food
that, for the French, makes life worth living.


   In that time, the menu, printed on a mimeographed sheet of
paper, has scarcely budged. The customers won't let it. They want
the caneton a la Sophie, tender slices of duck breast in a sweetly
piquant apricot and green pepper sauce. They demand the veal
scallops in a cream and lemon sauce.


   Up and down the Hudson, innkeepers and new-wave restaurateurs
have made giant strides raising the region's culinary standards
over the past decade. But Chez Sophie has been there all along,
with a single cook in the kitchen turning out one flawless dish
after another.


   Yes, there is a Sophie. She is French, despite her all-American
last name (Parker), and six nights a week she serves 40 to 50 meals
to customers who, in many cases, have eaten at the restaurant more
than 100 times. At the age of 73, she rules over a kitchen staff of
precisely two, not counting the dishwashers.


   Her husband, Joseph, takes reservations, greets and seats and
keeps the diners happy. Her son, Paul, waits on tables and buys the
food and wine.


   Bill and Kimberley Comiskey from nearby Malta eat at Sophie's
every Friday night, in the same booth. They have done so ever since
the restaurant moved to the diner about three years ago. That adds
up to more than 150 meals, but the actual total runs much higher,
because they come with friends on other nights and celebrate at
Sophie's on special occasions.


   ``This is the place we compare others to,'' said Ms. Comiskey,
who operates a day spa in Latham. ``It's our benchmark.''


   Mrs. Parker herself makes very limited claims for the place.


   ``I do very simple things, actually,'' she said, seated at a
front booth in her chef whites early one afternoon, before the
day's cooking got under way. ``I don't even think of it as French,
really, I just think of it as good food.''


   In a way, the modesty is understandable. Chez Sophie cruises
along with a set menu of seven appetizers, eight main courses (plus
a fish and pasta of the day), and seven desserts. The wine list
fits on two sides of a piece of typewriter paper: 39 whites on one
side, 38 reds on the other.


   There's a nice list of Belgian beers. The appetizers are priced
from $4.50 to $10, the entrees from $21 to $29.


   The offerings are pre-nouvelle: country pate, escargots in
butter and garlic, roasted poussin, steak with peppercorn sauce,
chocolate mousse. There are a few contemporary touches, like a veal
chop roasted with portobello and shiitake mushrooms, and quail in a
currant sauce enlivened with balsamic vinegar, but that's as wild
as things get.


   Within tight, traditional limits, however, Chez Sophie makes

results.content:
1999-10-16 
 Organic Food for a Healthier Life (1) 


YANTAI, October 16 (Xinhua) -- Known as the Chinese "vegetable
basket" with an annual vegetable business of 2.8 billion kilograms,
Shouguang city of east China's Shandong province will boost the
development of its organic vegetable industry to tempt health-
conscious consumers.


Representatives from Shouguang who are attending the
International Symposium and Exhibition on Fruit\Vegetable
Processing and Industrialization here have been seeking overseas
partners for organic vegetable production.


Xue Yanbin, assistant mayor of the city, said that though the
vegetables in Shouguang are well-known in China, the city should
strive to develop higher quality and healthier vegetables for
market sales so as to remain competitive in the next century.


Lin Yun, a businesswoman from the Yantai fruit wholesale market,
said, "Organic veggies are a little bit more expensive, but they
haven't been sprayed by chemicals and are good for the health.
More and more people would rather buy this kind of vegetable."


Liu Lianfu, chairman of China Organic Food Society who is
attending the ongoing symposium, said the popularity of organic
vegetables among Chinese consumers may be attributed to the fact
that fruit and vegetables are easily polluted with chemical sprays,
and the Chinese know it.


With China's improved living standard, Chinese people are
becoming more aware of the importance of a healthy lifestyle as
well as the need for environmental protection, and organic food
will thus have a special attraction, Liu said.

&HT;   



   After a winter of stews, roasts and heavy soups, this may be the
perfect time to dust off that wok and get into some serious
stir-fry. Piles of crunchy, colorful vegetables paired with savory
bits of marinated meat or fish can be just the thing to brighten a
tired culinary routine and segue into the salad days of summer.


   The wok was part of Chinese cooking for 3,000 years before it
managed to show up as something ``new'' in American kitchens just a
few decades ago.


   Many Americans recognized stir-frying and the wok as an ideal
way to deliver fast, low-fat, economical and tasty meals and
embraced it as a regular part of their at-home menus. For others,
it never quite took hold.


   Of course, you don't need a wok to produce great stir-fry; a
large frying pan will do. But using a wok adds greatly to the
esthetics of the process, and it comes down to being just plain
fun. There is, however, some basic information you need to know for
successfully using a wok and stir-frying.


   If you've never used a wok or want to add to what you already
know, a few minutes on the Internet can go a long way toward a
great season of stir-frying.


   &QR;  The ``Art of Stir Fry'' at www.ivillage.com


   /food/articles/0,3035,3252(tilde)70,00

of stir-frying, plus recipes.


   &QR;  At ``Wok Around the Clock'' at recipes.wenzel


   .net/h/howt(tilde)xv.htm you will find stir-fry lessons that
suggest you tie a tea towel around your head while stir-frying and
make noise like a samurai warrior.

successful stir-fry cook and the care and feeding of a wok see
soar.berkeley.edu


   /recipes/hints/stir-fry1.html.


   &QR;  Take a lesson in using a wok, chat with other cooks at ``Wok
Talk'' and delve into about 4,000 Asian stir-fry recipes at
www.chopstix.co.uk.


   &QR;  Other sites include ``A Stirring Site'' at
www.cookinglight.com/food/focus/focus.html and information on how
to season a wok at www.artattak.com/ctips/curewok.html.


   Once you get the basics of the process, the fun is just
beginning.


   If you think that stir-frying in a wok limits you to Asian
dishes, think again. Search ``stir-fry recipes'' and you will find
pages and pages of single recipes offering an unlimited choice of
dishes from all over the world using every possible ingredient with
maximum creativity.


   Just nibbling around the edges we found:


   &QR;  Italian stir-fry using chicken, olives, artichokes and

south of the border.

   &QR;  Call up www.ilovepasta.org and search ``stir-fry'' for 10

   &QR;  Kosher stir-fry? You bet. See www.kashrus

results.content:
&HT;      


 &UR;  &QL;  &LR; 
 &UR; SAN FRANCISCO _ &LR;  Bay Area grocery stores are making it possible for
us to cook quickly without having to resort to frozen or heavily
processed foods. With all of the freshly prepared foods _ fresh
salsa, cleaned and deveined shrimp, prewashed salad mixes and
smoked tofu, just to name a few _ why not take advantage?

   However, some pre-prepared foods are better than others. Many
commercial pestos, for instance, have lost their fresh herbal
flavor by the time you get them.


   The trick is to find the best products. Pasta Etc. brand pesto,
made in Sonoma, has no cheese or oil and is flavored with miso.
That may not sound like pesto at all, but its bright basil flavor
works very well in this week's Fast & Fresh recipe.


   The recipe is simple but elegant enough for a dinner party
because of the way it looks _ luscious pink salmon atop golden
couscous, accented with green basil sauce. Quick pan-frying gives
the fillets a crisp crust and moist interior, and the pesto sauce,
mixed with lemon juice, cuts through the richness of the fish.


   Another excellent prepared product is achiote paste. Widely used
in Mexico's Yucatan region, this seasoning base is made of ground
annatto seeds, spices, vinegar and sometimes garlic. Mixed with oil
and additional seasonings, achiote is an instant marinade that
gives intense flavor and an appealing saffron-red color to meat and
fish.


   In this week's 30-minute recipe, chicken breasts are marinated
in achiote, then quickly broiled. The chicken is placed on top of a
salad of crisp jicama and arugula dressed with lime juice and a
touch of cayenne, bringing the vibrant marinade to life.


   Like all lasagnas, the Now & Later recipe, Lentil and Butternut
Squash Lasagna, involves many steps. But it's worth every minute
you spend behind the stove.


   A vegetarian dish created by my non-meat-eating friend
Elisabeth, the lasagna brings together butternut squash, roasted
until creamy, with firm French lentils and intensely sweet
caramelized onions. A rich b &LR; e &LR; chamel sauce makes the layers float
on top of each other like clouds.


   When making a many-stepped recipe like Lentil and Butternut
Squash Lasagna, do all the prep work ahead of time. Chop the
vegetables and herbs, measure the liquids and grate the cheese
before you start cooking. Being organized allows you to cook many
things at once instead of trying to chop while minding something on
the stove.


   If you like, break up the preparation by cooking the b &LR; e &LR; chamel
and vegetables ahead of time, then layering the lasagna the next
day. To reheat b &LR; e &LR; chamel, add a bit more milk and heat it slowly,
stirring constantly. Do not allow it to boil.


   &QL; 
FAST & FRESH: dinner in about 20 minutes


   &LR;  &QL; 
 &LR; PAN-FRIED SALMON FILLETS WITH LEMON PESTO & COUSCOUS


   Ingredients:


   6 tablespoons prepared pesto sauce (see note)


   1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice


   1 (10-ounce) package instant couscous


   1/2 teaspoon salt + salt to taste


   2 tablespoons + 1 teaspoon olive oil


   4 boned skinless salmon fillets, 5 to 6 ounces each and 1-inch
thick


   Freshly ground pepper to taste


   4 lemon wedges


   Instructions:


   If possible, let the pesto sit at room temperature for 20
minutes before beginning preparation.


   Mix together the pesto sauce and lemon juice. Set aside at room
temperature.


   Prepare the couscous according to package directions, adding 1/2
teaspoon salt and 1 teaspoon olive oil to the cooking water. Keep
warm while while you prepare the salmon.


   Season the salmon fillets on both sides with salt and pepper.
Heat a large nonstick skillet until quite hot. Add 1 tablespoon of
the olive oil and heat until almost smoking. Cook 2 salmon fillets
flesh-side down over medium-high heat until crispy on the bottom,
about 2 minutes.


   Turn the fillets and cook an additional 2 minutes. The fish
should be tender in the middle and crispy outside. Remove the
fillets from the pan and keep warm.

results.content:
VALLEY MAN'S MILITARY CAREER OVER



   LOS ANGELES _ Instead of celebrating Independence Day at a
Hawaii military base, a former U.S. Marine spent the holiday at his
Los Angeles home over the weekend after being discharged for
refusing to take the controversial anthrax vaccine.


   Pvt. Roman J. Lezo had been one of the first Marines to face a
court-martial prosecution in a small but growing armed services
protest. But military officials in Kaneohe, Hawaii, instead offered
him a discharge under ``other than honorable circumstances.''


   ``I am proud on this day for every American and I was proud to
serve as a Marine, but I have no regrets about what happened,''
said Lezo, 20, who pleaded guilty last month to disobeying the
order to take the shot. ``They are losing some of the best Marines
over this because they are ... taking their health as their first
priority.''


   Lezo was one of 14 Marines in Hawaii who refused to take the
series of six shots, base officials said. More than 200 troops, who
believe the drug is not properly tested and can cause long-term
health problems, have chosen punishment or resignation rather than
take the vaccine, according to Pentagon officials.


   ``He is finally out of the clutches of the Military-Industrial
Complex,'' said Lezo's mother, Roberta Lezo. ``We are ecstatic to
have him home.''


   Rather than face six months in jail, loss of two-thirds of his
pay and a dishonorable discharge with a felony on his record, Lezo
opted to avoid a trial and admit guilt for disobeying an order.


   But because of his discharge, he has lost all of his military
benefits, including his right to the GI Bill, which would have
guaranteed him $15,000 for college.


   ``My health was my No. 1 concern. Nobody wanted to take these
shots,'' Lezo said. ``They are trying to push this shot on people
and it's not right.


   ``It's a shame it had to come to this.''


   Anthrax is a bacterium that can be used as a biological warfare
agent _ one of the deadliest ever developed _ with a 90 percent
fatality rate if left untreated.


   Since the Food and Drug Administration approved the vaccine in
the 1970s, no long-term effects have been reported, said Virginia
Stephanakis, spokeswoman for the Army Surgeon General's Office at
the Pentagon. As of July 1, only 70 of the 303,000 vaccinated
troops have suffered side effects, Stephanakis said.


   Other Marines like Lezo have suffered greater consequences for
refusing the vaccine.


   Most recently, three Marines were court-martialed June 23 with
two others facing charges at Twentynine Palms Ground Combat Center
in the Mojave Desert.


   Six Marines based at the Miramar Marine Corps Air Station and
Camp Pendleton also are facing courts-martial for refusing to take
the mandatory shots.


   During his ordeal, Lezo said he was berated and sometimes
threatened by military officials.


   ``They would tell me that I was risking the lives of the entire
squad, and they warned me that if I didn't take it I would be
convicted and not be able to get a job even at McDonald's,'' Lezo
said.


   Lezo was charged with disobeying a lawful order from a
commanding officer and dereliction of duty. He also faced a charge
of failure to obey an order from a noncommanding officer, which was
not related to the anthrax case.


   Once a lance corporal with a secret security clearance, Lezo had
been demoted, given extra duties, confined to his barracks and lost
half of his pay prior to his discharge.


   The ex-Marine who was a helicopter mechanic is planning to
enroll in college in the fall and hopes to become a commercial
airline pilot. But in the meantime he is looking for work in the
aeronautics industry.


   ``It's time to start my life over,'' he said.


   And on this Independence Day, he spent the evening at a barbecue
with old friends.


   ``It's good to be home,'' he said.


   X X X &QL;

results.content:
THE APPETITE WAITS FOR NO BIRD 



   Probably the most challenging part of cooking Thanksgiving
dinner is deciding what to serve until the turkey is carved. You
need some kind of diversionary starter for everyone to nibble at
while the lumps are being mashed out of the potatoes and whisked
out of the gravy, but it can't be anything really rich or heavy or
filling, or no one will ever make it to the pumpkin pie.


   And it certainly can't be anything that takes more than a few
ingredients and a couple of steps to assemble on a day when even
the best cook feels overwhelmed.


   You could just go out and buy a few sneaky convenience foods,
but the flavors would seem off before a meal that celebrates real
home cooking. A better way to give the appearance of being a
generous and caring cook without becoming a galley slave is to
choose from some quick, simple and surprisingly different starters
based on ideas borrowed from classic hors d'oeuvres.


   Only one of these takes more than 15 minutes of work, most of
them far less. They are all familiar enough to serve to
unadventurous relatives on this all-American holiday, but each one
has a little twist.


   Perhaps my favorite is real onion dip, ideally served with
potato chips but almost as good with calorie-deficient raw
vegetables. Ever since Lipton took over the supermarket aisle,
onion dip has been routinely made with powdered onion soup mix.
Even in cookbooks you find recipes like, ``Stir 3 tablespoons onion
soup mix into 1 cup sour cream.'' There had to be a way to make it
simple without opening up a packet full of mystery ingredients.


   It seemed to me that the original idea was to imitate the
dominant flavor of onion soup _ caramelized onions _ so I tried
doing exactly that. I minced some onions, cooked them in oil until
they were well browned and then stirred them into sour cream.


   It was a fresh, three-ingredient dip (if you count the oil,
which you drain), with clarity, intensity and complexity of flavor.
(You can make and serve this right away, but the onion taste
intensifies if you allow it to sit, refrigerated, for about a day.)


   Similarly, I decided I could improve on the standard recipe for
shrimp cocktail sauce, which I always found thin and uninspired.
Without departing too far from the original, made with Heinz chili
sauce, I came up with a richer, tastier cocktail sauce by borrowing
an idea from the famed French chef Joel Robuchon, who adds a little
butter.


   That not only makes the sauce cling to the shrimp better, but
makes it taste equally good warm or cold. (I like it warm, just as
a contrast to the cold shrimp.)


   Three other Thanksgiving tidbits I developed are even easier,
starting with marinated olives. All you have to do is toss a
variety of olives in olive oil, garlic and herbs; let them stand an
hour; then stand back while guests ask incredulously, ``What did
you do with these?''


   The addition of a fragrant, tangy lemon cut into segments makes
them even more special. But the real key is to use an assortment of
good olives, preferably the kind produced in France, Italy, Greece
or Spain and sold in bulk.


   If possible, include some oil-cured olives, which really come to
life when marinated. You can marinate the olives up to a week in
advance if you like.


   The unusually warm fall this year inspired another super-simple
appetizer. Fresh figs are still in produce markets _ and still
ripening in California _ and they can be halved and stuffed with
any creamy, flavorful cheese. Usually I rely on a good blue, but
creamy goat cheese, drizzled with balsamic vinegar, is more
crowd-pleasing.


   Finally, I wanted a simple, light dipping sauce for raw
vegetables, so I warmed olive oil with garlic, freshened the mix
with uncooked olive oil, seasoned it with lots of salt and pepper
and spiked it with lemon rind. The flavors go great with fennel,
one of the easiest of vegetables to convert into crudites.


   Just trim the bulb by cutting off the bottom half-inch or so,
then stand it up on its flat end and slice downward to ma
