results.content:
VEGGIES SIZZLE ON THE GRILL



   Grilling and backyard barbecues most often conjure up images of
sizzling steaks, burgers, chicken or fish.


   But has it ever crossed your mind to toss a colorful array of
fresh vegetables on the grill? If not, you'll be amazed at how
simple, healthy and fabulous tasting grilled produce can be.


   ``Most vegetables cook beautifully on the grill with just a
minimum of preparation or attention,'' notes Kelly McCune in her
``Vegetables on the Grill'' cookbook.


   ``We have been encouraging people to cook an entire meal on the
grill for years, and finally people are coming around,'' says Betty
Hughes, consumer affairs director for Weber-Stephen Products Co.,
the company that manufactures Weber grills. ``People are really
missing out if they don't do vegetables on the grill.''


   Grilling vegetables heightens their natural sweetness resulting
in a fabulous smoky, carmelized flavor that is very different from
those that are steamed, microwaved or boiled.


   The smoky flavor is derived from the juices from the vegetables
dropping down on the grill's heat source and thus cooking and
carmelizing the sugars in the vegetables, says Hughes. ``You'll get
the same smoky flavor whether you use a gas or charcoal grill.''


   For more of a wood flavor add flavored wood chips to a gas
grill, advises Hughes. Simply place wet chips in a small foil pan
and put the pan in the hottest area of the grill underneath the
cooking grates, which in Weber gas grills is in the front left hand
corner. Don't place the food directly above the chips to avoid a
flare up or a fire.


   Experiment and learn what works best on your grill. Here are
some tips for success _ gleaned from experts and our hands-on
experience:


   Vegetables are easiest to manage and hold their shape best when
grilled in larger pieces. For instance, cut zucchini and eggplant
(either Japanese or regular) into lengthwise slices rather than
small pieces. Tomatoes are best grilled halved rather than in
slices or quarters. Same goes for red, white or yellow onions and
red, green or yellow bell peppers. Asparagus, mushrooms and green
onions should be left whole.


   To keep asparagus spears from falling through the cooking
grates, use thicker spears or tie thinner spears together into
bundles of five or six spears with plain kitchen twine.


   There are several ways to grill corn on the cob. You can soak
the husks in water for an hour and then place them on the grill or
cook in the husks without soaking. Unlike other veggies, corn needs
to be turned often when grilling. If desired, a couple of minutes
before serving, peel back the husks to get a little brown color and
grill marks on the corn, along with some additional smoky flavor.


   For best results and fastest cooking, be sure the grill is very
hot before adding the vegetables of your choice, emphasizes Hughes.
Start a charcoal grill 30 minutes in advance of cooking or preheat
a gas grill for 10 to 15 minutes.


   The simplest and best way to grill vegetables is to brush them
all over with olive or vegetable oil, and place on the grill. No
blanching needed.


   While we prefer to season with salt and garlic or regular pepper
after grilling, some cooks like to toss the vegetables with oil,
salt and pepper prior to grilling. Don't bother to marinate
vegetables before grilling as they don't absorb much, if any,
marinade.


   For more flavor _ after grilling _ drizzle the produce with
herb-flavored oils, dressings or marinades and fresh herbs, but go
easy so the clean sweet flavors of the vegetables dominate. Hughes
likes to add bottled vinaigrette dressing to a platter of grilled
vegetables before serving as a side dish.


   Be sure the cooking grates are clean before you grill, notes
Lisa Hanauer, an Oakland-based food writer and former chef
restaurateur, who loves grilling vegetables and shares her
corn-on-the cob grilling tricks in the September issue of Taunton's
Fine Cooking magazine.


   Although grill experts have differing opinions, we found wiping
the cooking grates light

results.content:
1999-09-05 11:17:53 
 usa 
 Chips, Fries Big Part of Kids' Diet 


	NEW ORLEANS (AP) -- Kids aren't fat just because they're couch  
potatoes, but because they stuff themselves with mountains of 
potatoes cooked the least healthy way, a researcher says. 


	Potato chips and French fries make up more than one-quarter of  
the vegetable servings eaten by children, and nearly one-third of 
the veggies eaten by teen-agers, according to a survey compiled by 
Catherine Champagne of LSU's Pennington Biomedical Research 
Institute. 


	It's not surprising, considering the number of people who jam  
mall food courts and burger joints, said Champagne, who calculated 
the information from USDA annual surveys for 1994-96. 


	``It just sort of confirmed what I suspected -- that for some  
people the only way they get vegetables might be in this form. And 
that's really sad,'' she said. 


	Champagne, an associate research professor at Pennington and a  
registered dietitian, used the U.S. Department of Agriculture's 
Continuing Survey of Food Intakes by Individuals. 


	That survey's database translates each kind of food into food  
pyramid servings. For instance, French fries are both vegetable and 
fat. A superdeluxe pizza includes bread, fat, cheese, meat, and 
vegetables. 


	The USDA defines a serving of vegetables as 1 cup of raw leafy  
vegetables, a half- cup of other vegetables, or 3/4 cup of vegetable 
juice. 


	Champagne looked at the total figures for vegetables, then  
checked for fries and chips, and worked out what percentage they 
made up of the total. She presented her findings at a conference 
sponsored by the National Institutes of Health and others at Emory 
University. 


	She found that even children younger than 7 years old got 27.3  
percent of their vegetables as fries and chips. The figure rose to 
28.9 percent for children aged 7 to 12, 31.2 percent for those aged 
13 to 18 -- and 40 percent for black teens. 


	``Why do I find that not surprising, when one-fourth of the  
breakfasts eaten by adults in the United States are eaten at 
McDonalds?'' said Dr. Harold Solomon, a childhood obesity 
specialist at Beth Israel-Deaconess Hospital and an associate 
professor at Harvard. 


	Bonnie Liebman of the Center for Science in the Public Interest  
uses snacks to get her own three children to eat more fruits and 
vegetables. 


	``In the late afternoon, they're starving. I'll cut up carrots,  
red peppers, maybe give them a little dressing to dip it in, and 
put it next to them while they're doing their homework. It's 
usually gone by dinner,'' she said. 


	``It's too bad our culture says you should eat junk between  
meals.'' 


	The USDA's data is solid and Champagne's approach sounds  
reasonable, said Michael Goran, a professor of preventive medicine 
at the University of Southern California and a specialist in 
childhood obesity. 


	``I think it's very sound,'' said American Dietetic Association  
spokeswoman Jackie Berning, an assistant professor at the 
University of Colorado in Colorado Springs.

&HT;    
 &HT;   



   It's time to take summertime global and experiment with the
grilling traditions of the world. And there's no better way to do
it than with a kebab sampling.


   You can make the portions on each kebab as small or as large as
you'd like. And feel free to create your own combinations, pairing
favorite meats with preferred veggies or even fruits, like prunes,
figs, apricots and peaches.


   There are really only a few rules to keep in mind. It's good if
you can intersperse lean meat cubes with fatty, and cut pieces
about the same size so they will cook evenly. When using different
vegetables on the same skewer, make sure they have similar cooking
times; longer-cooking vegetables may be blanched first to start the
cooking.


   Experiment with different skewers, metal or wood. You can
usually find economical versions at grocery and discount stores.
The latest Williams-Sonoma catalog offers stainless steel skewers
adorned with brass handles in the shape of animals. A set of six is
$15.


   If you use wood skewers, soak them in water for about an hour
before using to keep them from burning while on the grill. You can
also wrap the ends in foil. It's also a good idea to grease the
grilling grate generously to prevent sticking.


   One trick: Use a kebab rack. These stand about 2 inches high,
and you place the skewers on top so they are just above the grate,
but not touching it. We spotted one at Stein Mart for $14.99.


   Finally, the last trick to kebabs is the unskewering. As he
traveled the world sampling kebabs, cookbook author Steven Raichlen
discovered the best way to handle this dilemma.


   He suggests holding a skewer with one hand, and then, with a
piece of thick bread in the other, pull the meat toward you a bit
to loosen; everything should just slide off.


   Below, we give you a few of the international recipes Raichlen
discovered while working on ``The Barbecue! Bible'' (Workman
Publishing, $18.95) plus some others we tried.


   MAIN DISH


   Madeira Beef and Bay Leaf Kebabs (Espetada)


   Makes 4 servings Preparation time: 20 minutes Marinating time:
4-6 hours Cooking time: 8-12 minutes


   Grilled beef is popular throughout Portugal, but on the island
of Madeira, this kebab is the favorite. It used to be cooked
directly on branches from bay leaf trees. Here, we stick with the
leaves. Steven Raichlen recommends serving with crusty bread for
soaking up the juices as shown below.


   1 1/2pounds beef tenderloin or boneless sirloin


   1/4cup extra-virgin olive oil


   1/4cup red wine vinegar


   1onion, finely chopped


   1/2cup chopped fresh Italian (flat-leaf) parsley


   4cloves garlic, finely chopped


   1teaspoon salt


   1teaspoon freshly ground black pepper


   12bay leaves


   Trim any sinews and excess fat off the beef, then cut the meat
into 1 1/2-inch cubes. Combine the olive oil, vinegar, onion,
parsley, garlic, salt and pepper in a large nonreactive baking
dish. Add the beef and toss thoroughly to coat. Cover and let
marinate in the refrigerator for 4 to 6 hours.


   Preheat the grill to high. Remove the beef and bay leaves from
the marinade and thread onto the skewers, dividing the bay leaves
among the kebabs. When ready to cook, oil the grill grate. Arrange
the kebabs on the hot grate and grill, turning with tongs, until
the meat is cooked to taste, 2 to 3 minutes per side (8 to 12
minutes in all) for medium-rare. Baste the espetadas with any
excess marinade, but not during the last 3 minutes. Serve the
espetadas on or off the skewers on slices or chunks of Portuguese
bread for soaking up the juices.


   Per serving: 273 calories, 32 grams protein, 15 grams fat
(percent calories from fat, 49) , 1 grams carbohydrate, 95
milligrams cholesterol, 371 milligrams sodium.


   MAIN DISH


   Oriental Chicken Kabobs


   Makes 4 servings


   Preparation time: 20 minutes Cooking time: 10-12 minutes


   Here is a light, flavorful kebab infused with some of our
favorite Asian tastes _ hoisin and ginger. The whole baby corns are
a nice touch.


   1 1/2pounds s

results.content:
1996-04-09 08:52 
 Coarse Food Grain, Wild Vegetables Favorite in Inner Mongolia 


HUHHOT, April 9 (Xinhua) -- Wild vegetables, corn, millet and
other coarse food grain have staged a comeback on the dinner
tables of many families in north China's Inner Mongolia after
disappearing for decades.


The price of a bag of 400-gram of millet averages five yuan in
capital city Huhhot, higher than the cost of the same amount of
fragrant rice imported from Thailand, or four times of domestic
rice. And there is no lack of buyers despite of the staggering
price.


Newly developed semi-finished food made of corn flour, buck
wheat flour and oats have a ready market in many parts of the
region.


This indicates a change in people's mind on dietary habits and
a social progress, said a regional commercial official.


Reviewing the historical change, the official said, coarse food
grain served as the principal food in the region two or three
decades ago, accounts for 70 percent of the total food
supply. Each family used to save the limited supply of flour and
rice for children and the old in the 1970s and the annual per
capita consumption of meat was no more than five kg. Now the per
capita consumption of meat is more than 40 kg.


With living standards improving since China's economic reforms
which began in 1979, people gradually replaced wild vegetables
with high-grade varieties. Chicken, duck, meat and fish have
become popular in home cooking.


In recent years, people came to realize that coarse grain food
contains many nutritious ingredients. Digging wild vegetables on
the outskirts while people are holidaying has become a fashion
nowadays.

results.content:
LICORICE-FLAVORED VEGETABLE TAKES ROOT IN SOPHISTICATED COOKING



   It's celery with an attitude. An onion with a mane. Dill with
some weight on it.


   It's fennel _ the brightest bulb on the American food scene.


   New York City caterer-to-the-stars Pamela Morgan has several
recipes for the licorice-flavored vegetable in her just-published
``Flavors.''


   ``It's so fresh and crisp,'' she says, ``and you can use the
tops for garnish. And it's available just about year-round.''


   Indeed. You can use the whole plant, from the bulb to the
feathery fronds to the seeds. It's three, three, three foods in
one.


   Long a staple in Mediterranean cuisines, fennel has made its way
to the heartland of America. And the newest cookbooks are brimming
with the discovery.


   Morgan offers an olive melange with fennel seeds, and low-fat
tuna and fennel salad pitas. Steven Raichlen stuffs the bulb into
sea bass in ``The Barbecue! Bible.'' Raichlen also dries the stalks
and throws them on the fire to perfume the smoke. James Peterson
even deep-fries fennel in his just-published ``Vegetables.''


   Fennel's natural season is fall through late spring, but with
the miracle of modern supermarkets and importing, it's available
all year. Which is good, because the clean, crisp flavor is a
welcome summer taste.


   Sometimes labeled ``anise,'' larger bulbs will probably be
fibrous and should be peeled with a vegetable peeler. To maintain
crispness, don't cut up fennel until ready to prepare.


   COLD RED PEPPER AND FENNEL SOUP WITH SUMMER HERBS


   Serves 8 as first course, 4 as main course


   1/4 cup olive oil


   6 large red bell peppers (about 2 1/3 pounds), roasted, peeled
and chopped


   4 cups chopped fresh fennel


   2 cups chopped yellow onion


   2 cups chopped carrot


   1 1/2 cups chopped leeks (2 medium leeks, white and pale green
parts only)


   2 tablespoons minced fresh thyme


   3 garlic cloves, peeled and chopped


   1 teaspoon fennel seeds


   2 bay leaves


   5 cups chicken stock or reduced-sodium canned chicken broth


   1/2 cup medium-dry white wine


   2 tablespoons Pernod


   Salt and freshly ground black pepper


   2 tablespoons roughly chopped fresh basil


   2 tablespoons roughly chopped flat-leaf parsley


   2 tablespoons roughly chopped chervil


   In a medium-large pot over low heat, warm the olive oil. Add
chopped peppers, fennel, onion, carrot, leeks, thyme, garlic,
fennel seeds and bay leaves. Cover and cook, stirring occasionally,
until vegetables are almost tender, about 20 minutes. Add chicken
stock, wine, Pernod and 1 tablespoon salt. Bring to a simmer,
partially cover and cook, stirring occasionally, until vegetables
are very tender, about 30 minutes.


   Cool soup and remove bay leaves. Puree soup in batches in food
processor or blender, or force it through the medium blade of a
food mill. Refrigerate until very cold, at least 5 hours or
preferably overnight.


   Adjust salt and season the soup generously with fresh black
pepper. Sprinkle basil, parsley and chervil over soup and serve
cold.


   Nutritional analysis per serving: 159 calories, 8 grams fat, 18
grams carbohydrates, 5 grams protein, trace cholesterol, 49
milligrams sodium, 48 percent of calories from fat.


   _ ``Flavors'' by Pamela Morgan (Viking, $29.95)


   _


   PROVENCAL PENNE


   Serves 4-6


   4 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil


   1 medium onion, minced


   2 plump, fresh garlic cloves, peeled and minced


   1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes, or to taste


   1 fresh bay leaf


   Sea salt, to taste (or kosher salt)


   1 fennel bulb (about 1/2 pound), trimmed and cut in matchsticks


   28-ounce can peeled Italian plum tomatoes in juice, or 28-ounce
can crushed tomatoes in puree


   Grated zest (orange peel) of 1 orange, preferably organic


   1 pound dried Italian tubular pasta, such as penne


   1/4 cup fresh flat-leaf parsley leaves, snipped with scissors


   In an unheated skillet large enough to hold the pasta later on,
combine oil, onion, garlic, red pepper flakes, bay l

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-03-29 02:10 
 New Soybean Oil Said Healthier  
By PHILIP BRASHER, AP Farm Writer


   WASHINGTON (AP) -- A new soybean developed by government
scientists yields oil that, once processed, has far less
heart-damaging fats and other substances than other cooking oils.


   The oil straight from the soybean has less than half the
saturated fat of conventional varieties. Also, it does not have to
go through a process that produces artery-clogging trans fatty
acids.


   Soybean oil is used in foods from margarine to crackers. Food
manufacturers are eager to find a healthier version, because the
Food and Drug Administration plans to require the listing of trans
fats on food nutrition labels.


   The soybean holds ''excellent potential'' for food makers and
''will provide the needed flexibility to be used in a wide variety
of products,'' the Institute of Shortening and Edible Oils, which
represents companies that process vegetable oils, said in a letter
to the United Soybean Board. The board helped fund the USDA
research.


   ''Just by changing the kind of oil that's used by food
manufacturers and restaurants would go a long way to reducing heart
disease in this country,'' Margo Wootan, director of nutritional
policy for the Center for Science in the Public Interest, said
Tuesday.


   Shoppers won't see the new product before next year at the
earliest, because the first commercial crop being planted next
month in North Carolina will be saved for seed and testing.


   The new soybean was developed by Agriculture Department
scientists in Raleigh, N.C., using conventional breeding methods
and not genetic engineering, which has become controversial in
Europe and Asia.


   More than 80 percent of the vegetable oil used in cooking and
food manufacturing comes from soybeans because of its relatively
low price and wide availability.


   But soybean oil cannot be used for cooking unless it is
hydrogenated to extend its shelf life and improve its flavor.
Hydrogenation, which also solidifies the oil, removes linolenic
acid, a substance that causes the oil to taste rancid when heated.
The new soybeans have a third as much linolenic acid as
conventional varieties.


   Pioneer Hi-Bred International, a unit of DuPont, has a soybean
with half as much linolenic acid as conventional soybeans. Unlike
the USDA soybean, however, the Pioneer variety isn't lower in
saturated fat.


   Hydrogenated oil would still be needed for some products, such
as baked goods, to give them the proper texture and body, but
manufacturers could blend in unhydrogenated oil to lower the
overall content of trans fat, industry experts say.


   Health experts say trans fatty acids may be even worse for the
heart than saturated fat, but consumers have no way of knowing how
much of it is in food.


   Margarine made from hydrogenated soybean oil now lists only the
saturated fat -- about 2 grams per serving -- and not the 3 grams of
trans fat. Three Nabisco's Chips Ahoy! cookies, for example, total
2 grams of saturated fat along with another 2 grams of trans fat.


   The FDA's labeling plan spurring the search for healthier
cooking oil would require the amount of trans fat in a footnote on
nutrition labels while adding the amount of saturated fat in the
usual listing.


   ''We want to do everything we can to avoid the labeling when it
comes,'' Jay Franklin, an Oklahoma soybean farmer, said Tuesday.


   About 1,000 acres of USDA's new soybean will be planted this
year, enough to produce seed for 50,000 acres in 2001, said Richard
Wilson, a scientist working on the project. Varieties with similar
traits are being bred for local growing conditions in nine other
states: Georgia, Indiana, Maryland, Minnesota, Missouri, Ohio,
South Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia.


   ------


   On the Net: USDA's Agricultural Research Service:
http://www.ars.usda.gov


   United Soybean Board site: http://www.unitedsoybean.org


 AP-NY-03-29-00 0210

results.content:
1998-10-30 
 Russian Minister Denies Threat of Famine 


MOSCOW, October 29 (Xinhua) -- Russian Food and Agriculture
Minister Viktor Semyonov said Thursday that Russia faces no threat
of famine despite a grain output that was about half of a year
ago.


"We see no reason for food shortages," Semyonov told a press
conference.


According to preliminary reports, Russia produced 47.3 million
tons of grain this year compared to 88.5 million in 1997.


Semyonov described media reports on food issues as an attempt
to create some advantages for imported foods in Russia, Interfax
reported.


The minister said Russia had stocked enough potatoes, sugar,
vegetable oil and vegetables and there were enough grain to meet
its basic needs, but it should create a reserve fund.


While acknowledging that 22 of Russia's 89 regions are
suffering from grain shortage, the minister said some 100 million
Russians are growing their own potatoes and vegetables, about 50
million Russians raise their own cattle, which represent a hedge
against food shortages.


The private sector in agriculture accounts for up to 90 percent
of the total output of potatoes, 76 percent of vegetables, 55
percent of meat and 47 percent of milk, Semyonov said.


"This is a serious stabilizing factor," he added.


"Russia as a whole has a sufficient amount of grain, but
reserves should be formed to rapidly stop local food shortages,"
Semyonov said. "We cannot afford to have such low harvests for two
years in succession."


On foreign food aid, the minister said, such assistance,
actively discussed by some international humanitarian
organizations, must not damage Russian food manufacturers.


He maintained that the current problem with food in Russia "is
not so much the shortage of supplies, but the fact that many
valuable foodstuffs, primarily meat and milk, have become less
affordable to many people because of the financial crisis."


In this sense humanitarian aid could be quite useful in some
areas for individual population groups and it is senseless
rejecting it, Semyonov said.


However, he said his ministry "is categorically opposed to
commodity interventions at dumping prices under the guise of
humanitarian aid," he said.


The ministry "will closely monitor the process to prevent
damage to local producers," Semyonov said.

results.content:
&HT;   



   People tend to be intimidated by sauces. Perhaps it's the
French, who have made their sauces a point of national pride and
aren't at all shy about telling the rest of the world. Or maybe
it's the sauciers, that culinary elite that gives the rest of us
the idea that sauces are beyond our reach. Whatever the source of
this inferiority complex, the truth is that sauces aren't all that
difficult to make.


   Consider that most sauces are made of just a very few basic
ingredients that most people already have on hand. Butter, flour or
other thickening agents, spices and maybe wine are the simple basis
for scores of sauces. Yes, there are blending and thickening
techniques that you'll have to master, but compared with some other
culinary procedures, those are fairly simple.


   Nothing can transform the ho-hum into the unforgettable more
quickly than a sauce. And to deprive your repertoire of sauces is
to miss out on one of the most creative things you can do in the
kitchen. Remember, too, that the French haven't cornered the market
on sauces. Nearly every nation and region in the world has a
signature sauce, making the creative opportunities nearly
unlimited.


   If you're moved to give up those powder-filled envelopes you've
been relying on to jazz up your cooking and are game to enter the
creative world of sauces, check out these World Wide Web sites for
an informative overview.


   &QR;  At www.gumbopages.com/food/sauces/ you will learn, in simple
language, about such things as ``mother sauces'' and their
derivatives. For example, you'll learn that hollandaise is the
mother of bearnaise, maltaise and mousseline. There are easy
instructions on thickening techniques and recipes.


   &QR;  Other sites at which to learn the basics of sauces and get
your vocabulary up to par are ``a compendium of sauces and dips''
at www.flavorweb.com/sauces.htm and a ``glossary of sauces and
condiments'' at azstarnet.webpoint.com/food/cksauces.htm


   worcestershire.


   &QR;  An article by Naomi Cutner at Homearts at food.homearts.com


   /cookings/basix/36basa16.htm takes the mystery out of those
French sauces by simply explaining the preparation of white sauces,
brown sauces, hollandaise, mayonnaise, gravy-type sauces and
vinaigrette _ the basic French sauces.


   &QR;  At www.cs.cmu.edu/(tilde)mjw/recipes/sauces/index.html you'll
find a mind-boggling index of sauces and marinades that will give
you an idea of just how many choices you have. From flavorful
Japanese dipping sauces to Greek gyro sauces to endless nuances of
our very own barbecue sauces, along with the full contingent of
French sauces, it's all there.


   &QR;  You didn't think Cyberspice had forgotten your homework
assignment, did you? See the Association of Dressings and Sauces
site at www.dressings-sauces.org/ for a history of dressings and
sauces. You'll learn that many authorities believe the first batch
of mayonnaise _ a mixture of egg yolks, oil and seasonings _ was
whipped up to celebrate the 1756 French capture of Mahon, a city on
the Spanish island of Minorca, by forces under Louis-Francois-Armad
de Vignerot du Plessis, duc de Richelieu. Boring, you say? Well,
get this: The duke, who was widely known as a bon vivant, had the
odd habit of inviting his guests to dine in the nude. Think about
that the next time you're spreading some Deep South on a BLT.


   CONDIMENT


   Spicy Barbecue Sauce


   Makes 3 cups Preparation time: 10 minutes Cooking time: 38
minutes


   This spicy, thick and chunky barbecue sauce works with
traditional grilled foods such as chicken, ribs or steak, and it's
also great on fish and grilled vegetables.


   1 tablespoon minced or pressed garlic


   1 large onion, finely chopped


   1 1/2 tablespoon olive oil


   1 (14-ounce) can crushed tomatoes


   1/3 cup tomato paste


   1/4 cup red wine vinegar


   1/4 cup Worcestershire sauce


   1 1/2 teaspoon hot sauce, or to taste


   1 bay leaf


   1 tablespoon dried oregano


   1/4 teaspoon crushed red


   pepper, or to taste


   1/2 teaspoon dried thyme

results.content:
&HT;    
 &HT;   



   WASHINGTON - Bryostatin-1, a potentially valuable anticancer
drug found in the gut of an obscure sea creature from a family of
animals known as bryozoans, has helped throw a monkey wrench into
efforts by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to ``renourish'' an
eroded Fort Pierce, Fla., beach.


   Nobody knows where bryostatin-1 comes from, whether from a
stringy little sea creature known as ``Bugula neritina'' or from
bacteria that live in the creature's stringy gut.


   But Bugula neritina's distant kinship to several species of
bryozoans discovered in sand the corps was dredging from the ocean
floor in the renourishment project was a factor in a federal
judge's decision to temporarily halt the Fort Pierce project.


   In granting a temporary restraining order sought by scientists
and south Florida environmental groups, Judge Henry Kennedy
specifically cited a court affidavit in which one of the plaintiffs
noted that Bugula neritina is a relative of the newly discovered
Florida bryozoans.


   In the document, bryozoan expert Judith E. Winston said she had
discovered 13 new species of the creatures in an area called Capron
Shoal, from which the corps has started dredging sand to use in
rebuilding Fort Worth's South Beach.


   ``The medicinal properties of the newly discovered bryozoans
have not yet been explored,'' said Winston. She added that if the
creatures were not protected, ``the opportunity to conduct such
research may be lost forever.''


   (optional trim follows)


   In an animal kingdom that includes such impressive creatures as
great whales, elephants and Florida alligators, bryozoans don't
ordinarily get a lot of attention. They just grow on sand, rocks,
boat bottoms and other supports in the sea -- and in some case, in
fresh water. They gulp down whatever nourishing micro-morsels
happen to float by.


   (optional trim ends)


   If the bryozoans discovered by Winston are unpopular with
officials of Florida's St. Lucie County, which was helping pay for
the beach restoration, hope and money ride on their California
cousin, Begula neritina, and the drug it has provided.


   Drug trials aimed at obtaining a Food and Drug Administration
license for bryostatin-1 are underway, and a southern California
marine biotechnology company, CalBioMarine Inc., says it has
perfected a technique of growing bryozoans by the ton.


   ``We just are waiting for call from a pharmaceutical company
that would contract with us to produce it,'' said Dominick Mendola,
president of CalBioMarine. ``We have developed a system for growing
them. We have tested it for many years, and it works.''


   Although contractors working for the National Cancer Institute's
Natural Products Branch, which sponsors searches for drugs in
obscure plants and marine creatures, have collected and sent in
samples of over 60,000 species for evaluation, only bryostatin-1
and a handful of other potential drugs have been identified.


   Naturalists at Arizona State University, a Natural Products
Branch grantee, found bryostatin-1 in Bugula neritina about 20
years ago. Since then the substance has survived a slow scientific
gauntlet and is now in ``Phase II'' FDA trials as an anticancer
drug.


   Mendola said that in addition to developing a technique whereby
bryozoans are ``seeded'' on perforated plastic plates and grown in
the ocean, his company is working to identify and transplant the
gene for bryostatin-1 in some type of easily grown bacteria in the
hope of producing great quantities of the substance.


   He said there is very little danger the bryozoans that produce
brytostatin-1 -- or harbor the bacteria that produce it -- ever
will be wiped out.


   `` They're everywhere,'' he said. ``You couldn't obliterate them
if you tried.''


   The company also operates a facility in the Florida Keys, where
it raises a type of sea squirt known as Ecteinascidia
turbinata,(cq) from which another potential anticancer drug is
being tested.


   (optional trim follows)


   Marine biologists from Fort Pierce's Harbor Branch Oceanographi

   The company also operates a facility in the Florida Keys, where
it raises a type of sea squirt known as Ecteinascidia
turbinata,(cq) from which another potential anticancer drug is
being tested.

results.content:
ADDING PROTEIN TO VEGETABLES  
 CARROT HOT DOGS 



   Cold Cuts, With Help From Cauliflower


   For those who find it difficult to eat enough vegetables,
Mitchell Hochman has patented a formula for cold cuts and hot dogs
that are made from fresh vegetables and low-fat meat.


   Hochman's family has run a meat-processing business for more
than 50 years, and he hoped to fill a void he saw between full-fat
meat and tofu or whey vegetarian products. He came up with a
formula for replacing the water commonly added to processed meats
with moisture from fresh vegetables like carrots, cauliflower,
broccoli and spinach. He named his venture ``Project 7099'' because
the vegetables he uses are 70 to 99 percent water.


   Hochman's patent calls for liquefying the vegetables and
blending the liquid with lean or low-fat meat. He recommends using
a one-to-four ratio of whole vegetables to meat. He then adds
spices, sweeteners and other flavorings, along with soy protein and
natural food colorings. The food is then formed into meat blocks
intended to resemble hot dogs or cold cuts like bologna.


   Hochman, who lives in New York City, wants to license his
invention to a major meat processing company. He won patent
5,766,667.


   Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and
Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

results.content:
FENNEL ADDS A LILT 



   A single vegetable brought to its essence _ that's the meaning
of summer soup. Winter soups, with their soothing richness and
warmth, tend to be a composition of ingredients _ beef-vegetable,
chicken-noodle, chowder, minestrone.


   But summer soups refresh rather than soothe. And with so many
vegetables hitting their peak of freshness, my first urge for
summer soups is to isolate each one and make it more than what it
is on the vine, to refine it to its purest form. (An exception is a
bright gazpacho, whose many flavors blend into a single taste.)


   The beauty of summer soups _ one main ingredient served hot or
cold _ is that they're so easy. Zucchini, spinach, tomato, bell
pepper: the less you change them, the better.


   The technique for all vegetables is the same; learn it and you
can transform any vegetable into an extraordinary summer soup,
whether it's pea or fennel, watercress or artichoke, tomato,
carrot, haricots verts or even a soup of fine herbs, tarragon,
chive, parsley and chervil.


   It's just a matter of cooking your vegetable, pureeing it in a
blender, adjusting the consistency with stock or water, seasoning
it, and straining. Some vegetables, like tomatoes and cucumbers,
don't need to be cooked.


   The principle is simple: separate the flavor and color from what
contains it, the cellulose. The tool that separates it is the
chinois.


   The chinois, a fine-meshed conical sieve, is critical to these
soups. It creates the texture of luxury. The chinois combines
layers of fine mesh that catch even the smallest particles of
fiber, producing a finely textured liquid that feels like silk or
satin. Certainly, you could heat your puree and serve it without
straining, or you might pass it through a food mill and then
through a strainer. But again, when you're looking for an essence
of something, you must remove all the extraneous vegetable fiber
that has no flavor.


   My thinking about soups is so similar to my approach to sauces
that I always wonder, is sauce a soup or is soup a sauce? Which
came first? If it's a great summer soup, it can be a great sauce,
too. And vice versa. Sometimes we'll make a sauce that tastes so
good, we decide to put it in a cup and call it soup.


   Soups are the most chameleonlike dishes. They can be served at
any point during the meal _ as a canape, a first course, the
perfect intermezzo, a dessert canape, the dessert or a sauce.


   My favorite way is as opening canapes _ two or three spoonfuls
of intense flavor presented in small white bowls before the meal
begins. A canape soup excites the senses and prepares you for the
meal ahead. And these summer soups make the very best canapes,
because they focus on a single flavor. One sip of carrot soup
should be as powerful in flavor as a mouthful of carrots.


   Elements of finesse make a big difference. And cooking the
vegetable well is one of them. All green vegetables should be
cooked in so much water that the water does not lose its boil,
water that has a cup of salt for every gallon, and the cooked
vegetable must immediately be shocked in ice water. This big-pot
blanching and chilling insures the brightest green possible.


   Root vegetables and red and yellow bell peppers are simmered in
a small amount of stock or cream, then blended.


   Another element of finesse is introducing some sort of fat _
cream or oil _ to enrich the flavor and add body, although some
vegetables, like cucumber and sorrel, require no fat. Perhaps
you'll also want an acid like sherry or balsamic vinegar.


   Some vegetables benefit from a secondary component (add a little
blanched dill to the cucumber puree for cucumber soup, for
instance). But ultimately, the great summer soup is a single cooked
vegetable pureed and strained through a chinois.


   Gazpacho is the perfect warm-weather soup, and the
interpretation I offer here is intense, and easy. The main
technique is turning on your blender, and then straining the
liquid. The flavor is extraordinary because you're using fresh
ingredients _ cucumbers, onion,

results.content:
1999-12-15 
 Better Food Supply Guaranteed in Macao After Handover 


ZHUHAI, December 15 (Xinhua) -- By 7 a.m. every morning,
truckloads of live pigs, cattle, poultry and fresh vegetables
converge at the Gongbei Customs checkpoint of Zhuhai, the nearest
mainland city to Macao.


Many of the trucks bear the emblem of Doumen Foodstuffs Import
and Export Corporation of Zhuhai, which operates many production
bases that specialize in providing non-staple food supplies to
Macao.


Yang Yifan, deputy general manager of Doumen, said his company
has been responsible for bringing market supplies in Macao for
years, and all the livestock and vegetables they haul are
carefully tended.


"We will introduce stricter quality control standards to
produce more high-quality non-staple foodstuffs so that residents
of Macao will have greater choices for better food after the
handover on December 20," said Yang.


For example, to provide Macao with top-quality pigs and prevent
spread of disease, Doumen workers are asked to don boots and wade
through a pool of disinfectant before entering the pig-breeding
area, where 1,000 head of 90-kg lean pigs are waiting to be loaded
into trucks and shipped to Macao.


An official at the chicken farm said they have taken
precautions so that no shipments of underweight or overweight
chickens enter the Macao market. The chickens they now supply to
Macao are raised in a natural environment, which are believed by
Macao residents to be tastier than those chickens raised in cages,
said the official.


"Our purpose is to let compatriots of Macao eat well," said the
official.


At an 80-hectare vegetable growing farmland, the deputy general
manager said local vegetable farmers rise at four o'clock in the
morning to pick vegetables so that fresh choices will be available
at a major commodity wholesale market in Macao by 7:30 a.m.
Ordinary residents of Macao will be able to buy fresh vegetables
by eight o'clock.


According to the deputy general manager, his company supplied
Macao with 8,000 head of live pigs, 337,000 live poultry, 150 head
of cattle, as well as 1,500 tons of fresh vegetables in the first
11 months of the year.

results.content:
1996-06-02 
 China Sees Full Vegetable Basket 


TIANJIN, June 2 (Xinhua) -- China has made great achievements
in non-staple food production, the so-called "vegetable basket
project", according to a working conference held here recently.


A batch of large scale vegetable bases have been built and more
advanced agricultural know-hows used in the non-staple food
production, according to the conference.


Latest statistics show that in the first three months of this
year, the output of meat increased by 16.4 percent over the same
period last year, while that of eggs rising by 13.5 percent, and
that of aquatic products by 15.5 percent.


The planting acreage of vegetables also witnessed increase in
the period, which helped provide sufficient vegetables for Chinese
residents.


In 1995, China produced 50 million tons of meat, 6.35 million
tons of milk, 16.75 million tons of eggs, 25.17 million tons of
aquatic products and 41.9 million tons of fruits, all increasing
by various extents over the previous year.

results.content:
LOW-HEAT OVEN SLOWLY BRINGS OUT THE GOODNESS IN FRUITS 



   NEW YORK _ For some years now, I have been using low, dry heat
to add intense flavor to tomatoes or to make sweet root-vegetable
chips. I simply put the vegetables in a very low oven and let them
laze away as the moisture is slowly drawn out and the sugars become
caramelized and profoundly sweet.


   Recently, to add a little distinction to some of the more common
fruits that I use in desserts, condiments, salads or garnishes, I
began experimenting with this oven-drying technique to bring out
their inherent syrupy goodness. After some fits and starts, I think
that I perfected the method.


   At the restaurant, we have been turning out ambrosial, lightly
dried peaches, plums and nectarines as they hit the height of their
ripeness this summer. With fall approaching, we began drying
heirloom apples and pears with just as much success.


   Drying fruit (or vegetables) at home is just as easy. Any type
of oven will do: gas, electric or convection.


   If you are in no hurry _ and if you have an oven setting of less
than 200 degrees, which is usually marked ``warm'' _ use that
setting and let the fruit dry for up to 12 hours. If 200 degrees is
your lowest setting, dry the fruit for no longer than 6 hours. The
larger the pieces, the moister the fruit (or vegetable) will
remain.


   Simply place the pieces on baking sheets lined with parchment
paper, leaving at least an inch around each one, and put the sheets
in a low oven. Take a peek from time to time; the drying is done
when the edges begin to curl, the flesh begins to firm up and the
center is still very soft. Or just taste the fruit as it dries, and
remove it when it reaches the intensity you like.


   For this fall salad, the pears are only lightly dried. They
retain a great deal of their moisture, and their sugar takes on
just a hint of caramel. To add an even greater depth of flavor, I
marinate them in port and ginger before sending them off for a long
bask.


   COMPOSED SALAD OF RED OAK-LEAF LETTUCE, FENNEL, OVEN-DRIED
PEARS, TOASTED WALNUTS AND MAYTAG BLUE CHEESE


   Time: 2 hours 15 minutes, including 2 hours marinating and
drying


   6 Comice pears


   1 cup port wine


   3 tablespoons light brown sugar


   1 teaspoon grated fresh ginger


   { cup extra virgin olive oil


   3 tablespoons fine quality, well-aged balsamic vinegar


   Coarse salt and freshly cracked black pepper to taste


   2 medium fennel bulbs


   2 heads red oak-leaf lettuce, well washed, dried and pulled
apart


   { cup toasted walnut pieces (if available, black walnuts add an
interesting note)


   4 ounces Maytag Blue Cheese.


   1. Peel pears, cut them in half lengthwise, and carefully remove
core and stem.


   2. Combine port, brown sugar and ginger in a shallow baking
dish. Add pear halves, cut-side down, and spoon port mixture over
them. Cover with plastic film and marinate for 1 hour, turning from
time to time.


   3. Preheat oven to 200 degrees. Place marinated pears on a
parchment paper-lined baking sheet in the oven, and dry for about 1
hour or until pears are just beginning to firm but remain moist in
the center.


   4. Whisk together the olive oil and vinegar. Season to taste
with salt and cracked black pepper. Wash and trim the fennel bulbs.
Cut bulbs in half lengthwise, then cut fennel lengthwise into very
thin slices.


   5. Beginning at the wide end, cut each half of pear lengthwise,
down to but not through the stem end.


   6. Toss lettuce and fennel together. Add a small amount of
dressing, and toss to combine. Place equal portions of the dressed
mixture on each of six luncheon plates. Fan two pear halves across
the greens, overlapping the stem ends. Sprinkle a few walnut pieces
around the edges of the plates. Crumble an equal portion of the
cheese over each plate. Drizzle a bit of the remaining dressing
over the top, and serve.


   Yield: 6 servings.

results.content:
FOOD QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS  
 (JT) 



   &UR; Stocks Need Time &LR;


   Q: What is the secret to a flavorful stock? Mine always turn out
watery.


   A: Chances are you are not simmering it long enough. Good,
flavorful stocks need hours of gentle cooking in order to encourage
the meats, bones and vegetables to give up their flavors.


   Depending upon the stock you are making, be prepared to simmer
it anywhere from one to six hours. Fish and vegetable stocks cook
quickly, chicken stocks fall in the middle, and beef and veal
stocks can cook almost all day for the richest results.


   Start by covering the ingredients with two inches of cold water
and slowly bringing the mixture to a simmer. Using cold water is
important. Shirley Corriher, a food scientist, says that if you add
meats and vegetables to hot water, their starches will expand and
gel, which inhibits the release of flavor.


   Using a variety of vegetables is also essential. Onions, leeks,
garlic, celery and carrots are the standards, but don't limit
yourself. Parsnips add sweetness, mushrooms, an earthy flavor, and
a halved tomato lends richness and an attractive, ruddy color.
Beware of assertive, cruciferous vegetables like cabbage or
broccoli, which can overpower a stock. Parsley and other herbs, a
bay leaf, peppercorns and cloves add nuances.


   If you are making a brown stock _ one in which you roast the
bones before simmering _ add some vegetables to the roasting pan.
They will caramelize, and their flavors will intensify. You can
roast vegetables for a vegetable stock, too.


   As for salt, add just a little at the beginning (say, a half
teaspoon) to help draw flavor from the vegetables and bones. Before
taking the stockpot off the heat, taste the broth to see if it is
intense enough (add a sprinkling of salt to the spoon). If it
tastes weak, keep simmering until it is rich and flavorful. Then
turn off the heat and stir in salt to taste.


   &QL;

results.content:
1998-01-06 
 China's Non-Staple Food Consumption 


BEIJING, January 6 (Xinhua) -- The per-capita share of meat,
fish, vegetables, fruit and eggs in China is above the world
average, according to the Ministry of Agriculture.


The average per capita share last year of meat was 50.2 kg.,
eggs, 17 kg., milk, 6.6 kg., fish, 29 kg., vegetables, 253 kg.,
and fruit, 40.4 kg.


This followed a decade-long national drive to increase
non-staple food production in the "vegetable basket" project, in
which the central government spent more than three billion yuan
building 591 large vegetable production centers and 213 animal
husbandry centers. By the end of 1997, the country had 4,000
wholesale farm produce markets.


As a result, last year China produced 62 million tons of meat,
21 million tons of eggs, 8.1 million tons of milk, 36 million tons
of aquatic products, 313 million tons of vegetables, and 50
million tons of fruit.

results.content:
A SMOKY PEPPER'S SEDUCTIVE POWER 



   Peppers release their heat in many ways, whether in a straight
drive like cayenne or a consuming explosion like a jalapeno. The
Aleppo pepper is more seductive, exuding a mellow, earthy warmth
that seems to expand rapidly, then slowly dissipate.


   When sprinkled over roasted potatoes, the deep red waxy flakes
of the Aleppo, a pepper that comes from Syria, do not just add
flavor; they change the potatoes. Behind their pure nutty flavor,
there is smokiness and a little spice. With carrots, the pepper
underlines the vegetable's sweetness with its own raisin-like taste
_ and that lingering heat. It is like paprika, but much more
complex.


   Aleppo refers to red peppers in the capsicum family that are
grown, partly dried and coarsely ground around the city of Aleppo.
Other peppers from nearby regions look the same, but the Aleppo
flavor is distinct, just as the flavor of prosciutto di Parma is
distinct from other cured pork.


   As alluring as it is, Aleppo pepper has managed to elude most
chefs and home cooks. Restaurants serving Syrian and other Middle
Eastern food, like Zaytoons in Brooklyn, Moustache in Greenwich
Village and Layla in TriBeCa, do not even use it.


   And yet, the chefs who have discovered it can't seem to put it
down. Floyd Cardoz of Tabla uses Aleppo pepper in a number of
dishes, often blended with cayenne and chilies from India and New
Mexico. Its mild, rich heat is in the pan-roasted lobster glazed
with Goan curry and in the tomato curry sauce served with a raviolo
of spinach and sheep's milk ricotta. It even finds a place in a
warm Cheddar fondue with cumin.


   Joyce Goldstein, a San Francisco chef who has written cookbooks,
is another devotee of Aleppo pepper, and like Cardoz, she is not a
purist about it. She often simply uses it in place of other dried
red peppers for a richer, smokier aroma.


   ``Anytime you have the choice of using hot paprika or a
paprika-cayenne combination, that's the time to use it,'' she said.


   Aleppo pepper is sold in most good spice shops, like Adriana's
Bazaar at Grand Central Market, (800) 316-0820, and Kalustyans, 123
Lexington Avenue, (212) 685-3416. It is also sold online at
www.worldspice.com. The price is usually around $2 an ounce.


   A similar pepper called Maras comes from just over the border in
Turkey. It looks the same as the Aleppo _ bright red, flaked and
moist from a small addition of salt _ but is a tad hotter. Urfa,
also from Turkey, is darker and smokier, with a deeper, dried-fruit
aroma. Sometimes these peppers are not even packaged with specific
names. Maras and Aleppo may simply be labeled Middle Eastern
pepper.


   Aleppo is used in a spread called muhammara, in which the coarse
powder is diluted in oil and water, then mixed with bread crumbs,
ground walnuts, lemon juice and pomegranate syrup, and eaten like
hummus, with flatbread. It is also used to season meat fillings,
legumes and salads.


   But you can use it like any other dried red pepper. It can be
sprinkled over sweet potatoes with a little coarse sea salt and
olive oil before roasting them. Aleppo blends well with other
spices, too, like toasted and ground cumin and coriander for
coating pieces of carrot before roasting or braising. The light,
thin flakes cling well to vegetables, fish and meats and work well
with other spices as rubs or in marinades.


   Aleppo's sweetness and soft heat is especially good with sweet
vegetables like tomatoes and eggplant. One way to see this is to
char eggplants and puree them while warm with garlic, olive oil and
lemon juice, adding a touch of Aleppo at the end. The pepper
underscores the smokiness of the eggplant.


   As Cardoz points out, Aleppo has one quality that few other
dried red peppers have: you can add it to a finished dish and not
worry about the sharpness overwhelming it. ``If you add almost any
other chili pepper at the end of cooking, it hits you in the
throat,'' he said.


   Aleppo has a roasted, finished flavor, so you can simmer white
beans with onion, garlic and herbs, then

results.content:
1998-06-16 
 Anhui Outstrips World in Per Capita Non-Staple Food Consumption 


HEFEI, June 16 (Xinhua) -- The per-capita consumption of
nonstaple food in east China's Anhui province has outstripped the
world average.


In 1997, each of the residents in the province consumed 226 kg
of vegetables, 45 kg of meat, 13.9 kg of egg and 21.3 kg of
aquatic products, according to the Agriuculture Department of the
province.


Over the past decade, Anhui has spent six billion yuan in
constructing 206 Shopping Basket Projects, where
vegetables, pigs, ducks, beef cattle, chickens, and fish are
grown, according to an Agriculture Department official.


The Shopping Basket Projects produce more than five million
tons of quality vegetables a year, which are shipped to supply
residents in the province and also sold to many areas outside
Anhui as well.


The province produced 14 million tons of vegetables, 2.77
million tons of meat, 880,000 tons of eggs, 29,700 tons of milk,
1.3 million tons of aquatic products and 650,000 tons of fruits in
1997.


The six kinds of non-staple food had a total output value of 30
billion yuan, accounting for 50.6 percent of the province's total
agricultural output value and becoming a major source of income
for farmers.

results.content:
WILL THE 2000 BUG GOBBLE THE VEGGIES? 



   Tom Johns, the president of the Territorial Seed Co., has no
idea whether the millennium bug, a k a Y2K, is ``overblown fiction
or a real problem.'' But that did not stop him from warning about
possible Y2K disruptions in the catalog that Territorial recently
mailed to 650,000 gardeners.


   In the catalog, Johns reminded his customers of the alarm that
some gardeners felt last year after the Johns Hopkins School of
Medicine announced that broccoli sprouts contain high levels of
sulforaphane, a cancer-fighting compound. He said the announcement
set off such a frenzy that worldwide supplies of open-pollinated
varieties of broccoli seed that reproduce similar plants generation
after generation were wiped out in 48 hours.


   ``We should all learn from that experience,'' Johns concluded.
``If in fact the millennium computer bug turns out to be real, I
truly believe the world's seed supply available to home gardeners
will be gone just as fast.''


   Competitors say Johns is sowing Y2K hype, but there is no
denying that he is harvesting a once-in-a-lifetime marketing
opportunity. Polls reveal that tens of millions of Y2K-leery
Americans fear that computers could break down frequently enough
during the transition to the year 2000 to cause big disruptions in
the global economy. Hard-core alarmists fear there will be limited
supplies of seed for next year's crops. But the ranks of the
worried also include a larger group of gardeners who plan to grow
vegetables this year as a hedge against breakdowns in deliveries of
food to stores.


   Territorial's response is the $99.50 Millennium Victory Garden,
a mix of 47 vegetable seeds. It is the most popular item in the new
catalog, Johns said, and on a pace to become the most popular
offering in the company's 20-year history.


   To some seed dealers, Territorial's assertions are farfetched at
best. Lana Baker, the vegetable seed specialist at Molbak's Seattle
Garden Center in Washington, which claims to stock the largest
variety of vegetable seeds of any retailer in the world, said
Molbak's never had a problem getting the type of broccoli seed that
Johns contends was wiped out. Besides, she said, ``it's extreme to
suggest that people will run out of seed because of Y2K.''


   In any case, Molbak's sales are up, too, as are those of
industry giants like W. Atlee Burpee in Warminster, Pa. Some
vendors, like Ferry-Morse Seed Co. in Fulton, Ky., say that sales
have not yet jumped significantly but that salespeople in the field
are reporting requests from retailers to be ready to ship extra
seed quickly.


   ``We never thought people would plant more vegetables as a hedge
against the year 2000, but we are definitely seeing a millennium
effect,'' said Donald Zeidler, direct marketing manager at Burpee.


   Others on the home-grown food chain are also feeling the
effects. The Wisconsin Aluminum Foundry in Manitowoc, Wis., a maker
of pressurized home-canning equipment, has seen its sales double in
the last year.


   If the demand lasts, vegetable gardening may reverse a long-term
decline. Just over 20 percent of American households grew
vegetables in 1997, according to the National Gardening Association
in Burlington, Vt. That's down from 49 percent in 1975, the
post-World War II peak, when many Americans were growing food in
response to inflation in food prices.


   Although flower gardening remains popular, more and more growers
of edible gardens have thrown in their trowels. As more homemakers
moved into the job market and wide varieties of relatively
inexpensive vegetables became available year round, vegetable
gardeners found it hard to justify the investment _ until the year
2000 threat arose.


   ``We had become spoiled shopping at the local supermarket,''
said Don Landis, 50, an airline cargo handler who lives in suburban
Seattle. But concerns over the year 2000 bug convinced him and his
wife to return to backyard vegetable gardening for the first time
in 10 years. ``If this turns out to be a non-event,'' he said,

results.content:
THREE-BEAN SALAD 



   I've named this salad after those crocks of marinated green
beans, garbanzo and kidney beans in every American salad bar. But
my three-bean salad is really something entirely different, a
simple composition of dried beans and fresh beans: a base of pureed
white beans is infused with truffle oil, topped with a mixture of
fresh beans in a vinaigrette and finished with field greens or
fresh herbs.


   The key to success is your bean technique. Dried beans must be
properly rehydrated and then gently simmered, never boiled. If you
boil the heck out of beans, they tend to explode. Soaking them in
warm water and then gradually bringing the cooking liquid up to a
gentle heat insures even cooking and intact beans. Add salt toward
the end of cooking rather than at the beginning, or it will inhibit
rehydration.


   The salad works well with any fresh beans _ Blue Lake, haricots
verts, yellow wax, fava, lima or cranberry beans, to name some
possibilities _ cooked until they are firm but give no resistance
to the teeth. To cook fresh beans _ or any green vegetable, for
that matter _ I use a technique I call big-pot blanching: cook your
vegetable in so much water that the water does not lose its boil
when you add the vegetables. Your water should be heavily salted,
about a half cup for each gallon. The result is a vegetable of the
brightest possible color.


   If you've cooked your beans properly, you almost can't go wrong
with this salad. Feel free to experiment with the vinaigrette: wine
vinegars (sherry, red or Champagne) or balsamic are good choices. I
love to serve it throughout the summer when we have abundant
varieties of ``fresh from the garden'' beans. It's seasonal,
elegant and fun _ an interpretation of a salad bar standard that's
worthy, I think, of haute cuisine. &QL; 
 &QL; 
THREE-BEAN SALAD  &QL;


   Time: 2 hours, plus overnight soaking of beans  &QL; 
 &QL;


   1 cup dried marrow beans or other white beans, soaked in 4 cups
water at room temperature overnight


   5 cups plus 2 tablespoons vegetable stock or canned vegetable
broth


   1 shallot, peeled and halved, plus 1 teaspoon minced


   1 small carrot, peeled


   Bouquet garni: 3 sprigs parsley, 1 sprig thyme and 1 bay leaf,
wrapped in two 5-inch sections of leek greens and tied with string


   Kosher salt and freshly ground white pepper


   4 to 5 tablespoons white truffle oil


   2 teaspoons sherry wine vinegar


   1 cup trimmed haricots verts in 1-inch pieces


   1 cup trimmed yellow wax beans in 1-inch pieces


   { cup shelled, peeled fava beans


   1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil


   1 teaspoon lemon juice


   2 cups frisee or baby greens, for garnish.


   1 tablespoon peeled, seeded, diced tomatoes


   1. Prepare the bean puree: Drain the white beans. In a large
saucepan or casserole, combine the beans with 4 cups of water.
Place over low heat, and bring to a simmer. Remove from the heat,
and allow the beans to rest for 5 minutes. Remove any beans that
float to the surface. Drain, and chill under cold running water.
Return the beans to the saucepan, and add 5 cups of the vegetable
stock, shallot halves, carrot and bouquet garni. Place over low
heat, and simmer for 20 minutes.


   2. Add \ teaspoon salt, and continue to cook until the beans are
completely tender, 25 to 30 minutes. There should still be some
liquid remaining in the pan. Place a strainer over a bowl, and
drain the beans, reserving the liquid. Remove and discard the
carrot and bouquet garni. Using a food processor, begin to puree
the beans. With the machine running, slowly add the reserved liquid
through the feed tube, adding just enough to make a smooth puree.
Next, pass the puree through a tamis or drum sieve. Measure 1 cup
of puree into a mixing bowl, and set aside the remainder for
another use. Whisk in the remaining 2 tablespoons vegetable stock,
2 tablespoons of the truffle oil and 1 teaspoon of the vinegar. The
puree should have a creamy consistency; add 1 more tablespoon of
truffle oil if desired. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

results.content:
1996-06-05 
 EC Provides Aid For Pakistan's Health Care Program 


ISLAMABAD, June 5 (Xinhua) -- The European Commission (EC) has
committed 750,000 ECU (about 33.5 million rupees) of food aid for
Pakistan's Primary Health Care Program implemented by the Health
Ministry.


According to a press release here today, the food aid consists
of 1,055 tons of vegetable oil, and will be channeled through the
UN World Food Program.


The beneficiaries will be expectant mothers who register
themselves for vaccination against tetanus and for examination
before and after the birth.


The vegetable oil will provide valuable additional nutrition to
the expectant mothers during pregnancy.


The EC previously contributed food aid to World Food Program
projects in Pakistan in 1991 and 1992 amounting to 1.75 million
ECU (77.2 million rupees).


An EC donation of 1.04 million ECU (43.6 million rupees) of
food aid for Pakistan's needy groups was announced last December.

results.content:
COMPUTER HOTLIST: FRUITS AND VEGETABLES 




   World Geography of Potatoes _
julian.dac.uga.edu/potato/intro.html


   The potato as change agent? That's the theory from Dr. Robert E.
Rhoades at the University of Georgia. Rhoades has discovered that
the potato is everywhere, and has profound effects on many
cultures. &QL;


   Fruit and Vegetable Encyclopedia _
www.dole5aday.com/menu/nutrition/menu.htm


   When telling your kids to eat their vegetables, you need hard,
cold facts to back up your claims that they're healthy and tasty.
Dole's Fruit and Vegetable Encyclopedia has the intelligence you
need on dozens of varieties. &QL;


   Aggie Horticulture _
aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu/vegetable/vegetable.html


   No one knows what it takes to grow fruits and veggies in Texas
better than Texas A&M University. Get growing tips and pay a visit
to the Center for Vegetable Improvement, which brought you
genetically engineered 1015 onions and maroon carrots. &QL;


   Chuck's Produce Talk _ www.comevisit.com/chuckali/produce.htm


   Chuck works as a produce manager at a California grocery store,
and when he's not stocking produce he's writing about it for his
Web site. He's got practical tips on everything from nutrition to
figuring out when a pear is ripe. &QL;


   USDA Agricultural Marketing Service Farmers Markets _
www.ams.usda.gov/farmersmarkets/


   The U.S. Department of Agriculture keeps track of farmers
markets all over the country. If you're traveling and in need of
seriously fresh fruits and veggies on the road, check here. &QL;


   Produce Oasis _ www.produceoasis.com


   Like the Fruit and Vegetable Encyclopedia, this is a compendium
of facts about produce. But here, you get such gems as: ``In
ancient Greece, tossing an apple to a girl was a traditional
proposal of marriage; catching it was acceptance.'' &QL;


   The Wonderful World of Gourds _
daphne.palomar.edu/wayne/ww0503.htm


   Wayne's got a thing for gourds. He appreciates them in many
different ways, as food, as decorative items and as the butt of a
good joke or two. &QL;


   Web Page of the Killer Tomatoes _
www.awod.com/gallery/rwav/ctyner/kt.html


   Attack of the Killer Tomatoes, originally made in 1980, was a
spoof of the disaster movies of the 1970s. It's since become a cult
favorite, inspiring three sequels, a cartoon series and vegetable
paranoia in millions. &QL;


   How to Become a Fruitarian _ www.islandnet.com/arton/fruit.html


   Fruitarians believe it's bad to eat even vegetables, since in
many cases you are destroying the plant itself. Fruit is an
``offering'' from a plant, and by eating it you are spreading its
seeds. Apparently, this is not a joke. &QL;


   Recipes Archive: Vegetables _
www.neosoft.com/recipes/vegetables/default.html


   Looking for great vegetable recipes? Here's the archive from the
rec.food.recipes news group on Usenet that deals specifically with
vegetables. &QL; 
 &QL; 
 &QL; 
XXXX END OF STORY &QL;

results.content:
The vegetables are loaded not just with useful fiber and
vitamins (A and C), but they've got phytochemicals, sulforaphane,
indoles _ all compounds that are believed to fight everything from
colon and breast cancer to Alzheimer's disease.


   So if broccoli, cauliflower and their various cousins in the
vegetable patch are life-enhancers, are they even more so when
grown organically?


   Yes, according to the people at Warren Weber's Star Route Farm
in Bolinas. They believe their organic crops are not only healthier
but that they taste better than their conventionally grown
counterparts.


   ``That's what customers tell us,'' says production manager
Douglas Gallagher.


   The consumer feedback is an advantage of entering the farmers'
market business, which the 25-year-old Star Route Farm did this
year, making its products more widely available to consumers who
increasingly ask for organic produce.


   Fifteen years ago, Gallagher says, Star Route's 40 acres _
supplemented by twice that acreage at its satellite farm in the
Coachella Valley of Southern California _ would have been
considered large for an organic operation. Now, he says, the
operation is small fish in an expanding pond, as many large-scale
farms jump on the organic bandwagon.


   The reasons include greater consumer awareness as well as the
development of natural pest-fighting products and fertilizers,
which can be applied with conventional machinery. ``You don't have
to make your own compost any more,'' Gallagher points out.


   Still, Star Route relies heavily on a natural crop cycle to
maintain its soil and guarantee healthy and plentiful future crops.
As soon as the last broccoli and cauliflower are harvested _ in a
few more weeks _ the Bolinas fields will be planted with clover and
other cover crops that get plowed under in the spring. Star Route's
restaurant and retail customers will then receive essentially the
same crops (broccoli, lettuces, herbs, flowers and root vegetables)
from the Coachella Valley farm, which, in turn, converts to cover
crops for the hot summer months.


   Gallagher says Star Route's location on a flood plain is ideal
for cool-weather lovers like broccoli. The heavy soil (technically,
blucher loam) isn't well suited for root vegetables, but the
crucifers thrive here from spring to fall _ even into mid-winter if
it's a dry year.


   Competition from large farms that have switched to organic
practices _ some as far away as Arizona and Mexico _ may benefit
consumers by driving prices down, but it's obviously a concern for
small operations.


   Weber and Gallagher are part of a group of west Marin growers
who are working with the county's Agricultural Commissioner's
Office to create a Marin organic label to promote the use of
locally grown produce.


   Support from trend-setting restaurateurs who want their produce
not only fresh and natural but locally grown if at all feasible, is
a boon to farms like Star Route. Plus, it helps to be virtually in
the backyard of a metropolis.


   ``We can drive to Ferry Plaza (site of a Saturday farmers'
market) in an hour,'' says Gallagher, so the distance, and time,
from field to table are about as short as they can get.

results.content:
&HT;   



   AUSTIN, Texas _ It's a hassle to organize your family and
friends, gather up all that food and navigate the traffic, all the
time knowing it's going to be hot as blazes until the sun goes
down.


   But it's worth it. That's why 65,000 to 70,000 locals annually
wind their way to the Auditorium Shores of Town Lake for the Austin
Symphony's Fourth of July celebration.


   It's a fun family/friends venue. It's red, white and fireworks.
Food and music, too.


   Peggy Gunn, whose family has celebrated the Fourth this way for
more than a decade, traditionally spreads her red and white quilt
over the grassy banks and serves a picnic for six to 12 people.
``I've got a sister from North Carolina coming this year, who is
bringing her 12-year-old daughter.'' Add to that her husband, two
grown daughters, and local friends bringing young children, who
always add magic to the evening, and the quilt fills up.


   Gunn likes it that way. The best relationships are built around
the dinner table or picnicking on quilts, says the Southern-born
hostess, who, while rearing her children, always kept a picnic
basket packed for impromptu family outings.


   Her Fourth of July menu varies each year, with the exception of
the mandatory deviled eggs. This year's spread will include
crudites with tzatziki, marinated beef tenderloin, artichoke-rice
salad and spirited watermelon. All cold. All dishes that can be
prepared ahead. In fact, the salads are better made at least two
days before serving.


   Gunn likes to cook and spread a menu of dishes with family
meaning, but other revelers opt for take-out.


   ``I don't ever prepare the food myself,'' says Jeani
Sandefer-Smith, who has been July Fourthpicnicking on Auditorium
Shores since 1976. ``I go to Whole Foods or Central Market and get
cool stuff.'' Melons, Greek salad, shrimp cocktail, tarragon
chicken salad, cold pastas, French bread and always some kind of
sinful individual desserts such as tortes loaded with cherries and
whipped cream.


   She packs everything in a large ice chest with wheels, attaching
other items to the cooler with a bungee cord so nothing has to be
carried. Arriving at the picnic site about 5:30 p.m. to get her
favorite spot, she puts down a canvas first, then a blanket,
staking the corners with small flags and making it easier for the
dozen or so family and friends to find the spot.


   If the summer keeps up its heat wave, there is no question that
it will be a hot time in the old town on July Fourth. But cannons
will boom, as the Symphony's new music director Peter Bay directs
Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture. Rockets will flare, as fireworks have
their 15 minutes of fame in the Austin skies. And people will oooh
and aahhh.


   For Gunn, Sandefer-Smith and thousands of other picnickers, the
patriotic evening will be worth the effort.


   Peggy Gunn's Fourth of July fireworks picnic


   Crudites with Tzatziki


   2 cups low-fat yogurt, drained


   1 cucumber, seeded (but not peeled), grated and drained


   1/2 cup finely chopped sweet onion


   4 cloves minced garlic


   Salt and pepper to taste


   1 tablespoon olive oil


   1 teaspoon vinegar


   Pinch dried mint


   Assorted raw vegetables: red pepper strips, carrot sticks, onion
brushes, jicama slices, celery sticks, etc.


   Combine yogurt, cucumber, onion, garlic, oil and seasonings. Mix
well and chill overnight. Serve as a dip with the raw veggies. (The
tzatziki also is good on gyros, pitas or as a salad dressing.)
Makes 3 cups.


   Chilled Beef Tenderloin with Horseradish Sauce


   4-6 pounds beef tenderloin


   Marinade:

   3 tablespoons salad oil

turning occasionally. Preheat broiler, remove meat from liquid, pat

In 1995, Shangyi sold 50 million kg of vegetables to Beijing, Tianjin Municipality, and Zhangj ... with only potatoes and oats as their staple food, and very little in the way of vegetables an ... first in the county to engage in commercial vegetable growing when he spent 2,000 yuan to open a s
results.content:
1996-08-07 
 Vegetable Basket for Big Cities In Poor County 


Beijing, August 6 (Xinhua) -- "The vegetables you buy at local
markets in Beijing might have come from Shangyi County," Qiao
Denggui, party secretary of the county Communist Party Committee,
proudly tells visitors from the nation's capital.


This is by no means an exaggeration. Shangyi, a county in
northern Hebei Province, is now making a good living by providing
a large amount of vegetables to other parts of the country and
even selling some abroad.


In 1995, Shangyi sold 50 million kg of vegetables to Beijing,
Tianjin Municipality, and Zhangjiakou City in Hebei, as well as to
Russia and Mongolia.


For those who live in places with more favorable conditions,
these figures don't sound like much. But for farmers in Shangyi,
which is in north China, on the edge of the Mongolian Highlands,
with its cold weather and poor economy, it means a not
insignificant move historically.


For decades, local farmers led poor lives, with only potatoes
and oats as their staple food, and very little in the way of
vegetables and meat.


In 1992, Pan Yonghe, a farmer in Dayingzi Village, became the
first in the county to engage in commercial vegetable growing when
he spent 2,000 yuan to open a small vegetable plot covered with
plastic sheeting as he had learned from local agronomists from the
county-seat.


For people in this poverty-stricken county, 2,000 yuan meant 10
years of savings, and it was all Pan had, and was money he had
saved to build his dream house.


The move turned out to be a big success. In the first year, Pan
earned 7,000 yuan from his vegetable plot, growing celery,
tomatoes, and cabbage. The tale of Pan's success encouraged the
villagers to follow suit.


The county leaders, who had been looking for a way to help
local farmers become affluent, came to see the unique advantages
of the county in growing vegetables. Shangyi county is
agricultural-based and has less industrial pollution, and urban
residents are eager to buy organic, or "clean vegetables", from
places like Shangyi.


Over the past few years, local officials and scientists have
put a great deal of effort into getting more local farmers into
the vegetable business by means of preferential policies and
bringing in more scientists. They have also sent salesmen across
China, especially to big cities, to market their products.


Urban residents in an increasing number of cities are getting
acquainted with Shangyi's produce, as are foreign markets.


Vegetables have brought cash to this underdeveloped county and
its 180,000 people.


By 1995, 8,500 rural families no longer had to worry about
their food and clothing, and some 2,000 households became
well-off, thanks to the revolutionary changes that had been
brought about.


This year, locals invested 1.36 million yuan in vegetable
production, with acreage increased to 4,000 ha., including 413
ha. of green-houses and plastic-covered plots.


According to Qiao, the county is trying to expand vegetable
production, but also plans to introduce investment from other
parts of the country or overseas to set up a vegetable processing
business to produce dried or canned vegetables.


"I believe that more Chinese and foreigners will develop a
taste for vegetables produced here," Qiao concluded.

results.content:
1999-10-14 
 Asia-Pacific Countries Urged to Upgrade Fruit, Vegetable Processing 


YANTAI, October 14 (Xinhua) -- An international symposium on
fruit and vegetable processing technology and industrialization
closed here today, with countries in the Asia-Pacific region urged
to improve the processing technology they currently use for these
foods.


The three-day symposium was an important component of the
International Symposium and Exhibition on Fruit and Vegetable
Processing Technology and Industrialization, the first
international symposium on the matter ever held in China.


Scholars and experts from at home and abroad gave presentations
on issues in the field. The symposium has received 112 reports and
papers from over 20 countries and international organizations.


Some 150 participants from over 30 countries put forward some
recommendations in which they urged countries of the United
Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (
ESCAP) region to go all out in upgrading processing technology for
fruits and vegetables.


They suggested that a similar seminar be held next year to
exchange experiences and to demonstrate equipment and products.


Other recommendations encouraged the Regional Network of
Agricultural Machinery (RNAM) and the Asia Pacific Center of
Transfer of Technology (APCTT), two important regional
institutions of the ESCAP region, to play a greater role in
promoting fruit and vegetable processing and industrialization.


It was suggested that RNAM expand the scope of its work so as
to better meet the needs of fruit and vegetable processing, which
covers the whole process of planting, harvesting, post-harvest
processing, storage and marketing.


Representatives from some international organizations,
including the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United
Nations (FAO), the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO),
World Bank, and the Asian Development Bank, participated in the
symposium.


The symposium was jointly sponsored by the ESCAP, APCTT, the
Chinese Academy of Engineering, and Shandong Provincial Government.

Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (
ESCAP) region to go all out in upgrading processing technology for
fruits and vegetables.


They suggested that a similar seminar be held next year to
exchange experiences and to demonstrate equipment and products.


Other recommendations encouraged the Regional Network of
Agricultural Machinery (RNAM) and the Asia Pacific Center of
Transfer of Technology (APCTT), two important regional
institutions of the ESCAP region, to play a greater role in
promoting fruit and vegetable processing and industrialization.


It was suggested that RNAM expand the scope of its work so as
to better meet the needs of fruit and vegetable processing, which
covers the whole process of planting, harvesting, post-harvest
processing, storage and marketing.


Representatives from some international organizations,
including the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United
Nations (FAO), the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO),
World Bank, and the Asian Development Bank, participated in the
symposium.


The symposium was jointly sponsored by the ESCAP, APCTT, the
Chinese Academy of Engineering, and Shandong Provincial Government.

YANTAI, October 14 (Xinhua) -- An international symposium on
