results.content:
&HT;   



   Now that Halloween is safely behind us, some people will no
doubt go back to letting themselves be frightened by underarm
antiperspirants, irradiated food and spiders in the toilet. Those
are only a few of the popular health scares that are actually no
more dangerous than a skeleton mask.


   There will be bogus health scares as long as there is money to
be made off frightened people by removing their dental fillings or
selling them gizmos to eradicate dust mites, and the Internet
circulates those scares faster than ever. Other groundless alarms
will always be motivated less by greed than by ignorance,
gullibility or the sheer enjoyment of seeing people become
hysterical.


   That second category includes sincere phobias that power lines
and antiperspirants cause cancer, which science has refuted
repeatedly. And of eating genetically modified food, which prompts
DNA co-discoverer James Watson to say, ``I am worried about a lot
of things, but not about modified food.'' And of food irradiation,
which is proven to substantially reduce such foodborne infections
as E. coli without raising radiation levels.


   And of pesticides for fruit and vegetables, which three of four
Americans believe increase their chances of cancer. The American
Institute for Cancer Research not only has found no evidence to
that effect but also has warned that the fear is causing people to
avoid fruits and vegetables that can reduce their chances of
cancer.


   Science doesn't know everything, certainly, but frights often
distract us from real risks that we can avoid. There's evidence to
suspect cell phones might cause brain tumors, for example, but no
conclusive proof. Using headsets is a sensible precaution. But an
even better argument for headsets is there's no doubt about the
connection between cell phones and car accidents.


   Then there are the outright hoaxes so easily circulated by
e-mail. Waterproof sunscreens do not cause blindness, the sodium
laureth sulfate in shampoo does not cause cancer and three women in
Chicago did not die mysteriously after being bitten by spiders in a
public restroom, according to the authoritative Internet hoax Web
site, urbanlegends.about.com _ which currently is stressing that
Mountain Dew is not an effective contraceptive for males who drink
it.


   David Emery of About.com points out how the spider hoax e-mail
typically debunks itself. It refers to the nonexistent United
Medical Association and Blare Airport and Big Chappies restaurant
in Chicago.


   Deceptive sales pitches are harder to spot, but it helps to ask
what's in it for whoever is spreading the news. As soon as word
came out that chocolate contains cancer-fighting antioxidants
similar to vitamins C and E, the Mars company promoted a Web site
dedicated to timely information ``on chocolate and health.''


   As consumer scams go, that was hardly more deceptive than ending
price tags with ``.99.'' The Federal Trade Commission (FTC)
announced this summer that after one day's research, it told 800
Web sites their false or unsubstantiated health claims broke
federal laws.


   Beware, says the FTC, of broad claims, big words, testimonials
instead of scientific research, products available from only one
source and the terms ``scientific breakthrough'' or ``ancient
remedy.'' When you hear something can't hurt you because it's
natural, remember arsenic is natural.


   The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) says the most fertile
fields for health fraud are products to treat arthritis, cancer and
AIDS; to help people lose weight quickly or improve their sex
lives, and to reverse baldness, eliminate wrinkles and enlarge
breasts.


   The Web site www.quackwatch.com is the most comprehensive
resource on health frauds and how to spot them, although it tends
to give all alternative remedies the dismissal that only most of
them deserve.


   WellnessWeb.com is more open-minded about classical medicine
without opening its arms in embrace, pointing out that just because
something is not proven doesn't mean it can't be true. It wasn't
long ag

results.content:
HEALTH BENEFITS SPROUT FROM MIGHTY BEAN 



   (Undated) - Ponce de Leon needed a better map.


   Forget the Fountain of Youth. He should have been looking for
the (begin ital) field (endital) _ that is a field filled with
soybeans.


   It's not easy to praise a bean, but this is one mighty bean.


   Research shows that not only can it lower fat and cholesterol in
diets by pinch-hitting for numerous items heavy in animal fats, but
soy can play a preventive role in the fight against several
cancers, including breast, colon and prostate. Soy also has been
found to help soften the unpleasant symptoms of menopause.


   The key, says Patricia Greenberg, author of ``The Whole Soy
Cookbook,'' is a tiny compound in soy called genistein.


   Genistein is an isoflavone, a compound that is genetically
similar to the human hormone estrogen. It's known as a
phytoestrogen, which means that it is a plant compound similar to
estrogen.


   Greenberg, a nutritionist who is a graduate of the Scottsdale
Culinary Institute, says soy is the closest thing to a ``perfect
food'' that nature offers.


   Soy foods differ somewhat in their concentration of isoflavones,
but all of the traditional soy foods _ tofu, soy milk, tempeh and
miso _ are rich sources of isoflavones, providing about 30 to 40
milligrams per serving.


   There are more than 300 plants that are sources of
phytoestrogens, including such mundane veggies as carrots, corn,
apples, barley and oats. Soy has received the most attention
because it has a much more intense concentration of the chemicals.


   Researchers long have noted that many Asian countries, which
tend to consume diets high in soy foods, have lower rates of
breast, prostate and colon cancer.


   Those countries' diets also tend to be lower in fat and
cholesterol and higher in fiber than Western diets. Low-fat,
high-fiber diets are linked to lower rates of cancer and heart
disease.


   Tofu goddess Greenberg just smiles.


   Adding just 25 grams of soy protein to your daily diet taps into
genistein's protective powers, she said.


   People who consume that soy protein will be more likely to lower
their intake of other proteins that tend to be higher in fat and
cholesterol.


   Greenberg's book includes dozens of recipes using soy foods and
offers sample daily menus that provide at least 25 grams of soy
protein.


   Many people know soy is great for them, but don't know how to
introduce it into their diets.


   Are they stuck eating blob after blob of tasteless tofu?


   Nope.


   There are dozens of ways to get that soy protein into your diet,
from raw soybean pods lightly steamed to highly processed soy
protein turned into hot dogs and hamburgers.


   Soy meat substitutes tend to absorb the flavor of whatever
they're cooked in. By contrast, meat itself puts out distinctive
flavors.


   Most palates can't necessarily tell the difference between
flavors of spices and flavors of meat. Greenberg once made a
vegetarian gumbo for a group of people who don't eat shellfish.


   They insisted they tasted the fish.


   ``They were tasting the saffron in the stock,'' she explained.
``They were tasting the flavor they were used to in the stock,
which they associated with fish.''


   This means chefs can simply marinate, season, sauce or spice
their way to a flavorful dish.


   The key is remembering that your soy product will play second
fiddle to your sauce.


   More processed products _ tofu hot dogs, for instance, or
pre-spiced soy cheese _ have less of a need to be spiced. &QL; 
 &QL; 
 &QL; 
PASTA WITH CREAM SAUCE AND MUSHROOMS &QL; 
(From the Indiana Soybean Board)


   Approximate values per serving: 382 calories, 18 g fat, 44 g
carbohydrates, 444 mg sodium, 42 percent calories from fat. &QL; 
1 tablespoon olive oil


   2 tablespoons chopped onions


   2 cloves garlic, minced


   1 teaspoon oregano


   1/4 teaspoon dried thyme


   1/4 teaspoon dried rosemary


   1/4 cup white wine


   1 2/3 cups soy milk


   1/4 cup margarine


   1/2 teaspoon salt


   1/2 teaspoon white pepper

results.content:
&HT;   



   AUSTIN, Texas _ It's the classic dad dilemma.


   Father's Day is less than 96 hours away, and millions of
offspring are facing the big dinner question: Do you give Dad
something he thinks tastes good (like a juicy ol' rib dripping in
barbecue sauce and fat) or something you think is good for him
(perhaps a small salad, with grilled fruits and vegetables)?


   It's a tug-of-war between taste and health that extends far
beyond this weekend when children want to pamper Dad. This is a
three-meals-a-day, every-day-of-the-year issue: achieving a balance
among food choices that run the gamut on the scale of healthy
eating.


   So what's a foodie to do?


   One option is to follow the path of Steven Raichlen, the author
of ``The Barbecue! Bible'' and ``Healthy Latin Cooking,'' which
both won prestigious national cookbook awards this year.


   Raichlen will dive into a heavy plate of sausage, ribs, pork and
brisket with the best of them, as he did one recent noon hour at
the Iron Works Barbecue in downtown Austin. Then he'll turn around
and prepare a light grilled shrimp for dinner, as he did that night
at Central Market Cooking School.


   The key for Raichlen is moderation (he didn't eat every ounce of
that heaping plate) and intense flavors (whether it's barbecue or
low-fat cooking).


   And turning on the grill.


   ``In general, grilling is a healthy cooking method,'' says
Raichlen, his head tilted, mouth poised above a beef rib that spans
his face ear to ear. Grilling is a healthy cooking technique, he
says, because ``there is little added fat.''


   Grilling also is something Texans endorse enthusiastically.


   ``Texas,'' Raichlen says, ``is a major epicenter of the two
biggest food trends happening in North America right now _ the
Latinization of the American diet and America going up in flames
with barbecue and grilling.''


   ``Grilling is wonderful,'' says Alexa Sparkman, a registered
dietitian in private practice in Austin. She contends that the
right grilled fish _ such as swordfish or shark _ can taste like a
beef steak if prepared well.


   If Dad still is determined to dine on beef, Sparkman suggests a
small tenderloin steak in the 4-ounce range. But first, she says,
trim all the visible fat and discard the bacon that wraps many of
them before tossing it on the grill. If the steak pushes 6 ounces,
which Sparkman says is a whole day's worth of protein, then Dad
should balance it with smaller, lighter meals the rest of the day.


   The point, she says, is moderation. In her practice, she tries
to help people find a middle-of-the-road place to begin a healthier
lifestyle. ``Extremes seldom work more than a few weeks,'' she
says.


   She also emphasizes portion control and flavorful ingredients,
such as salsas and pepper sauces, to give spark to meat and
vegetables. With balance and moderation, she says, people don't
have to give up their favorite foods in order to eat healthy.


   ``I'm not sure life would be worth living without barbecue or
chocolate,'' Sparkman says. ``It's portion control, portion
control, portion control.''


   That's a mantra echoed by Raichlen.


   He says the traditional Argentinian grill plate, which is 95
percent meat, is enough to give the typical North American
cardiologist a heart attack. Instead of replicating that, he
suggests using a small amount of meat on the plate and filling up
the rest with vegetables and other low-fat items.


   ``Use meat as the accent flavor, rather than the focus of the
plate,'' he says.


   That technique, says Dr. Jim Goolsby, a cardiologist with Austin
Heart, would help solve one of the major dietary problems in the
United States.


   People eat too much fat, Goolsby says. He recommends a diet
concentrating on fish, poultry, fruit and vegetables, while
minimizing red meat and desserts. Still, that doesn't mean Dad has
to abandon steak altogether.


   ``Is having steak on Father's Day criminal? No. But we hope to
achieve a life of balance and moderation,'' says Goolsby, a bird
hunter whose ideal meal includes smoked qu

results.content:
1999-08-25 
 Northern Tibet Grows Vegetables 


LHASA, August 25 (Xinhua) -- The Tibet Autonomous Region used
to have to get vegetables from other parts of China, but last June
it began experimenting with vegetable growing in its northern
region to meet local demand.


In Amdo County of Nagqu Prefecture, which is 5,300 meters above
sea level, spinach, pumpkins, potatoes and other vegetables are
now growing well in greenhouses which cover an area of 2,000 sq.m,
covered by plastic sheets to protect the vegetables from hail and
frost.


In the past, the county grew no vegetables, since that was
considered impossible to do on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, known as
the "roof of the world." Mutton and beef were the major food of
the local herdsmen.


According to a local senior official, the county plans to
expand its vegetable-growing area from the present 2,000 sq.m to
15,000 sq.m next year. By then, the vegetable output is expected
to reach 50,000 kg.


Several other counties in northern Tibet, including Baqen and
Sog, have also begun growing vegetables on a trial basis.

results.content:
BRET HELPS THE GULF COAST GET IN SHIPSHAPE 




   CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas _ At his baitshop beneath the John F.
Kennedy Causeway, Wilbert Gohlke and his wife scrubbed out bait
tanks they hope will soon be brimming with shrimp.


   Gohlke, 70 and a veteran of four decades of wresting a living
from the bays behind Clem's Marina, has a hunch Hurricane Bret did
the Texas coast a favor.


   ``Fishing and shrimping is good after a storm. I think all the
water that comes in from the Gulf of Mexico, it's good. It cleans
out all the dead water,'' said Gohlke.


   Some of the state's top marine scientists predict Bret's massive
infusion of freshwater will bring long-term, beneficial effects to
South Texas bay systems normally closed off from freshwater and
saltwater inflows. The flushing of the bays will mean more than
just better sport fishing. Experts say a whole marine ecosystem of
interdependent species, ranging from invisible plankton to ungainly
brown pelicans, will be helped.


   And the pesky brown tide, which has plagued Texas bays for
nearly a decade, may have been flushed away.


   But perhaps the most dramatic effect of the storm can be seen on
beaches along the Gulf of Mexico. Bret's storm surge carved open 12
new channels through the barrier islands along the Gulf from Port
Isabel to Corpus Christi, allowing huge quantities of fresh sea
water to flood the bays.


   ``Anytime you have a big storm event like this one _ and this
storm Bret went right through the center of the Laguna Madre,
dumped a lot of water, raised the tides to very high levels _ it
has a big effect on the flushing of the Laguna Madre,'' said Ken
Dunton, an associate professor at the University of Texas Marine
Science Institute at Port Aransas.


   Dunton, an expert in sea grass and coastal marshes, expects new
and expanded growth of three of the five species of sea grass,
which serve as a nursery for shrimp, crabs and fish. Those grasses
_ shoal grass, manatee grass and wigeon grass _ are also an
important food source for millions of ducks that winter in Texas
bays.


   ``The long-term benefits of increased freshwater inflows through
a major event such as a hurricane to Texas estuaries far outweigh
the short-term, negative effects. Long-term, you'll see increased
habitat utilization by commercially important species of finfish
and shellfish,'' including shrimp, blue crabs, trout, redfish and
black drum, Dunton said.


   One of the immediate short-term concerns is the heavy runoff
from farm lands, which means increased nitrates that promote algae
blooms such as brown tide. Other concerns are that larval marine
life could have been flushed out of protective bays into the Gulf;
sea grass could be covered in silt in areas near the new channels.


   When Bret moved ashore late Sunday, huge quantities of rainwater
were dumped directly into a number of South Texas bays with
relatively high salt levels, rapidly lowering their salinity. As
the storm moved inland, additional freshwater poured into the bays
after draining into creeks, sloughs and rivers that form the
watershed for the lower Laguna Madre, Baffin Bay, the Nueces
estuary _ which includes Corpus Christi Bay, Nueces Bay and Redfish
Bay _ and the Aransas estuary.


   ``What that means is when you flush the system like that, you're
carrying away a lot of material in the Laguna Madre that has been
sitting there decaying for a long time, dead sea grasses and
vegetation that has been rotting, and you're revitalizing the
system,'' said Dunton, who has been studying the bay system for the
last 13 years.


   ``You're exposing substrates, or (bottom) areas that have not
been exposed for a while, providing perhaps new opportunity for sea
grass growth or growth expansion, through the removal of this dead
and decaying material.''


   Late last week, state wildlife biologists and officials from the
Texas General Land Office were preparing to take aerial photographs
of Gulf beaches where Bret cut a dozen new channels above and below
the Port Mansfield cut, which divides North and South Padre Isla

results.content:
SECOND SET OF FOOD-HANDLING VIOLATIONS FOUND AT SAFECO FIELD 



   SEATTLE _ The same day the general manager of Safeco Field's
food vendor promised that food-handling problems ``won't happen
again,'' public health officials found an even greater number of
serious food safety violations.


   Public health inspectors identified 26 ``red critical''
violations at the Seattle Mariners' new stadium upon re-inspection
Thursday of concession stands and kiosks operated or managed by
Volume Services America Inc.


   ``This is unacceptable,'' said Dr. Alonzo Plough, director of
Public Health-Seattle & King County. ``We will not allow this to
become a chronic problem.''


   Alton Hutcheson, general manager of Volume Services America,
Inc., told the media Thursday that problems had been corrected at
Safeco Field and wouldn't happen again.


   Hutcheson did not return telephone calls Friday.


   But Elaine Richner, spokeswoman for Volume Services'
headquarters in Spartanburg, S.C., again emphasized that her
company was doing everything possible to improve food safety at
Safeco Field.


   Volume Services hired a food safety expert yesterday, Richner
said, who will oversee all food services at the Mariners' new
stadium. ``And all the food workers will receive additional
training.''


   Rebecca Hale, spokeswoman for the Mariners, said the baseball
organization has also hired a person to monitor Volume Services on
health-code compliance.


   ``We're surprised and very disappointed by this,'' Hale said.
The Mariners have been working with Volume Services and the health
department to prevent a ``third strike'' on food safety for the
homestand that begins Friday, she said.


   On Monday, food inspectors with Public Health-Seattle & King
County cited 24 of Safeco Field's 55 concession stands and 38
kiosks with ``red critical'' violations. Such violations require
immediate action to prevent the spread of foodborne illnesses such
as E. coli, salmonella or hepatitis A.


   In 1996, government officials took action to correct similar
problems at the Kingdome when it was revealed that the Dome's food
vendor, Ogden Entertainment, had been cited with 158 red critical
violations over a three-year period. Volume Services at Safeco
Field has acquired 50 such violations in the space of one week.


   New York-based Ogden recently announced plans to acquire Volume
Services.


   Seven of the 26 violations identified Thursday at Safeco Field
were in stands or kiosks that already had been cited Monday. The
health department operates a ``three strikes and you're out''
policy in food safety, and will temporarily close down vendors who
violate the rule within a year's time.


   In addition to the red critical violations found among food
handlers inside the Mariners' stadium Thursday, food inspectors
temporarily closed down two outdoor food carts for lack of
hand-washing facilities. One concession stand's improperly prepared
food was destroyed.


   ``Volume Services America and the Mariners must resolve these
problems immediately,'' Plough said, or else the department ``will
take all necessary actions in order to protect the public health.''


   The Mariners on Friday issued a detailed plan in response to the
second round of food safety violations aimed at achieving 100
percent compliance.


   In addition to Volume Services hiring a full-time food safety
expert, and the Mariners' promise to assign someone to oversee
Volume Services, the Mariners announced that all food workers will
be required to complete a more ``stringent and comprehensive food
safety program'' before the next homestand begins.


   The program is called ServSafe and is offered by the National
Restaurant Association, Richner said.


   Asked what kind of training the food workers had received before
working at Safeco Field, Volume Services' Richner said she wasn't
certain but everyone had at least received the minimum training
required to be certified by the health department.

results.content:
1998-08-29 
 Price Under Control in Central, Northeast China's Flood Areas 


BEIJING, August 29 (Xinhua) -- Sharp price fluctuations
triggered by the disaster have been kept under control in China's
flood-hit areas, according to today's China Daily.


The Hunan Provincial Price Administration put a cap on the
market price of grain, edible oil, pork, vegetables, medicines,
agricultural materials and disaster-relief supplies.


The cities of Changsha, Yueyang and Changde have allocated 10.3
million yuan (1.2 million US dollars) emergency money to
reconstruct the vegetable-producing bases and transport grain and
vegetables from other cities to the province, said local price
official Zhang Zheng in a telephone interview.


The money come from a special "price adjustment fund," which is
only used when market prices see sharp fluctuation.


Zhang acknowledged that the price of rice rose by 30 percent
and that of vegetables by 60 percent in mid-July.


"The province's general price situation is normal now," he said.


When Jiujiang of Jiangxi Province faced its most serious flood
situation at the end of last month, some residents started panic
buying of rice and staple foods.


Local price officials intervened in the market by using the
grain reserves to stabilize market demands and ease people's panic.


As a result, the grain price quickly returned to the normal
level, according to price official Yang Meilai.


Government officials organized business people to purchase
fresh vegetables from neighbouring provinces and the city's
vegetable wholesale market sought help from business partners in
other provinces through its information network.


A total of 150,000 kilograms of vegetables was transported to
Jiujiang within 24 hours, said Yang.


By the end of last month, Jiangxi Province had provided three
million yuan (360,000 US dollars) from its price adjustment fund
to stabilize the market.


Hubei provincial government has urged price administrations
along the Yangtze River to strengthen their market monitoring on
the price of food, clothes and medicines.


Meanwhile, prices are also normal in northeast China's
Heilongjiang and Jilin provinces


A price official in Harbin said the price of eggs, meat and
vegetables remained stable.


In Changchun, local price official Ye Hao said the floods made
no difference to the cost of rice as there was an abundant grain
supply thanks to last year's harvest.

results.content:
1998-02-09 
 China to Replace Styrofoam Food Containers with Vegetable Fibre Material 


SHANGHAI, February 9 (Xinhua) -- China is installing 30
production lines in five provinces and municipalities that will
produce the first generation of vegetable fibre food containers to
replace styrofoam ones to solve its growing "white pollution"
problem.


The production lines will be in place by the end this year in
the city of Shanghai, and Jiangsu and Jiangxi provinces in the
east, and the city of Chongqing, and Sichuan Province in the
southwest, and will have an annual production capacity of 900
million containers.


The funding is coming from Shanghai Zhongdong Industry
Investment Co. LTD., a group of seven companies belonging to the
Ministries of Machinery and of Internal Trade, and to Shanghai,
Chongqing, and Jiangsu. It has 100 million yuan (12 million US
dollars) in registered capital.


The vegetable fibre is made from rice straw, wheat straw, and
sugarcane residue. The low-cost containers are biodegradeable, and
experts here say the discarded containers can be used as
fertilizer or as fodder for cattle.

results.content:
&HT;      


 &UR;  &QL;  &LR; 
 &UR; SAN FRANCISCO _  &LR; The past year has been an amazing one for
restaurants in the Bay Area, with exciting new places opening all
over the map. Small neighborhood spots have become destinations,
and splashier high-profile places have attracted diners in ever
increasing numbers.

   But what's made this explosion of restaurants even more
significant is the talent behind them _ the people in the kitchen
who turn out food that wows our palates and keeps us coming back
for more.


   They're not just the big names. Peeking behind the stoves, the
Food staff has uncovered five especially talented young chefs who
we bet will soon emerge as stars in their own right.


   Some have formal training; some don't. Their styles range from
straightforward and subtle to inventive and cross-cultural. But all
of them infuse their cooking with a love for what they do, and the
skills to excel at it.


   Their passion is on the plate _ and we're all the luckier for
it.


   &QL; 
 &UR; ALEXANDER ONG &LR;


   &UR; By Karola Saekel &QL;  &LR; 
 &UR; c. 1999 The San Francisco Chronicle &LR;


   If Alexander Ong's classic culinary training needed to be honed
to a razor's edge, he got his chance in Florida, when the
Ritz-Carlton organization made him a 911 chef.


   Like a paramedic, the 911 chef rushes off at a moment's notice
to rescue a kitchen in dire need: When a sous chef is hospitalized
with bleeding ulcers, another is thrown in the slammer after an
altercation in a bar, or yet another walks out in a huff on the eve
of a convention. Pinch-hitting in these situations is a challenge,
Ong admits.


   It's not a life Ong would have liked to live forever, but ``it
was a chance to learn a lot about how America works and see a good
part of the country for a single guy.'' (He has since married
Kimberly Norton, whom he met in Florida and who is now his pastry
chef.)


   Ong already had a handle on how hotel kitchens work in other
parts of the world. The son of a professional couple in Malaysia,
he wasn't interested in an academic career. After graduating from a
Catholic high school, he headed for Kuala Lumpur and a job as a
banquet server at the huge Shangri-La Hotel. His ambition was to
get into the ``controlled chaos'' of the 600-cook kitchen. The chef
finally gave in to his pleadings and told the 17-year-old to report
to the kitchen the next morning.


   ``I got myself properly outfitted in chef's whites,'' Ong
recallstells &LR;  with a grin. ``The chef took one look at me and said,
`Now get out of that uniform and put on a dishwasher's shirt.' It
was humbling, but I wasn't about to give up.''


   Co-workers couldn't understand why a son of the middle class
would want to be a menial laborer. `` `You could work in a nice
office,' they used to tell me.'' But he persisted. Three months
later, when a prep cook left, he got his chance.


   From then on Ong's career has spiraled ever upwards. Wanting to
work in the United States but not being able to obtain a visa _
``it's not like high-tech workers; cooks are a dime a dozen'' _ he
settled for a position in Bermuda. It wasn't a bad life _ good pay
undiminished by taxes, no rent and free food. With a British
Commonwealth passport, ``We could fly to New York in the morning,
shop in Chinatown, have two lunches and be back in our dormitory by
night.''


   But the work was uninspiring _ ``three-bean salad straight from
the can,'' he explains with a comic little shudder _ so he jumped
at an offer from the Atlanta Ritz-Carlton, later transferring to
Florida.


   Always looking for new challenges, there followed stints at
Caesar's Tahoe, Orocco East-West Supper Club in San Francisco's
Richmond District, in friend Chris Yeo's Straits Cafe, at Stars and
briefly as opening chef at Le Colonial.


   When longtime acquaintance, restaurant entrepreneur George Chen
(who owns Betelnut, Shanghai 1930, Long Life Noodle Co.), invited
him into a new venture, Xanadu, he saw new opportunities. He helped
design the place and, with Chen, took a nonstop eating jaunt across
A

results.content:
1998-04-17 
 Vegetable Supply in China Ample 


BEIJING, April 17 (Xinhua) -- Chinese Agriculture Ministry
sources say that vegetable supply in China now can meet the needs
of the people.


The "Shopping Program", that was developed in 1988, has played
an important role in developing non-staple foods and guaranteeing
an ample supply in urban areas.


In the past decade, China has built five vegetable production
bases in Gansu and Hainan provinces, the Inner Mongolia and
Guangxi Zhuang autonomous regions. These bases provide fresh
vegetables for the eastern and northern parts of the country.


China had 740,000 hectares of vegetable-growing land in 1997,
with a total output of 313 million tons, valued at some 250
billion yuan.


At the same time, there are now 56 large wholesales vegetable and
other farm produce markets all other the country. In Gansu
province alone, there are 100 small and medium-sized wholesales
markets selling about 500,000 tons of vegetables to more than 20
provinces.

So the government also
results.content:
1998-05-10 
 China Improving Vegetables with New Technology 


BEIJING, May 10 (Xinhua) -- More varieties of vegetables will
be served by Chinese families because of new technology.


Wang Xiaobing, an official with the Ministry of Agriculture,
said the Chinese government is making efforts to please Chinese
housewives by filling their vegetable baskets through the use of
science and technology.


"The well-to-do Chinese families not only need a sufficient
supply of vegetables, but also hope to taste what vegetables
should be," he said.


Modern science and technology have not only helped increase
the vegetable output in China, but spoiled their tastes partly due
to the use of fertilizers, said Chai Min, a staff member with the
China Vegetable Seed-Breeding Center.


So the government also needs to turn to science and technology
to make Chinese food taste better and more delicious, he added.


Wang noted that both rural and urban vegetable markets are now
steadily priced and sufficiently supplied, though Chinese families
are demanding more vegetables to meet their tastes.


He went on to say that China has made some progress in this
field during the past few years. North China's Shanxi Province has
spread 138 types of vegetable seeds during the past five
years. Liaoning Province in the northeast and Qinghai Province in
northwest of China have also made progress in reducing fertilizer
use on vegetables, he added.


"China will also conduct a study on seed-breeding, and
increasing nutrition of vegetables soon," Wang said.


To make Chinese vegetables safer for consumers, the Ministry of
Agriculture will pass a regulation guiding the production and
technological process of vegetables this year, he said.

results.content:
1999-05-21 
 Philippine Groups Protest Against Visiting Forces Pact 


MANILA, May 21 (Xinhua) -- For the second straight day, the
protest action against the Visiting Forces Agreement (VFA) between
the Philippines and the United States erupted into a violent
confrontation outside the Senate, the Manila Times said Friday.


About 300 members of anti-VFA groups trooped to the Senate
building on Thursday to express their indignation over the VFA.


They also pressed for the release of 22 people who were
arrested and detained for disrupting Senate proceedings the other
day, the newspaper said.


Armed with rocks, wooden clubs and rotten vegetables, the
protesters tried to fight their way into the Senate's session hall
where lawmakers were debating the new military pact, the newspaper
said.


But their attempt to storm the Senate building was repulsed by
the Senate's security force, it said.


Protesters lighted firecrackers and threw spoiled vegetables to
the marines, the newspaper said.


A soldier suffered deep cuts in the arm after a protester hit
him with a wooden pole, while a policeman suffered contusions, it
said.

1996-10-31 
 Shanghai Residents Able to Enjoy 700 Kinds of Vegetable 


SHANGHAI, October 31 (Xinhua) -- Home cooks in Shanghai can
dish up two vegetables a day - without ever serving the same one
twice in the same year!


It is because China's biggest city boasts more than 700 species
of vegetables, a record high in the area's food availability.


But whether housewives in Shanghai will take up the challenge
is another matter.


Latest statistics from a municipal department in charge of
agricultural science show that Shanghai residents now enjoy more
than 700 species of vegetables.


Agro-technicians have improved some existing species, saved
other endangered species, and imported fine species from abroad.


Official figures indicate that over the past three years, the
municipal government has put more than 400 million yuan (48
million US dollars) into the upgrading of vegetable cultivating
facilities.

results.content:
1996-08-16 
 Farmers Profit from Vegetable Exports 


BEIJING, August 16 (Xinhua) -- Farmers in east China's Shandong
Province have a new road to wealth as export-oriented agriculture
has taken off in the area, today's China Daily reports.


It says Yantai and the eastern part of the province have become
"one big garden", turning out veggies for east Asian countries and
reaping a bountiful harvest of profit in return.


In Laiyang, 90 kilometers south of Yantai and the most prolific
plot in the regional vegetable garden, more than 100,000 farmers
in 400 villages working 20,000 hectares of farm land are producing
vegetables for foreign tables, the paper reports.


They earned 100 million US dollars exporting 100,000 tons of
vegetables last year.


The farmers supplied not only Chinese traditional vegetables,
but also ones introduced from foreign countries to satisfy foreign
tastebuds.


Yantai has also experimented with advanced technology along
with new vegetable species. In particular, greenhouse technology
has ensured a year-long supply of vegetables.


With Shandong's success as a model, five provinces around
Shandong has now devoted 20,000 hectares of farm land to vegetable
production.


Yantai is also working on the next step along the food chain,
developing vegetable processing and packaging industries.
